title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Multi-agent cooperation is a challenging problem in AI research, particularly when agents have different goals and capabilities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that enables explainable cooperation among multiple agents. HGAT learns to represent agents as nodes in a hierarchical graph, where attention mechanisms are applied to model complex relationships between agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in a variety of cooperative scenarios, including robot soccer and disaster response. Our results show that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task performance and provides interpretable insights into agent decision-making.

title: Efficient Index Pruning for Scalable Neural Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval has shown great promise in various information retrieval tasks, but its computational cost and memory requirements limit its scalability. This paper addresses this issue by proposing an efficient index pruning method, which reduces the number of passages to be ranked without sacrificing retrieval accuracy. Our approach leverages the clustering structure of the passage representations and the locality-sensitive hashing to identify and remove redundant passages in the index. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method achieves significant speedup and memory reduction while maintaining the retrieval performance of the original dense passage retrieval model.

title: Coordinated Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Dynamic Obstacle Avoidance in Real-World Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinated multi-agent pathfinding is a challenging problem in real-world environments, where agents must avoid collisions with each other and dynamic obstacles. This paper presents a novel approach, 'MAPDO', that integrates graph-based path planning with model predictive control to enable efficient and safe navigation. We propose a decentralized communication protocol that enables agents to share intentions and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results in a warehouse scenario demonstrate that MAPDO outperforms existing methods in terms of success rate, path length, and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Column-Stores
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of column-store databases for real-time analytics has led to a pressing need for efficient indexing techniques. In this paper, we propose a novel indexing scheme, 'ColIndex', that leverages the columnar storage layout to accelerate query processing. ColIndex utilizes a combination of Bloom filters and adaptive sampling to reduce the number of disk accesses, resulting in significant performance gains. Our evaluation on a distributed column-store demonstrates that ColIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x for aggregation queries and 2x for filtering queries.

title: Autonomous Conflict Resolution in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require conflict resolution mechanisms to ensure efficient and fair resource allocation. This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous conflict resolution using graph convolutional networks (GCNs). Our proposed framework, 'AgentGCN', leverages the structural properties of agent interactions to learn conflict resolution strategies. We demonstrate the effectiveness of AgentGCN in various scenarios, including resource allocation and task assignment, outperforming traditional rule-based and reinforcement learning-based approaches. The results show that AgentGCN can adapt to dynamic environments and generalize to unseen conflict scenarios, making it a promising solution for real-world multi-agent applications.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, allocating tasks efficiently among heterogeneous agents is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous task allocation using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'MARL-TA', which leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning to adaptively allocate tasks based on agent capabilities, task requirements, and environmental dynamics. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional heuristic-based methods, achieving improved task completion rates and reduced response times.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized the way we interact with digital information, but limited research has focused on the role of haptic feedback in shaping user experience. This study investigates the effect of personalized haptic feedback on user engagement, satisfaction, and performance in VR environments. We propose a novel framework for adaptively tailoring haptic feedback to individual users' preferences, and evaluate its impact through a user study involving 30 participants. Results show that personalized haptic feedback significantly enhances user experience, particularly for users with prior VR exposure. Our findings have implications for designing more immersive and inclusive VR systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but users with visual impairments are often excluded from its benefits. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR interfaces that cater to users with visual impairments. We conducted a participatory design study with 15 participants with visual impairments and developed a set of guidelines for accessible VR interaction techniques. Our approach incorporates audio-based navigation, tactile feedback, and personalized customization options. A usability evaluation with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Context-Aware Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques often neglect the contextual information associated with user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion framework, 'CAQE', which incorporates both semantic and spatial contextual features to refine the query representation. We introduce a graph-based approach to model the relationships between query terms, entities, and spatial locations, enabling more effective retrieval of relevant documents. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that CAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision and recall.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction Design
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but current interaction designs often neglect the role of embodied cognition. This paper investigates the effects of gesture-based interaction on user experience and performance in VR. We designed and evaluated a novel gesture-based system that leverages cognitive metaphors to enhance spatial reasoning and presence. Our user study reveals significant improvements in task completion time and self-reported sense of presence compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. The findings have implications for the development of more intuitive and immersive VR experiences.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Ranking and Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Document retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval (IR) systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, HNRM, which leverages query expansion and document embeddings to improve retrieval efficiency and accuracy. HNRM incorporates a query-dependent attention mechanism to adaptively weight document terms and a hierarchical ranking strategy to prune irrelevant documents. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that HNRM outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models in terms of retrieval speed and effectiveness, while achieving competitive performance on standard IR metrics.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, but existing approaches often rely on single-modal inputs (e.g., facial expressions or speech). This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multiple modalities (video, audio, and text) to recognize emotions in a more comprehensive and robust manner. Our HAN model learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and temporal segments, achieving state-of-the-art performance on three benchmark datasets. We also provide insights into the learned attention patterns, demonstrating the model's ability to capture subtle emotional cues.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years, as they provide insights into the decision-making process of AI-driven recommender models. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture for ERS, which leverages graph neural networks to model complex user-item interactions. Our approach incorporates multi-level attention mechanisms to capture both local and global dependencies in the graph, enabling the model to generate interpretable explanations for its recommendations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in improving recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Query-Oriented Document Embeddings for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a critical component of many question answering and information retrieval systems. However, existing methods often rely on computationally expensive neural networks or sparse keyword-based representations. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'QODE', which learns query-oriented document embeddings that capture the semantic relationships between passages and queries. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QODE achieves state-of-the-art passage retrieval performance while reducing computational overhead by up to 75%. We further analyze the effectiveness of QODE in various IR applications, including open-domain question answering and dialog systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering (QA) models have achieved remarkable performance in recent years, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and understanding. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for explainable QA, which leverages graph-based attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between entities, concepts, and context. Our approach enables interpretable and fine-grained explanations for QA predictions, improving model trustworthiness and facilitating knowledge graph construction. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing human-understandable explanations.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly popular due to their ability to scale horizontally. However, optimizing query execution plans in such systems remains a complex problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed relational databases. Our method, called 'Distributed Query Optimizer' (DQO), uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan based on the database's workload and system configuration. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DQO outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent Framework for Real-Time Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of renewable energy sources, smart grids require efficient and adaptive resource allocation to ensure reliable and efficient power distribution. This paper proposes a decentralized autonomous agent framework, 'DARA', that leverages multi-agent systems to optimize real-time resource allocation in smart grids. DARA employs a hybrid approach, combining model-based reasoning with machine learning, to enable agents to learn from experience and adapt to changing grid conditions. Experimental results using real-world data demonstrate that DARA achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and grid stability compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Adaptive Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper tackles the problem of coordinated exploration in multi-agent systems, where agents must jointly explore a complex environment to maximize cumulative rewards. We propose a novel graph neural network (GNN) architecture, Adaptive Graph Explorer (AGE), which adaptively updates the graph structure to reflect the agents' changing beliefs about the environment. AGE enables agents to share information and coordinate their exploration policies, resulting in improved exploration efficiency and task performance. Experimental results on a range of multi-agent environments demonstrate the effectiveness of AGE in achieving better coordination and exploration compared to baseline methods.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Hierarchical Temporal Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are increasingly vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their reliability in critical applications. This paper presents a novel approach for detecting such attacks using hierarchical temporal convolutional networks (HTCNs). Our method leverages the temporal dependencies in the input data to identify subtle patterns indicative of adversarial perturbations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art detection methods, achieving an average detection accuracy of 95.2% while maintaining a low false positive rate.

title: Scalable Data Integration for Heterogeneous IoT Devices using Graph-Based Data Modeling
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to a surge in heterogeneous data sources, posing significant challenges for data integration and analysis. This paper proposes a novel graph-based data modeling approach, called 'IoTGraph', which enables scalable and efficient data integration for IoT devices. IoTGraph represents device data as a graph, allowing for flexible schema evolution and support for diverse data formats. We evaluate IoTGraph on a large-scale IoT dataset and demonstrate improved data integration performance and reduced data inconsistency compared to traditional relational database approaches.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are increasingly prevalent in modern data-intensive applications, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a Markov decision process that models the query optimization problem and employ a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate a significant reduction in query latency and improvement in resource utilization compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is crucial for many applications, but existing methods often lack interpretability. This paper introduces HTAN, a hierarchical attention network that detects anomalies while providing insights into the contributing factors. HTAN consists of a stacked encoder-decoder architecture with multi-level attention mechanisms, enabling the model to focus on relevant segments and features. We demonstrate HTAN's effectiveness on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance and offering visual explanations for detected anomalies.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we present a decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, where agents learn to allocate tasks using reinforcement learning. We propose a novel algorithm, 'DRL-TA', which utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn task allocation policies. Our approach enables agents to adapt to dynamic task environments and make efficient allocation decisions without relying on a centralized controller. Experimental results demonstrate that DRL-TA outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and system efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data and provide high availability. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in these systems. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using machine learning. We develop a framework that leverages query execution history and system metrics to train a machine learning model that predicts optimal query plans. Our approach is designed to work in a distributed setting, where multiple nodes are involved in query execution. We evaluate our approach using a real-world dataset and show that it outperforms traditional query optimization techniques in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for adaptive traffic signal control. We model the problem as a partially observable Markov decision process, where each agent corresponds to a traffic intersection. Our approach leverages graph convolutional networks to learn the local traffic dynamics and interaction between adjacent intersections. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in a simulated urban traffic network, achieving a 25% reduction in average travel time compared to traditional fixed-timing control strategies.

title: A Hybrid Indexing Approach for Efficient Query Processing in Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: NoSQL databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data analytics. However, query processing in these databases can be inefficient due to the lack of indexing mechanisms. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'HIQ', that combines the benefits of tree-based and hash-based indexing techniques. HIQ is specifically designed for column-oriented NoSQL databases and leverages the characteristics of column stores to optimize query performance. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HIQ significantly outperforms existing indexing techniques in terms of query latency and throughput.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a critical component in modern business intelligence applications. However, optimizing queries in such systems remains a major bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages the benefits of column stores to accelerate query processing. We introduce a cost-based optimization technique that considers both storage and computational costs, resulting in significant performance improvements. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that ColOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x, making it suitable for large-scale, real-time data warehousing applications.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where autonomous agents need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a decentralized auction-based mechanism, 'MAAT', for task allocation in dynamic environments. MAAT leverages a novel bidding strategy that takes into account agent capabilities, task urgency, and inter-agent dependencies. We prove the optimality and stability of MAAT under various task and agent distributions. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that MAAT outperforms centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and adaptability to changing conditions.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various information retrieval tasks. However, they often suffer from limited contextual understanding, leading to suboptimal ranking results. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, 'QDE', which leverages the query context to selectively expand relevant documents. We introduce a two-stage framework that first identifies query-dependent keywords and then incorporates these keywords into the document representation via a learned attention mechanism. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that QDE consistently improves the ranking performance of neural retrieval models, especially for long-tail queries.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem due to the lack of centralized control and communication constraints. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning approach, 'DRL-TA', which enables agents to learn task allocation strategies through experience. We model the task allocation problem as a Markov decision process and develop a decentralized Q-learning algorithm that enables agents to adapt to changing task requirements and agent availability. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that DRL-TA outperforms traditional heuristic-based methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification on graph-structured data is a challenging task due to the scarcity of labeled nodes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages both local and global graph structures to adapt to new classes. HGAT consists of a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant nodes and edges at multiple scales, and a meta-learning framework that fine-tunes the model on a few labeled nodes. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot node classification, achieving up to 15% improvement in accuracy.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various machine learning tasks, but their success heavily relies on careful hyperparameter tuning. This process is often time-consuming and computationally expensive. We propose a novel approach, BOHyp, which leverages Bayesian optimization to efficiently search the hyperparameter space. BOHyp models the hyperparameter-performance relationship using a probabilistic surrogate function and adaptively selects the most informative hyperparameter configurations to evaluate. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that BOHyp can find near-optimal hyperparameters with significantly fewer evaluations than traditional grid search and random search methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval (IR) due to the inherent ambiguity of user queries. Query expansion (QE) is a popular technique to resolve this issue, but traditional QE methods rely on manually crafted rules or statistical models. This paper proposes a novel QE approach that leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic query representations. Our model, dubbed 'QE-Net', integrates a transformer-based encoder with a graph-based attention mechanism to capture contextual relationships between query terms. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that QE-Net significantly outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of mean average precision and recall.

title: Deep Semantic Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of document retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the precision and recall of search results. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DeepSQE', which leverages semantic embeddings to expand queries with relevant terms. Our method incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on the most informative terms in the query and document contexts. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepSQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and reduced query latency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting has numerous applications in finance, healthcare, and climate science. However, most state-of-the-art models lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand the underlying factors driving the predictions. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) for explainable time series forecasting. HAN leverages a novel hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant time steps and features, allowing for visual attribution of the predictions. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms existing methods in terms of forecasting accuracy and provides meaningful explanations for its predictions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Protein-Protein Interaction Prediction
paper_abstract: Predicting protein-protein interactions (PPIs) is a crucial task in computational biology. Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results, but they often struggle with complex graph structures and limited labeled data. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant subgraphs and proteins. HGAT consists of two stages: a graph attention module that identifies key proteins and a hierarchical pooling module that aggregates node features. We evaluate HGAT on several PPI benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average AUC-ROC of 0.953. Our results highlight the potential of HGAT for PPI prediction and its applications in drug discovery and disease diagnosis.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its accessibility for users with disabilities remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences that cater to users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key accessibility barriers and developed a set of guidelines for VR developers to create accessible and usable VR interfaces. Our evaluation results demonstrate that our framework improves the overall VR experience for users with disabilities, enhancing their sense of presence, engagement, and satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Modern recommendation systems rely on graph-based models to capture complex user-item relationships. However, the scalability of these models is often limited by the quadratic complexity of graph neural networks. In this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages graph clustering and attention mechanisms to scale to massive user-item graphs. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmarks while reducing computational complexity by an order of magnitude. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence of HGAT and demonstrate its applicability in real-world e-commerce scenarios.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for explainable multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach enables agents to selectively focus on relevant teammates and environmental features, leading to improved cooperation and decision-making. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in a variety of multi-agent environments, including traffic management and robotic soccer. Furthermore, we provide visualizations and quantitative metrics to illustrate the interpretable nature of our model, facilitating human understanding of complex agent behaviors.

title: Investigating the Role of Embodiment in Virtual Reality for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but the impact of embodiment on user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study examining the effects of embodiment on user engagement, presence, and cognitive load in VR environments. We designed three VR scenarios with varying levels of embodiment, from low (controllers-only) to high (full-body tracking), and collected both quantitative (physiological, behavioral) and qualitative (interviews, surveys) data from 30 participants. Our results show that increasing embodiment leads to higher user engagement, sense of presence, and reduced cognitive load, but also highlights the importance of considering individual differences in embodiment preferences.

title: Hierarchical Transfer Learning for Imbalanced Time Series Classification
paper_abstract: Time series classification is a critical task in various domains, including healthcare, finance, and IoT. However, real-world datasets often exhibit class imbalance, leading to poor performance of traditional machine learning models. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical transfer learning approach, 'HiTS', which leverages pre-trained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) as feature extractors and adaptively adjusts the feature importance based on class frequencies. We evaluate HiTS on four benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in F1-score and AUC-ROC compared to state-of-the-art techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the heterogeneity and complexity of the input features. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our HAN model consists of multiple layers of attention mechanisms that capture hierarchical dependencies between modalities and facilitate the fusion of complementary information. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and CMU-MOSEI datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance in multimodal emotion recognition.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Adaptive Ontology-Based Communication
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective communication is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, the complexity of agent interactions and the diversity of agent knowledge representations hinder the development of efficient communication protocols. This paper presents AOCC, an adaptive ontology-based communication framework that enables agents to dynamically align their knowledge representations and facilitate more effective coordination. AOCC leverages machine learning-based ontology alignment and probabilistic modeling to infer the most relevant information to share among agents. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that AOCC significantly improves the overall system performance and adaptability compared to traditional communication approaches.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-time Anomaly Detection in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing number of IoT devices has led to a surge in anomalous traffic, posing significant security threats. This paper proposes a novel real-time anomaly detection framework, 'IoT-Guard', which leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to identify and respond to anomalies in IoT networks. IoT-Guard uses a Double Deep Q-Network (DDQN) to learn a policy that maps network traffic patterns to anomaly scores, and a custom-designed reward function to optimize detection accuracy. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that IoT-Guard outperforms traditional machine learning approaches in terms of detection accuracy and speed, while adapting to concept drift and varying network conditions.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Dense Retrieval
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer a given question. However, existing dense retrieval methods suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. We propose a hierarchical dense retrieval approach, 'HDR', which leverages a two-stage retrieval process to efficiently identify relevant passages. Our method first uses a coarse-grained retriever to select top-k candidates, followed by a fine-grained reranker to re-score and re-rank the candidates. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset show that HDR achieves a 2x speedup and 10% improvement in top-20 passage retrieval accuracy compared to state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, is crucial for human-computer interaction. However, existing approaches often suffer from high computational complexity and limited interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that efficiently integrates and selectively focuses on relevant modalities. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical structure to model intra- and inter-modal relationships, resulting in improved recognition accuracy and reduced computational cost. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing inference time by up to 30%

title: Adversarial Attack Detection for Deep Neural Networks using Graph-Based Anomaly Analysis
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance and reliability. This paper presents a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks on DNNs using graph-based anomaly analysis. We model the DNN's intermediate representations as a graph and identify anomalous patterns indicative of adversarial attacks. Our method, dubbed 'GraphGuard', leverages graph convolutional networks and attention mechanisms to detect subtle changes in the graph structure. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphGuard in detecting various types of adversarial attacks, including input manipulation and poisoning attacks.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Robot Systems
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple autonomous agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinate autonomous agents using hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL). We design a hierarchical framework that consists of a high-level coordination layer and a low-level control layer. The coordination layer uses a centralized critic to learn a value function that guides the agents' decisions, while the control layer employs decentralized actor-critic methods to execute actions. We evaluate our approach in a simulated multi-robot system and demonstrate improved coordination and task completion rates compared to decentralized reinforcement learning methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting models often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand their predictions. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs) for explainable time-series forecasting. HANs employ a hierarchical structure to learn attention weights at multiple scales, enabling the model to focus on relevant features and time-steps. We propose a novel attention-based feature importance metric, which provides insights into the model's decision-making process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HANs achieve state-of-the-art forecasting performance while providing meaningful explanations for their predictions.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel distributed approach, 'GraphMA', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn task allocation strategies for heterogeneous agents. GraphMA represents the agent network as a graph and uses GNNs to learn a latent representation of agent capabilities and task requirements. Through extensive simulations, we demonstrate that GraphMA outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization, while adapting to dynamic changes in the agent network.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Label Node Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label node classification is a fundamental problem in graph-based machine learning, where each node can belong to multiple classes. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that effectively captures complex node relationships and label correlations. Our approach employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to identify relevant neighbors and labels at multiple scales, allowing the model to adapt to diverse graph structures and label distributions. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of macro-F1 score and label ranking metrics.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel decentralized approach, GCN-TA, that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn task allocation policies. Our method exploits the graph structure of agent interactions and uses GCNs to encode agent features and task dependencies. We show that GCN-TA outperforms traditional centralized and distributed methods in various simulated scenarios, including robotic search and rescue, and smart traffic management. The proposed approach enables real-time task allocation in large-scale multi-agent systems with limited communication overhead.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in improving the effectiveness of information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks. We introduce a model that learns to generate expanded queries by modeling the semantic relationships between the original query terms and the relevant documents. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query expansion methods and achieves state-of-the-art results in terms of retrieval accuracy. We also show that the learned expanded queries can be effectively used to improve the performance of various retrieval models.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Temporal Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs (KGs) have become increasingly prevalent in many AI applications, but their temporal nature poses significant challenges for efficient embedding and inference. This paper introduces HiGATE, a novel hierarchical graph attention network for scalable temporal KG embedding. HiGATE leverages a graph attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant temporal dependencies and adaptively aggregate entity representations across different granularities. Our extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiGATE achieves state-of-the-art performance in link prediction and entity classification tasks while reducing computational overhead by up to 40% compared to existing methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents Using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents using multi-agent reinforcement learning. We propose a novel algorithm, 'MARA', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies for task assignment in a distributed manner. MARA utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to select tasks based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. We evaluate MARA in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search queries often require manual reformulation to achieve relevant results. We propose a novel reinforcement learning-based approach, 'RL-QE', to automate query expansion. Our method leverages a Markov decision process to iteratively refine the query, balancing exploration and exploitation. The reward function incorporates both relevance and fluency metrics, ensuring the generated queries are both effective and readable. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc dataset demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and query quality.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Document Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, which involves augmenting the original query with relevant terms to improve retrieval accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages deep learning-based document embeddings to generate query expansions. Our method, named 'DeepQE', uses a neural network to learn a dense representation of documents and queries, which enables accurate identification of relevant expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods, such as Rocchio and LCA, in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Relational Link Prediction
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has emerged as a promising approach for link prediction tasks. However, existing methods often struggle to effectively model complex relationships and hierarchical structures present in real-world graphs. This paper proposes a novel KGE framework, 'HATKE', which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant entities and relations. We demonstrate that HATKE outperforms state-of-the-art methods on benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in both accuracy and computational efficiency. We further explore the interpretability of HATKE through visualizations of attention weights, providing insights into the learned graph patterns.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks via Bayesian Uncertainty Estimation
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can severely compromise their performance. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'BayesGuard', that leverages Bayesian uncertainty estimation to analyze the robustness of DNNs against adversarial attacks. We introduce a hierarchical Bayesian model that captures the uncertainty of DNN weights and outputs, enabling the detection of potential vulnerabilities. Our approach is shown to outperform existing methods in identifying adversarial examples on benchmark datasets, and provides a more comprehensive understanding of DNN robustness.

title: Incentivizing Cooperation in Multi-Agent Systems via Adaptive Reward Shaping
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to incentivizing cooperation in multi-agent systems by adaptively shaping rewards based on the agents' behavioral patterns. Our method, called Adaptive Reward Shaping (ARS), uses a decentralized, online learning framework to identify and reinforce cooperative behaviors. We evaluate ARS in a series of experiments involving both homogeneous and heterogeneous agent populations, demonstrating significant improvements in cooperative outcomes compared to traditional reward functions. Theoretical analysis and simulations further support the effectiveness of ARS in promoting cooperation in complex, dynamic environments.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to enable cooperative task allocation. We introduce a decentralized, model-free algorithm that utilizes a graph neural network to represent agent interactions and a deep Q-network to learn optimal task assignments. Experimental results in a simulated package delivery scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and reduction in overall system latency compared to traditional, rule-based allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Relational Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial component in various AI applications. However, existing KGE methods struggle to capture complex relationships between entities in multi-relational knowledge graphs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) model that leverages the hierarchical structure of knowledge graphs to learn more informative entity representations. HGAN consists of a stacked attention mechanism that adaptively focuses on relevant neighboring entities and relationships at each hierarchical level. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in link prediction and triple classification tasks.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Specialized Search Engines
paper_abstract: Specialized search engines, such as those used in e-commerce or biomedical domains, require efficient and effective retrieval mechanisms to handle complex queries. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE+', which leverages a combination of lexical and semantic analysis to disambiguate query terms and expand relevant concepts. We demonstrate the efficacy of HQE+ through experiments on a large-scale e-commerce dataset, showcasing significant improvements in retrieval precision and latency compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between massive datasets. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the inherent complexity of graph structures and the need for distributed processing. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages a combination of graph summarization, query rewriting, and cost-based optimization techniques to improve query performance by up to 3x compared to existing approaches. We evaluate GraphOpt on a real-world social network dataset and demonstrate its scalability and effectiveness in handling complex graph queries.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Emotional Support in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in providing emotional support to individuals, but effective communication with users remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces 'Echo', a novel embodied conversational agent designed to provide empathetic support in VR. Echo uses a combination of machine learning-based affect recognition and natural language processing to simulate human-like conversations. We conducted a user study to evaluate the efficacy of Echo in reducing stress and anxiety levels in participants. Results show that users who interacted with Echo reported significant reductions in self-reported stress levels compared to a control group.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but its adoption is hindered by the lack of accessibility features for users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences that cater to the needs of visually impaired users. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with visually impaired individuals to identify key challenges and opportunities in VR interaction. Our framework incorporates audio-based navigation, tactile feedback, and personalized accessibility features. We evaluated our approach through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in user engagement and task completion rates compared to traditional VR interfaces.

title: Robustifying Deep Reinforcement Learning with Adversarial Experience Replay
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive successes in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes an adversarial experience replay (AER) framework that enhances the robustness of DRL agents against perturbed state observations. We introduce a novel algorithm that generates adversarial transitions using a learned perturbation model and incorporates them into the experience replay buffer. Our experiments on Atari games and robotic control tasks demonstrate that AER significantly improves the resilience of DRL agents to adversarial attacks, while maintaining their performance in nominal environments.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, leveraging auction-based mechanisms to optimize task assignments. Our approach, called 'AuctionMAS', enables agents to bid on tasks based on their capabilities and preferences, while ensuring fairness and efficiency through a Vickrey-Clarke-Groves (VCG) auction mechanism. We evaluate AuctionMAS in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods. Theoretical analysis and experiments validate the effectiveness of our approach in large-scale, dynamic multi-agent environments.

title: Investigating the Effects of Haptic Feedback on Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems rely heavily on gesture recognition to provide an immersive user experience. However, the lack of haptic feedback can lead to recognition errors and user frustration. This paper explores the impact of haptic feedback on gesture recognition in VR. We designed a custom VR system with a haptic feedback device and conducted a user study to evaluate the effects of varying feedback intensities on recognition accuracy. Our results show that optimized haptic feedback can improve gesture recognition by up to 23% compared to visual-only feedback, and that user performance is highly dependent on the feedback intensity and gesture type.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommender Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems have become ubiquitous in modern online services, but their lack of transparency hinders user trust and accountability. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network, 'HGAN', which incorporates hierarchical graph structures to model complex user-item relationships. By learning attention weights at multiple scales, HGAN provides intuitive explanations for its recommendations, improving user satisfaction and reducing bias. We evaluate HGAN on three real-world datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval in Large-Scale Text Collections
paper_abstract: Classical document retrieval systems rely on term-frequency based representations, which become inefficient when dealing with large-scale text collections. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive document embedding approach, 'QADE', that leverages the context of the query to dynamically adjust the document representations. QADE utilizes a neural network-based architecture to learn a shared representation space for queries and documents, enabling efficient retrieval through similarity searches. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QADE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) often require efficient task allocation to achieve global objectives. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task allocation framework that leverages distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) techniques. By modeling task dependencies as constraints, our approach enables agents to negotiate and allocate tasks in a decentralized manner, ensuring feasibility and optimality. Experimental results on a logistics scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms centralized task allocation methods in terms of solution quality and scalability.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience and engagement in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, analyzing their behavioral and physiological responses to customized avatars. Our results show that users who interacted with personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of presence, enjoyment, and perceived control, leading to increased engagement and reduced cybersickness. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR systems and potential applications in education, therapy, and entertainment.

title: Optimizing Query Performance through Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant performance challenges due to data fragmentation and network latency. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing approach, 'DynIndex', which dynamically adjusts the index structure based on query patterns and data distribution. We introduce a novel cost model that captures the trade-offs between index maintenance, query optimization, and data consistency. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that DynIndex improves query performance by up to 3x compared to traditional indexing methods, while minimizing index maintenance overhead.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various AI applications, but their lack of interpretability hinders their adoption in high-stakes domains. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that learns to explicitly model entity relationships and attributes in knowledge graphs. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant entities, attributes, and relationships, enabling the generation of transparent and explainable embeddings. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in improving both performance and interpretability over existing knowledge graph embedding methods.

title: Investigating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Games
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) gaming has gained immense popularity, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the effect of haptic feedback on user experience in VR games. We designed a novel haptic feedback system that simulates tactile sensations, such as texture and weight, and conducted a user study with 30 participants. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly increases user engagement, measured by gameplay duration and self-reported enjoyment. Furthermore, we found that haptic feedback enhances spatial awareness and reduces simulator sickness. The findings of this research have important implications for the design of immersive VR experiences.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Resource allocation in cloud computing is a complex optimization problem that requires efficient management of resources to minimize costs and maximize performance. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'CloudOpt', which learns to allocate resources dynamically based on workload patterns and system constraints. We employ a hybrid DRL architecture that combines the strengths of actor-critic methods and graph neural networks to model complex dependencies between resources and workloads. Experimental results on a real-world cloud dataset demonstrate that CloudOpt achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and response time compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to efficiently retrieve relevant documents for complex queries. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document representation, 'HierDoc', which leverages semantic embeddings and graph-based clustering to organize documents into a hierarchical structure. This allows for faster query processing and improved retrieval accuracy. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierDoc on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant reductions in query latency and improvement in mean average precision compared to state-of-the-art retrieval models.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data (e.g., speech, text, and vision) has gained significant attention in human-computer interaction. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features for emotion recognition. Our approach integrates attention mechanisms at multiple levels, enabling the model to provide explainable results by highlighting the most informative modalities and features. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recognition accuracy and provides interpretable results.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Long-Tail Classification
paper_abstract: Long-tail classification problems, where a few classes dominate the majority, are prevalent in many real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that adaptively focuses on relevant features and classes to improve classification accuracy and efficiency. Our HAN model consists of a class-aware attention module that selects informative features and a hierarchical classification module that leverages the attention weights to predict probabilities. Experiments on several long-tail datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant improvements in accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer a user's question. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document embedding (HDE) approach that captures both local and global document structures to improve passage retrieval efficiency. Our HDE model consists of a document-level transformer encoder and a passage-level dense retriever, which are jointly trained to optimize a combination of retrieval and answer generation objectives. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art dense retrieval models while reducing computational costs by up to 40%

title: Hierarchical Visual Attention for Explainable Robot Learning from Demonstration
paper_abstract: Learning from demonstration (LfD) is a promising approach to teach robots new skills, but it often requires large amounts of annotated data and lacks transparency. This paper presents a novel hierarchical visual attention mechanism, 'HVA-LfD', which enables robots to learn from demonstrations while providing explainable decision-making. Our approach leverages a two-level attention framework, focusing on both the demonstration sequence and the robotic task at hand. We evaluate HVA-LfD on a robot grasping task and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art LfD methods in terms of task success rate and interpretability.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Adaptive Auction Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages adaptive auction mechanisms to allocate tasks to agents in real-time. Our approach, called 'AuctionMA', uses a novel bidding strategy that incorporates agent capabilities, task requirements, and environmental uncertainty. We provide theoretical guarantees for the AuctionMA's convergence and demonstrate its effectiveness in simulations of search-and-rescue and surveillance scenarios, outperforming state-of-the-art decentralized allocation methods.

title: Coordinating Task-Oriented Agents via Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: We present a novel framework for coordinating task-oriented agents in decentralized partially observable Markov decision processes (Dec-POMDPs). Our approach, called COORD, leverages a hierarchical decomposition of the Dec-POMDP into smaller sub-problems, which are solved using a decentralized optimization algorithm. We show that COORD outperforms existing methods in several benchmarks, achieving improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead. Furthermore, we provide theoretical guarantees on the performance of COORD in certain classes of Dec-POMDPs.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Study on Eye Movement Patterns
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology advances, there is a growing need for natural and intuitive interaction methods. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system for VR, which leverages machine learning to classify eye movement patterns and infer user intent. We conducted a user study to collect and analyze eye-tracking data, and our results show that our approach can accurately recognize user actions such as selection, manipulation, and navigation. We also investigate the effects of gaze-based interaction on user experience and discuss implications for future VR system design.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Word Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval tasks often suffer from vocabulary mismatch between queries and documents, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'WEMbed', which leverages word embeddings to effectively capture semantic relationships between terms. WEMbed uses a combination of local and global context-aware embeddings to generate a weighted set of expansion terms, which are then integrated into the original query. Experimental results on several standard TREC datasets demonstrate that WEMbed outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents using multi-agent deep reinforcement learning. We propose a novel algorithm, 'Dec-MADRL', which enables agents to learn cooperative strategies for task allocation in complex, dynamic environments. Dec-MADRL combines graph neural networks with deep Q-networks to learn a distributed task allocation policy, allowing agents to adapt to changing task requirements and environmental constraints. Experimental results using a simulated robotics testbed demonstrate the effectiveness of Dec-MADRL in improving task completion rates and reducing agent collisions compared to centralized optimization methods.

title: Designing Emotive Avatars for Enhanced User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformative potential, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper presents an emotive avatar framework, 'EmoVR', which leverages affective computing and social presence theory to create more relatable and engaging virtual agents. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, demonstrating that EmoVR avatars elicit stronger emotional responses and increase user motivation compared to traditional VR interfaces. Our findings have implications for VR-based education, therapy, and entertainment applications.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Relation Extraction
paper_abstract: Few-shot relation extraction (FSRE) is a challenging task, especially when dealing with long-tail relations and limited labeled data. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages graph structures to model entity interactions and attention mechanisms to focus on crucial context. HGAT consists of a hierarchical graph encoder and a relation-aware attention module, enabling the model to capture complex relational patterns from limited examples. Experimental results on the FewRel dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art FSRE models, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 4.2% on 1-shot and 2-shot settings.

title: Gaze-Informed Adaptive User Model for Enhanced Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize assistive technologies, but existing systems often fail to account for individual differences in user abilities and needs. This paper introduces GAUMER, a novel gaze-informed adaptive user model that leverages machine learning and eye-tracking data to personalize VR interactions for users with disabilities. Our approach dynamically adjusts interface elements, navigation, and feedback mechanisms to accommodate users' gaze patterns, cognitive load, and motor abilities. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates that GAUMER significantly improves task completion times, accuracy, and overall user experience for individuals with motor impairments.

title: Neural Ranking Models with Query Reformulation for Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models (NRMs) have demonstrated impressive performance in document retrieval tasks. However, they often struggle with complex or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel query reformulation approach, 'QR-NRM', which leverages a generative adversarial network (GAN) to iteratively refine and expand the original query. Our method incorporates a relevance-based reward function to guide the GAN, ensuring that the reformulated queries better capture the user's information need. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset show that QR-NRM significantly outperforms existing NRM architectures, particularly for queries with low lexical overlap with relevant documents.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. However, most existing methods lack interpretability, making it challenging to identify the root causes of anomalies. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that detects anomalies while providing explainable insights. Our model leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture complex patterns at multiple scales and focuses on the most relevant segments of the time series. We evaluate HAN on several real-world datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting anomalies while outperforming state-of-the-art methods in terms of explainability.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Effective task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and resources need to collaborate to achieve common goals. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinated task allocation using deep reinforcement learning. We introduce a decentralized, multi-agent Q-network (MAQN) that learns to allocate tasks in a distributed manner. MAQN leverages graph attention mechanisms to model agent interactions and task dependencies, enabling efficient and adaptive task assignment. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utilization compared to traditional, centralized allocation methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework based on distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) techniques. Our approach, called DACOTA, enables agents to negotiate and allocate tasks in a distributed manner, without relying on a centralized authority. We propose a novel DCOP algorithm that incorporates a heuristic search strategy to improve the quality of the allocation. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that DACOTA outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and communication overhead.

title: Efficient Conflict Resolution for Real-Time Database Replication
paper_abstract: Real-time database replication is crucial for many applications, but conflict resolution remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach, 'CRISP', which leverages machine learning-based prediction models to anticipate and resolve conflicts proactively. CRISP integrates a probabilistic conflict detection mechanism with a multi-version concurrency control protocol, enabling efficient and scalable replication in high-throughput environments. Our experiments on a simulated e-commerce platform demonstrate that CRISP reduces conflict resolution latency by up to 75% compared to state-of-the-art approaches, while maintaining high data consistency and availability.

title: Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complex and nuanced nature of patent language. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'RL-QE', that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize the selection of expansion terms. We model query expansion as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to select terms that maximize the relevance of the retrieved patents. Experimental results on a large patent corpus demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms traditional query expansion methods, such as pseudo-relevance feedback and word embedding-based methods, in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: The increasing demand for real-time analytics has led to a growing importance of efficient query optimization techniques. This paper presents a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'Grapheon', which exploits the structural properties of query graphs to optimize query plans for real-time analytics workloads. We introduce a cost-based optimization framework that leverages graph convolutional networks to predict query execution times and identifies the most efficient query plans. Experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that Grapheon outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and throughput.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has witnessed significant advancements with the advent of deep learning. However, existing methods often rely on opaque representations, hindering interpretability and trustworthiness. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture, which integrates visual, textual, and acoustic modalities for sentiment analysis. Our approach employs modality-specific attention mechanisms and a hierarchical fusion strategy to generate explainable representations. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI and ICT-MMM datasets demonstrate the efficacy of HAN in achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing transparent insights into the decision-making process.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for multimodal sentiment analysis, which integrates visual and textual features to better capture nuanced sentiment expressions. Our HAN model consists of two stages: a feature-level attention mechanism that selectively weighs modalities, and a sentence-level attention mechanism that focuses on salient regions. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both sentiment classification and aspect-based sentiment analysis tasks.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Resource Allocation in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: Efficient resource allocation is crucial in distributed systems, where dynamic changes in resource availability and demand require adaptable decision-making. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, 'DynaRA', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies for resource allocation in real-time. DynaRA integrates a graph neural network with a decentralized actor-critic architecture, allowing agents to capture complex system dynamics and make coordinated decisions. Experimental results on a simulated cloud computing environment demonstrate that DynaRA outperforms traditional optimization methods in terms of resource utilization and system responsiveness.

title: Hierarchical Few-Shot Learning with Meta-Learned Prototypes for Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning (FSL) has made significant progress in recent years, but most existing methods rely on a fixed metric space or are limited to a single level of abstraction. We propose a hierarchical FSL approach that meta-learns prototypes across multiple levels of abstraction, enabling more flexible and accurate image classification. Our method, Hierarchical Meta-Prototypes (HMP), leverages a nested episodic training framework to adapt to new tasks and classes. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets demonstrate that HMP outperforms state-of-the-art FSL methods, especially in the low-data regime.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to a growing need for efficient task allocation mechanisms. This paper presents 'MARL-TA', a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that enables dynamic task allocation in large-scale IoT networks. Our approach leverages a decentralized, asynchronous learning paradigm that allows agents to adapt to changing network conditions and task requirements. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that MARL-TA achieves significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced latency compared to traditional, centralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Graphs Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial step in scalable processing of large RDF graphs. Existing approaches often rely on heuristics or manual tuning, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning-based query optimizer, 'RLQO', for distributed RDF graphs. RLQO learns to predict the optimal query plan by interacting with the database environment and receiving rewards based on execution time and resource utilization. We evaluate RLQO on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.
