title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but the lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to provide insights into the decision-making process. Our approach enables the identification of relevant state features and action patterns, improving the transparency of RL policies. Experimental results on Atari games and robotic control tasks demonstrate that HAN-based agents outperform state-of-the-art RL methods while providing meaningful explanations for their actions.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multidimensional Arrays in Cloud-Based Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of cloud-based data warehouses has led to a surge in the storage and analysis of large multidimensional arrays. Query optimization for such arrays is crucial to ensure efficient processing and reduced latency. This paper presents a novel cost-based query optimization framework, 'ArrayOpt', that leverages statistical models and machine learning techniques to predict query execution costs. We introduce a novel array representation scheme that enables efficient pruning of irrelevant data and reduces the search space for query optimization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ArrayOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in query execution time.

title: Designing Intelligent Virtual Assistants for People with Disabilities: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants have the potential to improve the daily lives of people with disabilities, but current systems often fail to meet their unique needs. This paper presents a participatory design approach to developing intelligent virtual assistants that are accessible and usable by people with disabilities. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with individuals with disabilities, caregivers, and accessibility experts to identify key requirements and design principles. Our proposed framework, 'AccessibleVA', incorporates multimodal input, adaptive interfaces, and personalized assistance to support users with diverse abilities. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing virtual assistants.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents the design and evaluation of a conversational interface tailored to older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a participatory design process involving 15 older adults and 5 caregivers to identify key challenges and opportunities in current conversational systems. Our proposed interface, 'EasyChat', incorporates simplified language processing, visual cues, and personalized adaptivity to facilitate more effective and engaging interactions. A usability study with 20 older adults demonstrated significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing conversational interfaces.

title: Multi-Agent Coordination for Autonomous Vehicle Platooning using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicle platooning has the potential to significantly improve traffic flow and reduce fuel consumption. However, coordinating the actions of multiple vehicles in a platoon remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning framework for autonomous vehicle platooning. We model the platooning task as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process and develop a novel algorithm that integrates deep Q-networks with graph attention mechanisms. Our approach enables efficient and scalable coordination of autonomous vehicles in a platoon, outperforming existing methods in simulations and experiments.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Storage
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems with heterogeneous storage configurations pose significant challenges for query optimization. This paper presents 'OptiStore', a novel framework that leverages machine learning and graph-based modeling to optimize query plans for distributed databases with varying storage types. OptiStore integrates a cost-based optimizer with a storage-aware query planner, enabling efficient query execution across different storage hierarchies. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world distributed database system shows that OptiStore outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, reducing query latency by up to 40% and improving overall system throughput.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed column-store databases have become increasingly popular for big data analytics, but optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'ColOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to predict query performance. ColOpt identifies the most efficient query execution plan by analyzing column-level statistics, data distribution, and query patterns. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColOpt reduces query latency by up to 3x compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques, while maintaining high accuracy and robustness.

title: Personalized Gesture Recognition using Deep Learning on Multimodal Sensor Data
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to personalized gesture recognition using deep learning models on multimodal sensor data. Our system, ' GestureFusion', integrates data from computer vision, inertial measurement units, and electromyography sensors to recognize user-specific gestures. We propose a transfer learning framework that adapts to individual users' gesture patterns, achieving an average recognition accuracy of 95.2% on a dataset of 20 users. Experimental results show that GestureFusion outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and robustness to sensor noise and user variability.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Task Allocation in Cyber-Physical Systems
paper_abstract: Cyber-physical systems (CPS) require efficient task allocation to ensure timely and reliable execution of complex tasks. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for distributed task allocation in CPS. Our approach leverages decentralized Q-learning to enable agents to learn optimal task assignment policies in a partially observable environment. We introduce a novel reward function that incorporates both local and global performance metrics, enabling agents to balance individual and system-level objectives. Experimental results on a simulated CPS testbed demonstrate improved task allocation efficiency and reduced system latency compared to traditional centralized optimization methods.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Inclusive Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but existing gesture recognition systems often fail to accommodate users with diverse abilities. This paper presents a novel adaptive framework, ' GestureFit', which dynamically adjusts gesture recognition models based on individual user behavior and preferences. Our approach leverages a combination of machine learning and HCI principles to improve recognition accuracy and reduce fatigue for users with disabilities. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in usability and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture recognition systems.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the complexity of agent interactions and the need for efficient decision-making. This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model agent relationships and allocate tasks. Our approach, called 'GraphAgent', uses a hierarchical GNN architecture to learn a representation of the agent graph and predict task assignments. We evaluate GraphAgent on a variety of scenarios, including robotic search and rescue, and demonstrate its effectiveness in achieving near-optimal task allocations while reducing communication overhead.

title: Designing Inclusive Gestural Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gestural interfaces have become increasingly prevalent in modern computing, but individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers to using these systems. This paper presents a novel design framework for creating inclusive gestural interfaces that accommodate diverse motor abilities. We conducted a participatory design study with 15 participants with motor impairments, resulting in a set of design principles and guidelines for developing accessible gestural interactions. We also developed and evaluated a prototype system that incorporates these principles, demonstrating improved usability and accessibility for participants with motor impairments.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: As multi-agent systems become increasingly pervasive, there is a growing need for transparent and interpretable decision-making mechanisms. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework that enables explainable decision-making in multi-agent settings. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions, while also providing insights into the decision-making process. We evaluate our HAN framework on a range of multi-agent scenarios, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for multi-modal emotion recognition, leveraging facial expressions, speech, and text inputs. Our HAN model incorporates a hierarchical fusion mechanism that attends to relevant modalities at different levels, capturing both local and global context. Experiments on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance in recognizing emotions, outperforming existing multi-modal fusion methods. We also show that our model is computationally efficient, making it suitable for real-world applications.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to adapt to dynamic environments. Our approach, called 'RL-TA', utilizes a decentralized Q-learning algorithm to enable agents to learn optimal task assignments based on local observations and rewards. We evaluate RL-TA in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional, centralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging problem in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion (QE) is a widely used technique to improve retrieval effectiveness. However, existing QE methods rely on handcrafted features and heuristics, which may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'DRL-QE', which learns to expand queries by maximizing a reward function that incorporates retrieval metrics. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DRL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph-based Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data
paper_abstract: As machine learning models are increasingly deployed in real-world applications, they become vulnerable to adversarial attacks that can manipulate the model's output. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks in time series data using graph-based anomaly detection. Our method, referred to as 'GAD-TS', constructs a graph from the time series data and leverages graph neural networks to identify anomalous patterns. We evaluate GAD-TS on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting adversarial attacks with high accuracy and low false positive rates. Our approach outperforms existing methods, especially in scenarios where the attack is subtle and stealthy.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often struggle with scalability and complexity. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that addresses these limitations by learning hierarchical representations of graph-structured data. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges, enabling efficient few-shot learning on large-scale graphs. We demonstrate the efficacy of HGAT on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance with reduced computational overhead.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms have gained popularity for their scalability and ease of use. However, query optimization in multi-tenant DBaaS environments remains a challenge due to the complexity of resource sharing and dynamic workload patterns. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'OptiShare', which leverages machine learning-based workload prediction and dynamic resource allocation to minimize query latency and improve overall system throughput. Our experiments on a real-world DBaaS platform demonstrate that OptiShare reduces average query latency by up to 30% compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications, but optimizing query performance remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to predict query execution times and optimize query plans. We present a framework that learns from historical query data and adapts to changing workloads, achieving significant improvements in query response times and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing query latency and improving system throughput.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution in distributed relational databases is a challenging problem due to the complex interactions between query plans, data distributions, and system configurations. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively optimize query execution plans in response to changing workload and system conditions. Our framework, 'RL-Optimizer', uses a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy for query optimization, outperforming state-of-the-art heuristics and rule-based approaches in extensive experiments on a real-world dataset.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query execution plans in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans in distributed database systems. We design a deep Q-network that learns to select optimal join orders and indexing strategies based on the query workload and system configuration. Our experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) remains a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of each modality to recognize emotions at multiple levels. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific encoders, a cross-modal attention module, and a hierarchical fusion mechanism. Experimental results on the benchmark EMOTIC dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, with a relative improvement of 12.5% in F1-score.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: This study investigates the effects of haptic feedback on user experience in virtual reality (VR) interfaces. We designed an experiment where participants performed a series of tasks in a VR environment with and without haptic feedback. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly improves user performance, reduces errors, and enhances overall user satisfaction. We also found that the type and intensity of haptic feedback influence user behavior, with vibrations and resistance forces being more effective than tactile feedback. Our findings have implications for the design of VR interfaces, suggesting that haptic feedback can be a valuable tool for improving user experience and engagement.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 50 participants, analyzing their behavioral and physiological responses to customized avatars. Our results show that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, reduced anxiety, and improved overall satisfaction. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR systems and provide recommendations for future research.

title: EmoTract: Affective State Recognition from Multimodal Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Accurate affective state recognition is crucial for developing empathetic human-computer interfaces. This paper presents EmoTract, a novel multimodal framework that integrates computer vision, speech processing, and physiological signal analysis to recognize users' emotional states. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures complex relationships between modalities and contextual cues. Experimental results on a large-scale HCI dataset demonstrate EmoTract's superiority in recognizing subtle emotional shifts, outperforming state-of-the-art unimodal and multimodal approaches. We discuss implications for affective computing and HCI applications.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval, a fundamental task in information retrieval, involves retrieving relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion (QE) is a popular technique to improve retrieval performance. However, existing QE methods rely on manual feature engineering and often struggle to capture complex query-document relationships. This paper proposes a novel approach, DeepQE, which leverages deep neural networks to learn query-document interactions and generate effective expansion terms. We evaluate DeepQE on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional QE methods.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Virtual Objects in Mixed Reality
paper_abstract: As mixed reality (MR) technology advances, interacting with virtual objects in 3D space becomes increasingly important. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction technique, 'GazeShift', which enables users to seamlessly manipulate virtual objects using their gaze direction. We employ a combination of machine learning-based gaze estimation and computer vision techniques to track the user's gaze and infer their intended interaction. Our user study demonstrates that GazeShift outperforms existing interaction methods in terms of speed and accuracy, while also reducing user fatigue and improving overall MR experience.

title: Efficient Bayesian Neural Networks for Uncertainty Quantification in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Uncertainty quantification is crucial in computer vision applications, such as object detection and segmentation, where model uncertainty can impact decision-making. This paper presents a novel Bayesian neural network framework, 'BayesVision', that efficiently quantifies uncertainty through stochastic weight perturbations and probabilistic output layers. We propose a sparse Gaussian process prior to reduce the number of parameters and improve computational efficiency. Experimental results on popular benchmarks, including CIFAR-10 and Cityscapes, demonstrate that BayesVision achieves state-of-the-art performance in uncertainty estimation while maintaining competitive accuracy with deterministic models.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Disease Diagnosis with Electronic Health Records
paper_abstract: Electronic Health Records (EHRs) have become a crucial source of data for disease diagnosis. However, existing machine learning models often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to highlight relevant clinical features and EHR segments contributing to the predicted diagnosis. We evaluate our approach on a large EHR dataset, demonstrating improved diagnosis accuracy and providing insights into the model's decision-making process through visualized attention weights.

title: Enhancing Search Result Diversity using Adaptive Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Search engines often struggle to provide diverse search results, leading to user dissatisfaction. This paper proposes an adaptive query expansion framework, 'AQEPlus', which integrates both semantic and statistical features to generate novel queries that better capture user intent. AQEPlus leverages a hybrid approach, combining word embeddings with statistical language models to identify relevant expansion terms. Our experimental evaluation on a large-scale web corpus demonstrates that AQEPlus significantly improves search result diversity, reaching an average of 35% more diverse results compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance the quality of life for individuals with motor impairments. However, existing systems often rely on standardized gesture sets and machine learning models that are not adaptable to individual differences. This paper presents a novel framework for designing adaptive gesture recognition systems that can learn from user interactions and adapt to changing abilities. We propose a crowdsourced approach to collecting gesture data from individuals with motor impairments and develop a personalized machine learning model that can recognize gestures with high accuracy. Our evaluation with 20 participants shows that our system outperforms traditional gesture recognition systems by 25% in terms of recognition accuracy.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to enable individual agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and learn from their experiences. Our approach, dubbed 'DRL-TA', uses a novel graph attention mechanism to model agent-agent interactions and task dependencies, allowing agents to make informed decisions about task assignment. Experimental results on a realistic logistics scenario demonstrate that DRL-TA outperforms traditional optimization-based approaches in terms of task completion efficiency and robustness to agent failures.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction and Cognitive Load
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, focusing on the relationship between gesture-based interaction and cognitive load. We designed an experiment where participants performed a series of tasks in a VR simulation, using either gesture-based or controller-based input methods. Our results show that gesture-based interaction reduces cognitive load and improves task performance, particularly in tasks requiring spatial reasoning and problem-solving. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of VR systems and interfaces that leverage embodied cognition principles.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Robot Arm Control in Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: Robot arm control in uncertain environments is a challenging problem in robotics. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'HierRL', which decomposes the task into high-level goal-directed planning and low-level motion control. We introduce a novel option-learning mechanism that enables the agent to adapt to changing environmental conditions by selecting appropriate sub-policies. Experimental results on a real-world robot arm platform demonstrate that HierRL outperforms state-of-the-art model-free RL methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to uncertainty.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face significant challenges in optimizing resource allocation to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'CloudOpt', which leverages a two-level policy architecture to efficiently allocate resources. The high-level policy adjusts the resource pool, while the low-level policy allocates resources to individual virtual machines. We demonstrate that CloudOpt outperforms state-of-the-art methods in reducing response times and improving resource utilization on a real-world cloud workload dataset.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Graph-Based Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) methods often rely on hand-crafted features and simplistic ranking models. This paper proposes a novel graph-based neural network (GNN) approach for document ranking, which leverages the structural relationships between query terms and document entities. Our model, GraphRank, learns to represent documents as graphs and utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture both local and global context. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphRank outperforms state-of-the-art IR methods in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Dialogue
paper_abstract: Recognizing emotions in conversational dialogue is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the multimodal nature of human communication. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates visual, acoustic, and linguistic features to recognize emotions in conversational dialogue. Our HAN model uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant features and context, outperforming state-of-the-art models in emotion recognition tasks. We evaluate our model on the IEMOCAP dataset and achieve significant improvements in F1-score and accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Dialogue Systems for Task-Oriented Conversations
paper_abstract: Task-oriented dialogue systems have become increasingly prevalent in various applications, but their lack of transparency and explainability hinders user trust and understanding. This paper introduces HAtED, a hierarchical attention-based framework that generates explanations for its responses in task-oriented conversations. HAtED employs a novel hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant context and intent features, enabling the generation of informative and concise explanations. We evaluate HAtED on two benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in explanation quality, response accuracy, and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible and usable conversational interfaces that cater to the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive conversational interfaces, focusing on the specific challenges and requirements of older adults. We conducted a series of user studies and co-design workshops with older adults to identify key design principles and guidelines for creating accessible and engaging conversational interfaces. Our findings highlight the importance of simplicity, clarity, and flexibility in interface design, and provide recommendations for incorporating these principles into conversational AI systems.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding via Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) is a crucial task in AI, but existing methods often struggle with large-scale graphs and complex relationships. This paper introduces HierGAT, a novel hierarchical graph attention network for efficient KGE. HierGAT leverages a hierarchical representation of the graph, combining local and global attention mechanisms to capture both entity and relation semantics. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierGAT outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in terms of link prediction and graph reconstruction, while requiring significantly fewer parameters and computational resources.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly popular for large-scale data processing, but optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper presents 'RL-QOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning to adapt to changing workloads and database configurations. Our approach uses a deep Q-network to learn a policy for selecting optimal query plans, considering factors such as data distribution, network latency, and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that RL-QOpt outperforms traditional cost-based optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and resource efficiency.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Enhancing Search Result Diversity
paper_abstract: Conventional query expansion techniques often prioritize relevance over diversity, leading to redundant search results. This paper proposes a context-aware query expansion framework, 'CAQE', which incorporates user context and search intent to generate diverse and relevant search results. CAQE leverages a hybrid approach combining word embeddings and knowledge graphs to capture semantic relationships between query terms and expand the query scope. Experimental results on a large-scale search engine dataset demonstrate that CAQE significantly improves search result diversity and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require real-time control systems that can adapt to complex, dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'AVRL', which leverages a hybrid Actor-Critic architecture to optimize vehicle control policies. We introduce a new reward function that balances safety, efficiency, and comfort, and demonstrate improved performance compared to traditional model-based control methods. AVRL is evaluated on a realistic simulation platform, showcasing its potential for real-world deployment.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have different capabilities and resources. We leverage reinforcement learning to learn a policy that allocates tasks to agents based on their capabilities, workload, and communication constraints. The proposed approach, called 'DecentraAL', uses a novel reward function that encourages agents to share tasks and coordinate their actions to achieve global optimality. Experimental results on a simulated urban search and rescue scenario demonstrate that DecentraAL outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion time and agent utilization.

title: Exploring Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, focusing on gesture-based interaction. We designed a VR system that tracks users' hand movements and maps them to virtual objects, creating an immersive experience. Our user study reveals that gesture-based interaction enhances spatial awareness, memory recall, and cognitive load reduction compared to traditional controller-based input. We also find that users' gestures exhibit distinctive patterns that can be used to predict their cognitive states. Our findings have implications for the design of more intuitive and effective VR interfaces that leverage embodied cognition principles.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has shown immense potential in various domains, but user engagement remains a significant concern. This paper explores the effect of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in VR. We designed an experimental study where participants interacted with a VR environment using either a generic or personalized avatar. Our results indicate that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, measured through metrics such as interaction time, emotional arousal, and self-reported presence. We also identify key factors contributing to this effect, including avatar similarity, customization options, and social presence cues. The findings have implications for the design of VR systems and applications, particularly in fields like education, therapy, and entertainment.

title: Coordinating Task-Oriented Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, task-oriented agents must adapt to changing resource availability and task priorities. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-Coor', that enables agents to coordinate their actions and optimize resource allocation. Our approach combines a high-level task scheduler with low-level resource allocators, each trained using a variant of Q-learning. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HRL-Coor in a simulated smart factory scenario, showing improved task completion rates and reduced resource waste compared to decentralized or static allocation strategies.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to decentralized task allocation for autonomous agents using graph neural networks (GNNs). We model the agent network as a graph and learn a task allocation policy using a GNN-based architecture. Our approach enables agents to adapt to changing task requirements and network topologies without relying on a centralized controller. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm show that our method outperforms traditional decentralized allocation strategies in terms of task completion efficiency and robustness to agent failures.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Graph-based neural networks have shown promise in information retrieval tasks, but their computational complexity hinders their application to large-scale document collections. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) architecture that leverages document hierarchies to reduce computational costs. Our approach represents documents as hierarchical graphs, where each node corresponds to a document segment, and employs a message-passing scheme to propagate semantic information. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that our HGNN-based retrieval model outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models while achieving significant speedups.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Gesture-Based Interaction Framework for Enhancing User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way we interact with digital information, but traditional input devices limit the immersive experience. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interaction framework, 'Embodio', which leverages embodied cognition principles to enhance user experience in VR. By incorporating machine learning-driven gesture recognition and adaptive feedback, Embodio enables users to naturally interact with virtual objects using body gestures, leading to improved engagement, retention, and overall usability. A user study demonstrates significant benefits of Embodio over conventional input methods, highlighting its potential for VR-based applications in education, entertainment, and beyond.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its adoption is hindered by a lack of accessibility features for users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR interfaces that cater to users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with users from diverse disability groups, resulting in a set of guidelines and recommendations for VR interface designers. Our evaluation study demonstrates that interfaces designed using our framework significantly improve user experience and accessibility for users with disabilities.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Massive RDF Graphs using Parallelized Heuristics
paper_abstract: With the growing adoption of RDF as a standard for data representation, querying large RDF graphs has become a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ParaHeur', that leverages parallel processing and machine learning-based heuristics to reduce query execution times. We introduce a cost-based optimization strategy that adaptively selects the most effective join order and indexing scheme for a given query. Experimental results on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that ParaHeur achieves speedups of up to 5x compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers, while maintaining high accuracy and robustness.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Cognitive Load for Older Adults
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the potential of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) to alleviate cognitive load in older adults during human-computer interactions. We designed an ECA-based interface that incorporates gestures, facial expressions, and speech to facilitate multimodal communication. In a user study with 30 older adults, we compared the ECA-based interface with a traditional graphical user interface (GUI) in a task-oriented scenario. Results show that participants using the ECA-based interface exhibited significantly reduced cognitive load, as measured by pupil dilation and self-reported workload, while maintaining comparable task performance. Our findings suggest that ECAs can be a valuable design approach for promoting accessible and inclusive HCI for older adults.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in VR environments. We designed and implemented a novel avatar creation system that incorporates user preferences, personality traits, and physical characteristics. Our user study involving 120 participants shows that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, presence, and overall satisfaction in VR applications. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR systems and applications.

title: deceivedRank: A Novel Adversarial Ranking Approach for Search Engine Result Pages
paper_abstract: Search engine result pages (SERPs) are vulnerable to manipulation by malicious actors, leading to biased and misleading search results. This paper proposes deceivedRank, a novel adversarial ranking approach that detects and mitigates manipulation attacks on SERPs. We develop a game-theoretic framework that models the interactions between the search engine and adversarial entities, and design a ranking algorithm that incorporates uncertainty quantification and robustness metrics. Experimental evaluations on a large-scale search engine dataset demonstrate that deceivedRank improves the robustness of search results by up to 35% compared to state-of-the-art ranking algorithms.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a crucial task in human-computer interaction. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages the strengths of each modality to identify emotions more accurately. Our approach incorporates modality-specific attention mechanisms and a hierarchical fusion strategy to capture both local and global contextual information. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on two benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing interpretable insights into the emotional cues used by the model.

title: Designing Emotional Feedback Loops for Adaptive User Interfaces in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often struggle to provide users with intuitive and emotionally engaging experiences. This paper presents an innovative framework for designing emotional feedback loops in VR, which adapt to users' physiological and behavioral responses in real-time. Our approach integrates machine learning-based affect recognition with cognitive models of emotional regulation, enabling VR systems to modulate user emotions through dynamic interface adaptations. We report results from a user study demonstrating improved emotional resonance and user satisfaction in VR experiences designed with our framework.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component in distributed database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and resource utilization. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to optimize query plans. Our methodology, called 'GNN-QO', represents the database schema and query workload as a graph, and uses a GNN to predict the optimal query plan. We evaluate GNN-QO on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and resource utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of graph data and the need to balance performance and resource utilization. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to select optimal query plans based on graph topology, data distribution, and system workload. Experimental results on a real-world social network dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multimodal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multimodal fusion is a crucial component in Visual Question Answering (VQA) tasks, as it combines language and vision features to generate accurate answers. However, existing fusion methods often suffer from high computational complexity and neglect the hierarchical relationships between modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) for efficient multimodal fusion in VQA. HAN leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant regions in images and words in questions, reducing the dimensionality of the fused representation while preserving crucial information. Experimental results on the VQA 2.0 dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art fusion methods in terms of accuracy and inference speed.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize agent performance. Our approach, called 'AgentDRL', uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture to enable agents to learn task allocation policies from local observations and interactions. We evaluate AgentDRL on a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: As autonomous agents increasingly interact with humans, there is a growing need for transparent and interpretable decision-making processes. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for multi-agent systems, which learns to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions to make explainable decisions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in a simulated traffic management scenario, where it outperforms existing methods in terms of decision accuracy and interpretability. Our approach has significant implications for the development of trustworthy and human-centric AI systems.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework, 'DCTA', that leverages distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to allocate tasks to autonomous agents. DCTA utilizes a novel communication protocol that enables agents to iteratively exchange constraint information and converge to a feasible task allocation. We evaluate DCTA on a simulated robotics scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to centralized approaches.

title: Efficientsky: A Scalable Skyline Query Algorithm for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Skyline queries are essential in multi-criteria decision-making applications, but their computation can be computationally expensive and challenging to scale in distributed database systems. This paper presents Efficientsky, a novel algorithm that leverages data partitioning and parallel processing to accelerate skyline query evaluation. We introduce a dynamic pruning technique that reduces the number of candidate points and a load-balancing strategy to minimize communication overhead. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that Efficientsky outperforms state-of-the-art approaches by up to 5x in terms of query response time and scales to large datasets with millions of records.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Decision-making
paper_abstract: Explainability is a critical aspect of AI-driven decision-making systems, as they become increasingly pervasive in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that integrates graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to facilitate transparent decision-making. HGAT captures complex relationships between entities and highlights the most influential features contributing to the model's predictions. We evaluate HGAT on a real-world healthcare dataset and demonstrate its ability to provide accurate and interpretable predictions, outperforming state-of-the-art explainable AI baselines.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Zero-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) has gained popularity in recent years, but most existing methods rely on expensive annotation and suffer from poor scalability. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) for efficient ZSL, which leverages semantic relationships between classes to transfer knowledge from seen to unseen categories. Our HAN model consists of a class-attention module that adaptively weights class embeddings and a feature-attention module that selectively focuses on relevant input features. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of classification accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Survey and Novel Defense Mechanism
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable success in various applications, but they are vulnerable to adversarial attacks. This survey provides a comprehensive overview of existing attack methods on GNNs, including node injection, edge perturbation, and feature manipulation. We also propose a novel defense mechanism, 'GraphShield', which leverages graph autoencoders and adversarial training to improve the robustness of GNNs. Experimental results demonstrate that GraphShield achieves state-of-the-art performance in defending against various types of attacks on benchmark datasets.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Real-World Robotics
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various robotics tasks, but its lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in real-world applications. This paper presents a novel explainability framework, 'RL-Explain', which leverages attention mechanisms and saliency maps to provide insights into DRL decision-making processes. We demonstrate RL-Explain's effectiveness in a robotic grasping task, showcasing improved transparency and trustworthiness of the DRL policy. Our results indicate that RL-Explain can facilitate the development of more reliable and efficient DRL-based robotic systems.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning with Incomplete Information using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized multi-agent planning problems with incomplete information are challenging due to the exponential growth of the joint action space. This paper proposes a novel approach that integrates deep reinforcement learning with decentralized planning to tackle this problem. We introduce a hierarchical framework consisting of a high-level planning module and a low-level execution module, where agents learn to communicate and coordinate their actions using a deep Q-network. Experimental results on a decentralized resource allocation problem demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of solution quality and scalability.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we tackle the problem of decentralized task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems. We propose a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, which enables agents to learn optimal task allocation strategies in a distributed manner. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model the complex interactions between agents and tasks, and uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn policy and value functions. Experimental results on a series of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate, latency, and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed search systems struggle to balance query latency and result relevance. This paper presents a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that leverages local indexing and global aggregation to efficiently retrieve documents. HQE employs a probabilistic topic modeling scheme to identify latent concepts in the query and expand it with relevant terms, reducing the search space while preserving result accuracy. Experimental evaluation on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrates a 30% reduction in query latency and a 15% improvement in mean average precision compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture Recognition Systems for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have shown great potential in enhancing human-computer interaction. However, existing systems often neglect the needs of users with motor impairments, leading to reduced accuracy and accessibility. This paper presents a novel framework for designing gesture recognition systems that cater to users with motor impairments. We propose a machine learning approach that leverages a large gesture dataset collected from users with varying levels of motor impairment. Our system incorporates a personalized gesture adaptation module that adjusts to individual users' abilities, resulting in improved recognition accuracy and reduced error rates. We evaluated our system with 30 participants and observed significant improvements in usability and user satisfaction.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks Against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Uncertainty
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be detrimental to their deployment in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to robustify deep neural networks against adversarial attacks by leveraging Bayesian uncertainty. We develop a Bayesian neural network framework that incorporates uncertainty estimates into the model's predictions, allowing for the detection of adversarial samples. Our approach is shown to be effective in improving the robustness of deep neural networks against various types of adversarial attacks, including FGSM and PGD. Experimental results demonstrate the efficacy of our approach on several benchmark datasets.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Contextualized Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but often struggle to effectively incorporate external knowledge for query expansion. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'CtxQE', which leverages contextualized embeddings to generate informative expansion terms. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures both local and global contextual relationships between query terms and documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CtxQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Sparse Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multi-modal emotion recognition tasks often require processing large amounts of data from various sources, such as audio, video, and text. This paper presents a novel approach to reducing the computational overhead of such tasks by introducing sparse attention networks. Our proposed architecture, 'SparseEmoNet', learns to selectively focus on the most relevant modalities and features, thereby reducing the number of parameters and computations required. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and CMU-MOSEI datasets demonstrate that SparseEmoNet achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing inference time by up to 40% compared to existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has become a popular paradigm for open-domain question answering, but its effectiveness is highly dependent on the quality of the query representation. This paper proposes a hierarchical query expansion (HQE) framework that leverages both semantic and syntactic relationships between query terms to generate a more comprehensive and informative query representation. Our approach is designed to work in tandem with DPR models, and we demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency on several benchmark datasets. Furthermore, we analyze the impact of HQE on the robustness of DPR models to query variations and document length.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that affects overall system performance. This paper presents a novel decentralized autonomous task allocation framework (DATAs) that efficiently allocates tasks to heterogeneous agents with varying capabilities. DATAs leverages a distributed constraint optimization approach, enabling agents to negotiate and resolve conflicts locally. We evaluate DATAs in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing centralized methods.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-based Embeddings and Distributed Query Optimization
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a fundamental challenge in large-scale knowledge graphs, where ambiguous entities can lead to inaccurate query results. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GraphEmbDQ', which integrates graph-based entity embeddings with distributed query optimization to achieve scalable entity disambiguation. We design a hierarchical graph neural network to learn entity representations, and a distributed query optimization framework to efficiently prune the search space. Experimental results on the YAGO knowledge graph demonstrate that GraphEmbDQ outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and scalability, while reducing query execution time by up to 3x.

title: Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles using Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely heavily on accurate object detection systems to navigate complex environments. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for real-time object detection in autonomous vehicles. Our approach leverages a multi-scale feature fusion mechanism and a hierarchical attention module to selectively focus on relevant regions of interest. We evaluate our HAN model on the KITTI dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in detection accuracy and speed compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our proposed approach has the potential to enhance the safety and reliability of autonomous vehicles in dynamic environments.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Task-Aware Weight Adaptation
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, as it requires models to adapt quickly to new tasks with limited training data. This paper proposes a hierarchical meta-learning framework, 'TaskAdapt', which learns to adapt model weights to new tasks by incorporating task-aware information. We introduce a novel weight adaptation mechanism that leverages task embeddings to adjust the learning rate and momentum of the optimizer. Experiments on various benchmark datasets demonstrate that TaskAdapt outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods, achieving higher accuracy and faster adaptation to new tasks.

title: Hierarchical Attention for Explainable Multimodal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multimodal dialogue systems have shown promising results in human-computer interaction, but their lack of transparency and interpretability hinders user trust. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HAT', which enables explainable multimodal dialogue understanding. HAT incorporates visual and linguistic attention mechanisms to generate contextualized embeddings, which are then used to predict dialogue responses. Experimental results on the Multimodal Dialogue Dataset demonstrate that HAT outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of response accuracy and dialogue coherence, while providing visualized attention maps for enhanced interpretability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuroQE', which leverages neural embeddings to model term semantics. By incorporating a pre-trained language model into the query expansion process, NeuroQE can effectively capture latent relationships between terms and improve retrieval performance. Our experiments on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and recall compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Task Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning (MTL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but interpretability remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework, which seamlessly integrates task-specific attention mechanisms and hierarchical representations to facilitate explainable MTL. Our approach enables the model to selectively focus on relevant features and tasks, providing insightful visualizations and quantifiable performance improvements. We conduct extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating the efficacy of HAN in achieving state-of-the-art results while offering interpretable insights into the learned representations.

title: Efficient Document Representation Learning with Hierarchical Attention for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document representation methods in information retrieval (IR) often struggle to capture complex semantic relationships between entities and contexts. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HAT-IR', which learns to represent documents as a hierarchy of attention weights. Our approach leverages a multi-layer transformer encoder to model intra-sentence and inter-sentence relationships, enabling more accurate relevance scoring. Experimental results on several benchmark IR datasets demonstrate that HAT-IR outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Cardinality Estimation
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of cardinality estimation. This paper proposes an adaptive cardinality estimation technique, ACE, which leverages machine learning and statistical models to accurately estimate the cardinality of intermediate results. ACE dynamically adjusts to changes in data distribution and query patterns, outperforming traditional methods in terms of query execution time and resource utilization. Our experiments on a real-world DDS platform demonstrate the efficacy of ACE in improving query performance and scalability.

title: Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Caching and Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly used to manage large-scale data applications. However, query processing in DDS faces significant challenges due to data distribution, network latency, and node failures. This paper proposes an adaptive caching and replication scheme, called 'DynaCache', to optimize query performance in DDS. DynaCache dynamically adjusts cache sizes and replication factors based on query patterns, data access frequencies, and system workload. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that DynaCache achieves up to 35% reduction in query latency and 25% improvement in throughput compared to existing caching and replication strategies.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Neural Architecture Search via Graph-based Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising approach to automate the design of deep neural networks. However, the computational cost of evaluating candidate architectures hinders the adoption of NAS in resource-constrained settings. This paper presents a novel graph-based Bayesian optimization (BO) framework for efficient hyperparameter tuning in NAS. By encoding the neural architecture as a graph and leveraging graph kernels, our approach reduces the dimensionality of the search space and enables faster convergence to optimal hyperparameters. Experimental results on popular NAS benchmarks demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing the computation time by up to 3x compared to existing BO methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering over knowledge graphs (KGs) has gained significant attention in recent years. However, existing methods struggle to effectively model complex, multi-hop dependencies between entities and relations. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based framework, HAKE, which learns to recursively focus on relevant KG substructures when answering multi-hop questions. Our approach leverages a compositional representation of KG entities and relations, enabling the model to capture nuanced semantic relationships. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of HAKE in improving question answering accuracy, particularly for complex, multi-hop queries.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art information retrieval models rely heavily on manually crafted features and complex ranking architectures. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Document Ranking (HGNN-DR), which leverages the graph structure of documents to learn hierarchical representations. HGNN-DR adapts graph attention mechanisms to capture local and global document relationships, achieving improved ranking performance and reduced computational complexity. Experimental results on the TREC news dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HGNN-DR in retrieving relevant documents, outperforming existing neural ranking models.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, leveraging graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective assignment strategies. Our approach, called GNN-TA, represents the agent-task graph as a heterogeneous network and learns to optimize task assignments based on agent capabilities, task requirements, and system constraints. We demonstrate the efficacy of GNN-TA through extensive simulations, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, but it remains challenging due to the complexity and scale of real-world graphs. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and subgraphs. HGAT hierarchically aggregates node features and attention weights, enabling efficient classification of nodes in large graphs. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art graph neural networks in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: A Deep Ranking Model for Effcient Document Retrieval in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Heterogeneous information networks (HINs) have become a crucial component of modern information retrieval systems. However, existing ranking models struggle to capture the complex relationships between different types of nodes and edges in HINs. In this paper, we propose a deep ranking model, HINRank, which leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to learn node representations that capture both structural and semantic relationships in HINs. Our experiments on a large-scale dataset of scholarly articles demonstrate that HINRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in time series forecasting, as it enables model interpretability and trustworthiness. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel architecture that integrates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to capture complex patterns in time series data. HANs leverage hierarchical representations to identify relevant features and contextual relationships, producing more accurate and interpretable forecasts. We evaluate HANs on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating improved performance and explainability compared to state-of-the-art models. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications, such as demand forecasting and anomaly detection.

title: Self-Supervised Representation Learning for Time-Series Anomaly Detection via Contrastive Predictive Coding
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is a crucial task in various domains. Existing methods often rely on labeled datasets, which are scarce and expensive to obtain. This paper introduces a self-supervised approach based on contrastive predictive coding (CPC) to learn representations for time-series anomaly detection. Our method, dubbed 'TS-CPC', leverages the temporal dependencies in the data to learn a predictive model that distinguishes between normal and anomalous patterns. We demonstrate the effectiveness of TS-CPC on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while requiring no labeled data.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Scalable Time-Series Data Management
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and sensors has led to an explosion of time-series data, posing significant challenges for efficient data management. Existing indexing techniques struggle to balance query performance and storage overhead. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'TS-Tree', which leverages a hierarchical, adaptive partitioning scheme and a compact, bit-packed representation. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that TS-Tree outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query latency and 2x in storage efficiency, while maintaining strong scalability and fault tolerance.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion using Graph-Based Keyword Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively capture the semantic relationships between query terms, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach that leverages graph-based keyword embeddings to model complex query semantics. Our method, termed 'GraphQEx', represents query terms as nodes in a graph, where edges are weighted by semantic similarity measures derived from a large-scale text corpus. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphQEx significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% relative improvement in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multimodal dialogue systems have gained popularity in various applications, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and adoption. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates visual, acoustic, and linguistic features to generate interpretable responses. Our approach leverages attention weights to highlight relevant input features, enabling the identification of key factors influencing the system's decisions. Experimental results on a benchmark multimodal dialogue dataset demonstrate improved response accuracy and human-perceived explainability compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts system performance and scalability. This paper presents a novel graph-based indexing approach, dubbed 'Distributed Graph Index' (DGI), which leverages the structural properties of query graphs to optimize query execution plans. DGI constructs a compact, distributed index that captures the interaction patterns between query nodes, enabling efficient exploration of the query space. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database demonstrate that DGI outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques, reducing query latency by up to 30% and improving system throughput by up to 25%.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles, efficient task allocation becomes critical for large-scale deployment. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, dubbed 'AVTAR', to allocate tasks among autonomous vehicles in real-time. AVTAR leverages a graph neural network to model vehicle interactions and a hierarchical deep Q-network to learn optimal task assignments. Our experiments on a simulated urban environment demonstrate that AVTAR outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion rate, latency, and adaptability to changing traffic conditions.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but current interfaces often exacerbate existing accessibility barriers. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating inclusive VR interfaces for this population. We conducted participatory design workshops with older adults and caregivers to identify interface requirements and developed a novel VR system, 'EasyVR', that incorporates cognitive support features, such as simplified navigation and error prevention. Our evaluation with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments showed significant improvements in usability and user experience compared to commercial VR systems.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to decentralized task allocation for heterogeneous multi-agent systems. We propose a graph neural network (GNN) architecture that learns to allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, workload, and communication constraints. Our approach is scalable, robust, and adaptive to changes in the agent population or task requirements. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional optimization-based methods.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Neural Density Estimation
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer user queries. Existing methods rely on lexical matching or dense retrieval, which suffer from high computational costs or suboptimal performance. We propose a novel hierarchical neural density estimation (HNDE) framework for passage retrieval, which models the distribution of relevant passages using a hierarchical latent variable model. Our method leverages both local and global contextual information to estimate the relevance of each passage, outperforming state-of-the-art methods on the SQuAD-Open and TriviaQA datasets. We demonstrate the efficiency of HNDE by achieving a 3x speedup over existing neural retrieval methods while maintaining superior performance.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases are increasingly common in modern data management systems, but efficient query processing remains a significant challenge.
