This paper addresses the problem of multi-dimensional range queries, which are critical in various applications such as spatial databases and data analytics. We propose a novel indexing technique, 'DRIE', which leverages the distributed nature of the database to reduce query latency and improve scalability. DRIE uses a hierarchical indexing structure that adaptively partitions the data space based on query patterns, resulting in significant performance gains compared to existing indexing methods. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of DRIE in reducing query response times and improving system throughput.

title: Neural Ranking Models for Diversified Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines struggle to balance relevance and diversity in their retrieval results. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'DiversiRank', which incorporates a diversified attention mechanism to promote novelty and variety in the top-ranked items. We train DiversiRank on a large-scale e-commerce dataset using a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes for relevance, diversity, and user satisfaction. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in both retrieval effectiveness and user experience metrics compared to state-of-the-art baseline models.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: While multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has achieved success in various domains, the lack of interpretability hinders its applicability in real-world scenarios. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables explainable MARL. Our HAN model learns to focus on relevant agents and their interactions, facilitating the identification of key decision-making factors. We evaluate our approach on a suite of MARL benchmarks and demonstrate improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing VR systems often neglect the unique needs and abilities of this population. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences tailored to older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a user-centered design study with 20 participants, identifying key challenges and opportunities for VR interaction. Our results inform the development of a set of design guidelines and recommendations for creating accessible and engaging VR experiences. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through a prototype VR system, which shows significant improvements in user engagement and cognitive load reduction.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments, but existing VR interfaces often pose accessibility barriers. This paper presents the results of a user-centered design study aimed at creating an accessible VR interface for this population. We developed a novel set of interaction techniques that accommodate cognitive and motor impairments, and evaluated their usability with a group of older adults with mild cognitive impairment. Our findings highlight the importance of simplifying menu systems, providing clear auditory feedback, and using intuitive gesture-based interactions. We also introduce a set of design guidelines for accessible VR interfaces that can be applied to a range of applications.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Trust in Human-Robot Collaboration
paper_abstract: As robots become increasingly integrated into human workspaces, understanding the factors that influence trust in human-robot collaboration is crucial. This study explores the role of embodiment in shaping trust in robotic collaborators. We conducted a series of experiments where participants performed tasks with either an embodied robot or a non-embodied virtual agent. Our results show that embodiment significantly enhances trust in robotic collaborators, particularly in tasks requiring physical proximity. We also identify key design factors, such as robot appearance and movement patterns, that moderate this effect. The findings have implications for the design of robots that can effectively collaborate with humans in various domains.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) has made significant progress with the advent of deep learning models. However, existing approaches often lack transparency and interpretability, making it challenging to understand the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that incorporates both spatial and semantic attention mechanisms to generate explanations for VQA tasks. Our HAN model attends to relevant regions of the image and identifies key objects, attributes, and relationships, providing a step-by-step explanation for the predicted answer. Experimental results on the VQA-CP v2 dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy and explainability.

title: Investigating the Effects of Embodiment on Social Presence in Virtual Reality Mediated Communication
paper_abstract: As Virtual Reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent in social interactions, understanding the impact of embodiment on social presence is crucial. This study explores how varying levels of embodiment in VR avatars influence users' feelings of social presence, trust, and cooperation in virtual mediated communication. We conducted a within-subjects experiment with 40 participants, using a 2x2 factorial design to manipulate avatar embodiment and task type. Results show that high-embodiment avatars significantly enhance social presence and trust, particularly in collaborative tasks. Our findings have implications for the design of VR-based communication platforms and future research on social interaction in virtual environments.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Visual Question Answering Models using Attention-based Input Preprocessing
paper_abstract: Visual Question Answering (VQA) models have achieved impressive performance, but their robustness to adversarial attacks remains a concern. This paper proposes a novel attention-based input preprocessing technique, 'AttentionShield', to improve the adversarial robustness of VQA models. We introduce a learnable attention module that adaptively weights input features based on their importance for answering the question, thereby reducing the impact of adversarial perturbations. Our experiments on the VQA-CP dataset demonstrate that AttentionShield improves the robustness of state-of-the-art VQA models by up to 15% against strong adversarial attacks, while maintaining their accuracy on clean data.

title: Designing Accessible Augmented Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but users with visual impairments are often excluded from these experiences. This paper presents an AR design framework, 'AccessibleAR', that incorporates audio and haptic feedback to enable users with visual impairments to interact with virtual objects in a seamless and intuitive manner. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that AccessibleAR significantly improved task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional screen reader-based approaches. Our framework provides a foundation for designing inclusive AR experiences that can benefit a broader range of users.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution plans in distributed database systems is a complex problem due to the large solution space and dynamic nature of the system. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network (DQN) that learns to select the optimal execution plan for a given query by interacting with the database system. The DQN is trained using a reward function that balances query execution time and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Adaptive Relation Attention
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial step in various AI applications, but existing methods struggle to capture complex relation patterns. This paper proposes a novel KGE approach, 'ARAE', which incorporates adaptive relation attention to selectively focus on relevant relation triples. We introduce a neural attention mechanism that learns to weigh relation importance based on entity embeddings and graph structure. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show that ARAE outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in link prediction and entity classification tasks, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need to develop intuitive and efficient interaction methods. This paper explores the use of gaze-based interaction in AR environments, focusing on user experience and performance. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, comparing gaze-based selection with traditional controller-based input. Our results show that gaze-based interaction significantly reduces task completion time and improves user satisfaction, particularly in tasks requiring precise object manipulation. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of AR interfaces and propose future research directions.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Few-shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art results in node classification tasks, but often require large amounts of labeled data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN (HAT-GNN) that tackles the few-shot node classification problem. Our model leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant graph structures and node features, enabling effective learning from limited labeled data. We evaluate HAT-GNN on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements over existing few-shot learning methods.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Intent Detection in Conversational AI
paper_abstract: Few-shot intent detection in conversational AI is a challenging problem due to the limited availability of labeled data. We propose a novel meta-learning approach, 'IntentMeta', which leverages model-agnostic meta-learning to adapt to new intent types with only a few examples. Our method uses a task-aware attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant context and intent information. Experimental results on popular conversational AI benchmarks demonstrate that IntentMeta outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 12.5% on unseen intent types.

title: EmoTact: A Multimodal Emotion Recognition Framework for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition plays a crucial role in creating empathetic human-computer interfaces. This paper introduces EmoTact, a novel multimodal framework that leverages facial expressions, speech cues, and physiological signals to recognize emotions in real-time. Our approach utilizes a deep learning architecture that fuses features from multiple modalities, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the benchmark EmoReact dataset. We also present a user study demonstrating the effectiveness of EmoTact in enhancing user experience in a virtual reality application.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-robot interaction (HRI) is crucial for creating empathetic and personalized robots. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multi-modal features from facial expressions, speech, and body language to recognize emotions in real-time. Our HAN architecture consists of three levels of attention: modality-level, feature-level, and decision-level attention. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale HRI dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in emotion recognition accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods. The proposed framework has potential applications in developing more empathetic robots for healthcare, education, and customer service.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Graph-based Pruning for Resource-Constrained Devices
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has revolutionized the design of deep neural networks, but its computational overhead hinders its adoption on resource-constrained devices. This paper presents a novel graph-based pruning approach, 'GraphPrune', which reduces the search space by eliminating redundant graph motifs. We introduce a differentiable graph neural network (GNN) to learn the importance of each motif and prune the architecture accordingly. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphPrune achieves state-of-the-art performance on mobile devices while reducing the search time by an order of magnitude.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Multimodal Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines rely heavily on textual queries, but users often have multimodal preferences (e.g., images, videos) that are not effectively captured by traditional keyword-based search. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion framework that incorporates visual and textual features to improve multimodal retrieval. Our approach utilizes a graph-based attention mechanism to weigh the importance of different modalities based on the user's query context. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset show that our method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of retrieval accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Scalable Hierarchical Clustering for Unbalanced Datasets using Deep Embeddings
paper_abstract: Hierarchical clustering is a fundamental task in data analysis, but existing methods struggle with unbalanced datasets. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepHClust', which leverages deep embeddings to learn a hierarchical representation of the data. Our method employs a multi-resolution strategy to adapt to varying density regions, and a novel loss function that encourages balanced clustering. Experiments on diverse real-world datasets demonstrate that DeepHClust outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality and scalability, particularly for datasets with extreme class imbalance.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has shown remarkable success in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'AdvRL', which incorporates carefully crafted perturbations into the training process to enhance the robustness of DRL policies. We introduce a dynamic perturbation schedule that adapts to the policy's sensitivity to attacks, thereby improving its resilience to varying adversarial strengths. Experimental results on popular DRL benchmarks demonstrate that AdvRL significantly improves the robustness of DRL policies while maintaining their performance on original tasks.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Semantic Search in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of heterogeneous information networks (HINs) has created new challenges for semantic search. Existing query expansion methods often suffer from high computational complexity and limited contextual understanding. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework, HQE-HIN, which leverages the hierarchical structure of HINs to efficiently expand queries. Our approach incorporates semantic role labeling and graph attention mechanisms to capture nuanced relationships between entities and concepts. Experimental results on a large-scale HIN dataset demonstrate that HQE-HIN achieves significant improvements in search accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between data entities. However, as graph sizes continue to grow, query optimization becomes a significant bottleneck. This paper presents 'GraphOpt', a novel query optimization framework designed specifically for distributed graph databases. GraphOpt leverages graph structural properties to prune the search space and exploits parallelism to speed up query execution. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world social network dataset demonstrates that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 5x in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering (QA) models often struggle to provide transparent and interpretable reasoning for their predictions, particularly when dealing with multi-hop questions. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph-based reasoning to explicitly model relationships between entities and clauses in the input text. HGAT adaptively attends to relevant context and clause-level information, generating explicit and hierarchical explanations for its predictions. Experimental results on the HotPotQA dataset demonstrate significant improvements in both QA accuracy and explanation quality, outperforming state-of-the-art models.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a popular technique to improve retrieval performance, but it often relies on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well across different query types. This paper proposes a neural query expansion framework, NEQE, which leverages pre-trained language models to learn dense embeddings for queries and documents. We introduce a novel attention-based mechanism to selectively expand queries with relevant terms, and demonstrate significant improvements over traditional query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
paper_abstract: Social media platforms generate vast amounts of multimodal data, including text, images, and videos. Sentiment analysis of this data is crucial for businesses and policymakers. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multimodal features to improve sentiment analysis. Our HAN model consists of three stages: intra-modal attention, inter-modal attention, and fusion. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale social media dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in sentiment analysis accuracy compared to state-of-the-art unimodal and multimodal baselines.

title: Dynamic Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel approach to dynamic task allocation using hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL). Our method, called Hierarchical Task Allocator (HTA), consists of a high-level planner that assigns tasks to agents and a low-level learner that adapts to changing environmental conditions. We evaluate HTA in a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced response times compared to traditional auction-based methods. Our approach enables scalable and flexible task allocation in complex, dynamic environments.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces have revolutionized the way humans interact with digital information. However, the lack of personalized experiences in VR can lead to user frustration and decreased engagement. This study explores the effect of personalization on user experience in VR interfaces. We designed and implemented a VR system that adapts to individual users' preferences, learning styles, and cognitive abilities. Our user study with 30 participants reveals that personalized VR interfaces significantly enhance user satisfaction, reduce cognitive load, and improve task performance. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR systems and highlight areas for further research.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Relevant Documents using Hierarchical Neural Networks for Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) systems rely on hand-crafted features and ranking models, which often fail to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural network (HNN) architecture for IR, which learns to represent documents and queries in a shared latent space. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant document segments, enabling more accurate retrieval of top-ranked documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our HNN-based IR system, outperforming state-of-the-art baseline models in terms of recall and mean average precision.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to allocate tasks efficiently without a central coordinator. This paper proposes a novel approach using reinforcement learning, where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their local observations and interactions with other agents. We introduce a decentralized Q-learning algorithm that enables agents to adapt to changing task demands and agent availability. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms traditional auction-based methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) faces unique challenges due to the complexity of medical terminology and the need for high precision. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'MedExp', that leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to improve retrieval effectiveness. MedExp combines a neural ranking model with a relevance feedback mechanism that adaptively selects expansion terms from a medical thesaurus. Experiments on the TREC Medical Retrieval benchmark demonstrate that MedExp outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Autonomous Agents Using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: Cooperative autonomous agents have numerous applications in areas such as robotics, smart cities, and disaster response. Effective task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals, but centralized approaches can be brittle and vulnerable to single-point failures. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, preferences, and resource constraints. We propose a novel DCOP algorithm that incorporates agent heterogeneity, temporal constraints, and uncertainty awareness. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and robustness compared to existing decentralized task allocation methods.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: Investigating Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has transformed the way we interact with digital information, but existing interaction modalities often fall short in terms of user experience. This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles to VR interaction, focusing on gesture-based interfaces. We design and evaluate a novel VR system that leverages hand and arm gestures to facilitate intuitive object manipulation and navigation. Our user study reveals significant improvements in user engagement, task performance, and overall satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. We discuss the implications of our findings for the development of more immersive and effective VR experiences.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient exploration strategies to learn complex behaviors in real-world environments. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent deep reinforcement learning framework, 'MADE', which enables coordinated exploration among agents. MADE leverages attention mechanisms to facilitate communication and cooperation among agents, improving the efficiency of exploration and reducing the likelihood of catastrophic failures. We evaluate MADE on a suite of autonomous driving scenarios, demonstrating improved learning speed and robustness compared to independent exploration strategies.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Voice-Assisted Reminders
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces, such as voice assistants, have the potential to support older adults in managing their daily lives. However, existing systems often neglect the unique needs and abilities of this population. This study investigates the design of accessible conversational interfaces for older adults, with a focus on voice-assisted reminders. We conducted a user-centered design process, involving 20 older adults, to develop and evaluate a novel conversational interface. Our results show that the proposed interface significantly improves the usability and accessibility of voice-assisted reminders, particularly for older adults with cognitive and sensory impairments. We discuss the implications of our findings for the development of inclusive conversational interfaces.

title: Context-Aware Document Ranking with Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional document ranking models rely on static query-document matching, neglecting the context in which the query is issued. This paper proposes a novel context-aware document ranking approach, 'CADR', which leverages hierarchical attention networks to capture complex relationships between query context, document content, and user preferences. Our model achieves state-of-the-art performance on the TREC Deep Learning Track, demonstrating significant improvements in ranking accuracy and diversity. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the learned attention patterns, shedding light on the importance of contextual factors in search tasks.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Older adults with cognitive impairments face significant barriers when interacting with voice-based interfaces, leading to feelings of frustration and isolation. This paper presents the results of a co-design study with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments, exploring their needs and preferences for voice-based interfaces. We identify key design considerations, including the use of simple, consistent language, visual feedback, and adaptive difficulty levels. We also develop and evaluate a prototype interface, 'EasyVoice', which incorporates these design principles and achieves significant improvements in user engagement and task completion rates compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis has become increasingly important in natural language processing, but existing methods struggle to effectively fuse multimodal features from text, image, and audio inputs. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that learns to attend to relevant features across modalities, capturing complex relationships between them. Our approach leverages graph-based representation learning to model the intricate structures present in multimodal data. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving higher accuracy and robustness in sentiment classification tasks.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to navigate complex scenarios. However, the lack of transparency in RL decision-making hinders trust and safety. This paper proposes 'CLEAR', an explainable RL framework that integrates model-based and model-free approaches. CLEAR leverages attention mechanisms to identify relevant environment features and generate interpretable explanations for policy decisions. We evaluate CLEAR on a simulated autonomous driving benchmark, demonstrating improved interpretability without compromising control performance. Our approach has implications for real-world autonomous systems, enabling human-AI collaboration and increasing public trust.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Multimodal Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multimodal retrieval has gained significant attention in recent years, but the problem of query expansion remains a major challenge. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach for query expansion, which leverages the semantic relationships between text and image modalities. Our proposed model, 'MMQE', uses a multimodal embedding space to learn a compact representation of queries, and then expands the query using a generative adversarial network. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that MMQE significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 12.5% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Entity Retrieval using Graph-Based Semantic Embeddings
paper_abstract: Entity retrieval is a crucial task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve entities that match a given query. One of the key challenges in entity retrieval is the vocabulary mismatch problem, where the query terms do not match the terms used in the entity descriptions. In this paper, we propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages graph-based semantic embeddings to expand the query terms. Our approach uses a graph neural network to learn entity representations that capture the semantic relationships between entities and terms. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Improving Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Clustering
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems are designed to scale with large document collections, but they often suffer from high query latency due to the overhead of inter-node communication. This paper presents a novel approach to reduce query response time in DIR systems by applying hierarchical clustering to the document collection. Our method, called 'HierDIR', groups documents into clusters based on their semantic similarity and assigns each cluster to a specific node in the system. Experimental results on a large-scale document dataset show that HierDIR reduces query latency by up to 40% compared to state-of-the-art DIR systems while maintaining comparable retrieval effectiveness.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become a cornerstone of modern data analytics, but optimizing query performance in real-time remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'Aurora', an adaptive query optimization framework that leverages machine learning to dynamically adjust query execution plans based on workload patterns and system resources. We propose a novel cost model that incorporates statistical profiling, query execution history, and resource utilization metrics to guide plan optimization. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database benchmark demonstrate that Aurora achieves up to 3x performance improvements over state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Conversational Search using Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to mimic human-like interactions, but often struggle with complex, multi-turn queries. This paper proposes a novel approach to deep query reformulation, which leverages hierarchical graph attention mechanisms to capture contextual relationships between entities and intents. Our model, 'ConverseQA', learns to recursively refine queries by identifying key concepts, resolving coreference, and generating follow-up questions. Experimental results on the TREC Conversational Assistance Track dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and conversational coherence compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. Traditional QE methods rely on statistical techniques, neglecting the semantic relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel QE approach, 'SemQE', which leverages deep learning-based semantic embeddings to capture nuanced query semantics. Our method integrates a pre-trained language model with a relevance-based feedback loop, refining the query representation to better match relevant documents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art QE methods.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in document retrieval tasks, but their computational complexity hinders their deployment in real-world search engines. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HNR', which leverages a two-stage ranking architecture to reduce the number of document evaluations while maintaining retrieval effectiveness. The first stage employs a lightweight neural scorer to filter out irrelevant documents, and the second stage utilizes a more accurate but computationally expensive model to re-rank the top candidates. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNR achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency while maintaining competitive performance with state-of-the-art models.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We present a novel approach to task allocation in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. Our Hierarchical Task Allocation (HTA) framework utilizes a two-level hierarchy of agents, where high-level agents allocate tasks to low-level agents based on their capabilities and available resources. We employ a decentralized deep Q-network (DDQN) to learn the optimal task allocation policy, which is shown to outperform traditional methods in terms of task completion efficiency and agent utility. Experimental results demonstrate the scalability and adaptability of HTA in various simulated scenarios.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent-Based Systems for Real-Time Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: We present a novel decentralized autonomous agent-based system for real-time resource allocation in dynamic environments. Our approach leverages multi-agent negotiation protocols and distributed constraint optimization to allocate resources efficiently and adapt to changes in the environment. We evaluate our system in a simulated smart grid scenario, demonstrating improved responsiveness and reduced resource waste compared to traditional centralized approaches. The proposed framework has implications for various applications, including smart cities, logistics, and robotics.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) tasks require models to integrate information from different modalities, including images and natural language. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework that effectively fuses multi-modal features in VQA. HGAT uses graph attention mechanisms to model relationships between visual objects and question entities, while also incorporating hierarchical fusion of modalities at different levels of abstraction. We evaluate HGAT on the VQA 2.0 benchmark and demonstrate significant improvements in accuracy over state-of-the-art models, particularly for complex questions requiring multi-hop reasoning.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to provide explanations for DRL agents' decision-making processes. Our approach uses a hierarchical policy representation to focus on relevant state features and abstract away irrelevant information. We evaluate HAN on a range of Atari games and demonstrate improved explainability and robustness to perturbations compared to state-of-the-art DRL methods.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning to autonomous traffic signal control. We propose a novel framework, 'MA-STRL', which enables multiple agents to learn and adapt to dynamic traffic patterns in real-time. Each agent, representing a traffic signal, learns to optimize its control policy based on local observations and communicate with neighboring agents to achieve global coordination. We evaluate MA-STRL on a realistic traffic simulation platform and demonstrate significant improvements in traffic flow and reduction in congestion compared to traditional signal control methods.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Time Series Forecasting with Uncertainty Estimation
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is a fundamental problem in many real-world applications. However, traditional methods often struggle with few-shot scenarios, where limited data is available. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach, 'MetaTSF', which leverages uncertainty estimation to adapt to new time series datasets with limited observations. Our framework consists of a probabilistic neural network that learns to generate uncertainty-aware forecasts, and a meta-learning module that adapts the model to new datasets using Bayesian inference. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of MetaTSF in improving forecasting accuracy and uncertainty estimation in few-shot settings.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a novel approach using hierarchical graph attention networks (HGATs) to learn effective coordination strategies. Our HGAT model consists of a hierarchical graph structure that captures agent interactions at multiple scales, and attention mechanisms that focus on relevant agents and their relationships. We evaluate our approach on a variety of coordination tasks, including traffic management and resource allocation, and demonstrate significant improvements in performance and scalability compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in many homes, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a participatory design approach to creating inclusive voice assistants for this demographic. We conducted co-design workshops with 20 older adults to identify key accessibility requirements, such as simplified syntax, explicit error handling, and personalized feedback. We then developed a prototype voice assistant incorporating these features and evaluated its usability with 15 older adults. Results show significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion rates compared to existing voice assistants. Our findings inform the design of more accessible and usable voice assistants for older adults.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation with Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize agent assignments. Our approach, called 'RL-MASTA', employs a novel combination of graph neural networks and Q-learning to learn task allocation policies that adapt to changing environmental conditions and agent capabilities. Experimental results demonstrate that RL-MASTA outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and agent utility.

title: A Hybrid Ranking Model for Diverse and Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: The proliferation of online information has led to a pressing need for more efficient and diverse document retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel hybrid ranking model, 'DREM', which combines the strengths of traditional term-based retrieval and neural-based ranking techniques. DREM leverages a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize ranking, relevance, and diversity metrics, resulting in significant improvements over state-of-the-art baselines. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate that DREM achieves higher precision, recall, and novelty scores while reducing computational overhead by up to 30%.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding human-robot collaboration in these environments is crucial. This paper investigates the role of embodiment in VR-based human-robot collaboration, where users are represented by avatars and interact with robots through gestures. We conduct a user study comparing two conditions: embodied and non-embodied collaboration. Our results show that embodied collaboration leads to improved task performance, enhanced user satisfaction, and increased trust in the robot. We also identify key factors influencing these outcomes, including avatar design and gesture recognition accuracy. Our findings have significant implications for the design of future VR-based human-robot collaboration systems.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: We propose a hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for autonomous traffic signal control, where each agent controls a set of nearby intersections. The framework consists of a high-level planning module that allocates tasks to agents based on traffic conditions, and a low-level execution module that uses deep Q-networks to optimize signal timings. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale simulation of Pittsburgh's traffic network, demonstrating a 23% reduction in average travel time and a 17% decrease in congestion compared to traditional fixed-time signal control. The hierarchical architecture enables efficient exploration and adaptation to changing traffic patterns.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Decentralized Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized multi-agent systems (DMAS) are increasingly used in various applications, including robotics, autonomous vehicles, and smart grids. However, task allocation in DMAS remains a challenging problem, particularly in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel approach to autonomous task allocation using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We develop a decentralized DRL framework that enables agents to learn task allocation policies through interactions with their environment and other agents. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated environment, demonstrating improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Empathetic Response Generation Framework
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their responses often lack empathy, leading to user frustration and disengagement. This paper presents 'EmpaVoice', a novel framework that generates empathetic responses to user queries. We employ a multi-task learning approach, combining emotional intelligence with natural language understanding to create more compassionate and personalized interactions. Our user study with 100 participants demonstrates that EmpaVoice significantly improves user satisfaction and perceived empathy compared to existing voice assistants. We also provide design guidelines for inclusive voice interface development.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval using Word Embeddings and Concept Graphs
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval remains a challenging task due to the limited contextual information available. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages word embeddings and concept graphs to capture nuanced semantic relationships. Our method embeds query terms and documents in a shared vector space, then uses graph-based clustering to identify relevant concepts. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short queries, over state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that learns to allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, dependencies, and resource constraints. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between agents and tasks, and hierarchical pooling to capture both local and global dependencies. Experimental results on a suite of benchmark problems demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, resource utilization, and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Conversational AI using Graph-based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Conversational AI systems are increasingly vulnerable to sophisticated adversarial attacks that can manipulate user interactions. This paper proposes a novel graph-based anomaly detection framework, 'ConverseGuard', to detect such attacks in real-time. ConverseGuard models user-AI interactions as a graph and leverages graph neural networks to identify anomalous patterns indicative of adversarial behavior. We evaluate ConverseGuard on a large-scale conversational dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting targeted attacks, including those that evade traditional detection methods.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, but existing methods often rely on handcrafted rules or simplistic statistical models. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQL', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn optimal query expansion strategies. By formulating query expansion as a Markov Decision Process, we train a deep Q-network to select the most informative terms and weights for a given query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQL significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving improvements in both precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Cloud Databases
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy in cloud databases introduces significant performance challenges due to concurrent query execution and resource contention. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MQO', which leverages machine learning-based prediction models to dynamically allocate resources and prioritize queries for each tenant. We develop a robust cost model that incorporates query complexity, data freshness, and tenant-specific QoS constraints. Experimental evaluation on a real-world cloud database workload demonstrates that MQO achieves up to 35% improvement in query response times and 20% reduction in resource utilization compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Learning for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis is a challenging task that requires processing and integrating information from diverse sources such as text, images, and audio. This paper proposes a novel zero-shot learning approach that leverages graph attention networks to capture complex relationships between modalities. Our method, called GraphZero, learns to attend to relevant modalities and generate sentiment scores without requiring labeled data for new classes. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of GraphZero over existing state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 12.5% in sentiment accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Oriented Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed column-oriented databases have become increasingly popular for large-scale data analytics. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and dynamic reordering of join operations. We propose a graph-based approach to model the query optimization problem and develop an efficient algorithm to find near-optimal solutions. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving an average reduction of 30% in query execution time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where autonomous agents need to allocate tasks efficiently without a central controller. This paper proposes a novel approach using multi-agent reinforcement learning, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. We introduce a decentralized, asynchronous Q-learning algorithm that enables agents to adapt to changing environments and task requirements. Experimental results on a simulated robotics scenario demonstrate improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional, centralized approaches.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Improving Retrieval Efficiency in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines face the challenge of efficiently retrieving relevant documents from a vast, geographically dispersed index. This paper presents a novel context-aware query expansion technique that leverages user behavior, query logs, and semantic analysis to improve retrieval efficiency. Our approach, called CAQE, adaptively selects expansion terms based on the user's search history and context, reducing the number of unnecessary query iterations and resulting in significant latency reductions. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed search engine demonstrate CAQE's effectiveness in improving retrieval efficiency while maintaining relevance and precision.

title: Deep Hierarchical Query Reformulation for Efficient Retrieval in Specialized Search Engines
paper_abstract: Specialized search engines, such as those for academic publications or e-commerce products, often struggle with complex queries that require nuanced understanding of domain-specific terminology. This paper presents a novel approach to query reformulation, leveraging deep hierarchical neural networks to recursively refine queries and improve retrieval accuracy. Our approach, dubbed 'HierQR', incorporates domain-specific knowledge graphs and word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms. Experimental results on a large-scale academic search dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to existing query reformulation techniques.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In dynamic multi-agent systems, effective task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning framework, 'MA-RL', that enables agents to adaptively allocate tasks based on changing environmental conditions and agent capabilities. MA-RL utilizes a decentralized, asynchronous Q-learning approach to learn optimal task assignments and coordination strategies. We evaluate MA-RL in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional, centralized allocation methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their usability for older adults with cognitive impairments remains limited. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create an inclusive voice assistant that accommodates the needs of this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our proposed design incorporates personalized cognitive supports, such as memory aids and error forgiveness, and evaluates the effectiveness of these features through a usability study. Results show significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction, highlighting the potential for voice assistants to promote digital inclusion for older adults.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Relational Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have become a crucial component in various artificial intelligence applications. However, existing methods struggle to effectively model complex relational structures and heterogeneous information. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework, which leverages multi-relational attention mechanisms to capture nuanced interactions between entities and relationships. HGAT learns hierarchical representations by recursively applying attention across different relational contexts, enabling the modeling of intricate dependencies and constraints. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HGAT in link prediction, entity classification, and question answering tasks, showcasing its potential in real-world knowledge graph applications.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Heterogeneous Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in heterogeneous graphs is a challenging task due to the presence of multiple node and edge types. Recent approaches have leveraged graph attention networks (GATs) to learn node representations, but they fail to capture hierarchical relationships between nodes. In this paper, we propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that incorporates hierarchical attention mechanisms to learn node representations at multiple scales. We evaluate HGAT on three real-world datasets and demonstrate improved performance over state-of-the-art GAT-based methods. Our approach has applications in recommender systems, social network analysis, and knowledge graph completion.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on heuristics or manual feature engineering. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DRL-QE', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn an optimal query expansion policy. Our model learns to select the most informative terms to add to the original query, leading to significant improvements in retrieval performance. We evaluate DRL-QE on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in retrieving relevant documents, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Graph Databases
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of RDF graph databases in various applications, optimizing query performance becomes a critical challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RDFox', which leverages graph partitioning and parallel processing to accelerate query execution in distributed RDF graph databases. We introduce a cost-based optimization strategy that takes into account data distribution, query patterns, and node connectivity to minimize data transfer and processing overhead. Experimental results on large-scale RDF datasets demonstrate that RDFox outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 50% in terms of query response time.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Graph Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have emerged as a powerful tool for graph-structured data analysis. However, their performance is highly dependent on the choice of hyperparameters, which can be computationally expensive to tune. This paper proposes a Bayesian optimization framework, 'GraphBO', that leverages the graph structure to guide the search for optimal hyperparameters. We demonstrate that GraphBO outperforms traditional Bayesian optimization methods and achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, including molecular property prediction and social network analysis.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent Coordination via Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized approach to coordinating multiple autonomous agents in complex, dynamic environments. We employ reinforcement learning to train individual agents to adapt to changing circumstances and learn effective coordination strategies. Our method, dubbed '-AgentRL', leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and optimize collective behavior. Experimental results on a simulated traffic scenario demonstrate improved coordination and reduced congestion compared to traditional centralized control methods.

title: Query Optimization for Large-Scale Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component in graph database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and scalability. Existing optimization techniques rely on heuristics or static analysis, which may not adapt well to dynamic query workloads. We propose a novel approach, 'GraphRL', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans for large-scale graph databases. Our method learns to adapt to changing query patterns and database states, achieving significant improvements in query latency and throughput. Experimental results on a real-world social network dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphRL compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Conversational Strategies for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their usefulness is often limited for users with disabilities. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the conversational strategies employed by popular voice assistants and their impact on accessibility. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants with disabilities and found that current systems often rely on visual cues, assume uniform linguistic abilities, and neglect context-dependent preferences. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants, emphasizing the need for adaptive dialogue management, multimodal input support, and user-centered customization. Our findings have significant implications for the development of more accessible and usable conversational systems.

title: Meta-Learning for Adaptive Hyperparameter Tuning in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks require careful hyperparameter tuning to achieve optimal performance. However, this process is often manual, time-consuming, and dataset-dependent. This paper introduces a novel meta-learning approach, 'HyperMeta', which learns to adapt hyperparameters across diverse datasets and models. By leveraging a meta-learner to generate hyperparameter suggestions, we demonstrate improved performance and reduced tuning time on various benchmark datasets. Our approach is particularly effective for transfer learning and few-shot learning scenarios, where hyperparameter tuning is crucial but challenging.

title: A Real-time Query Expansion Framework for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in retrieving relevant documents in information retrieval (IR) systems. However, existing QE methods often suffer from high computational overhead, leading to slow response times. This paper proposes a novel real-time QE framework, 'RTEQE', which leverages a combination of lexical semantic analysis and machine learning-based term weighting. RTEQE reduces the dimensionality of the query space by identifying key contextual phrases, and then applies an efficient term re-weighting scheme to prioritize informative terms. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RTEQE achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness while reducing query processing time by up to 50% compared to state-of-the-art QE methods.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Multimodal Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Multimodal information retrieval (MIR) aims to retrieve relevant information from diverse media types, such as images, text, and audio. However, the complexity of MIR queries often hinders the retrieval performance. This paper proposes a context-aware query expansion (CAQE) approach that leverages multimodal features and contextual information to refine MIR queries. CAQE incorporates a novel attention mechanism to weigh the importance of different modalities and contextual cues, such as user location and search history. Experimental results on a large-scale MIR dataset demonstrate that CAQE significantly improves the retrieval accuracy and diversity compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Query-Dependent Document Ranking with Context-Aware Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional document ranking models rely on static representations of documents, neglecting the nuanced context of user queries. We propose a novel neural ranking model, 'ContextRank', which leverages query-dependent document encoding and contextualized embeddings. By incorporating query-aware attention mechanisms and semantic role labeling, ContextRank captures the intricate relationships between query terms, document entities, and their contextual roles. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy and relevance over state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Cooperative Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing systems face the challenge of efficiently allocating resources to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper proposes a cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CMARL', that enables autonomous agents to learn and adapt to changing resource requirements. CMARL employs a decentralized, communication-based approach, where agents share knowledge and negotiate resource allocations to maximize overall system performance. We conduct experiments on a simulated cloud environment and demonstrate that CMARL achieves improved resource utilization, reduced latency, and enhanced system adaptability compared to traditional heuristic-based allocation methods.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Elderly Users: A Study on Trust and Cognition
paper_abstract: This study investigates the impact of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) on elderly users' trust and cognitive performance. We designed and evaluated two ECAs, differing in their level of anthropomorphism and expressiveness, in a Wizard-of-Oz experiment with 30 elderly participants. Results show that the more anthropomorphic ECA increased users' trust and improved their cognitive recall, but also led to higher expectations and disappointment. We discuss the implications for ECA design and provide guidelines for creating more effective and trustworthy interfaces for elderly users.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems with Temporal Dependencies
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. We present a novel hierarchical task allocation framework that considers temporal dependencies between tasks. Our approach leverages a graph-based representation of tasks and agents, and utilizes a recursive decomposition technique to allocate tasks at multiple levels of abstraction. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach through simulations on a logistics domain, showing significant improvements in task completion rate and agent utilization compared to existing flat allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial component of human-computer interaction (HCI) systems. With the proliferation of multimodal interfaces, it is essential to develop models that can effectively integrate and process heterogeneous data from various sources. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for multimodal emotion recognition. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on salient features from different modalities, such as speech, text, and facial expressions. Experimental results on the Multimodal Emotion Recognition dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an F1-score of 0.92 in recognizing six basic emotions.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize social interactions, but current systems often exclude users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel framework for designing embodied conversational agents (ECAs) that promote inclusivity in VR environments. We propose a multimodal interaction model that integrates speech, gesture, and gaze cues to facilitate more natural and accessible human-agent communication. Our user study with participants with and without disabilities demonstrates that our ECA design improves social presence, trust, and overall user experience in VR. The findings have significant implications for the development of inclusive and accessible VR applications.

title: Designing Intuitive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Augmented Reality Training Systems
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) training systems have the potential to revolutionize various industries, but their adoption is hindered by the lack of intuitive user interfaces. This paper presents a gesture-based interface design framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to recognize and interpret user gestures in AR environments. We conducted a series of user studies to inform the design of our system, which incorporates a novel gesture recognition algorithm and a visual feedback mechanism to enhance user experience. Our evaluation results show that our approach significantly improves user performance and satisfaction in AR-based training tasks.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Disaster Response
paper_abstract: Effective disaster response relies on the coordination of multiple agents, including emergency responders, drones, and autonomous vehicles. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework to optimize agent coordination in dynamic, partially-observable environments. Our approach combines a high-level planner with low-level controllers, enabling agents to adapt to changing circumstances while minimizing communication overhead. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in a simulated disaster response scenario, achieving significant reductions in response time and resource utilization compared to decentralized or scripted approaches.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Augmented Reality Learning Environments
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent in educational settings, there is a growing need for intuitive and adaptive interfaces that facilitate effective learning experiences. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface design framework for AR learning environments, which leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to dynamically recognize and adapt to users' gestures. Our approach incorporates real-time user feedback and cognitive load assessment to optimize the interface's responsiveness and minimize user frustration. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in learning outcomes and user satisfaction compared to traditional keyboard-based interfaces.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating the actions of multiple agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HierMA', which enables agents to learn both individual and collaborative strategies. We introduce a novel hierarchical architecture that consists of a high-level coordination module and low-level action modules, allowing agents to adapt to changing environments and optimize global rewards. Experimental results on a traffic management scenario demonstrate that HierMA outperforms traditional decentralized and centralized approaches, achieving improved traffic flow and reduced congestion.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on effective document retrieval and passage ranking to answer user queries. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, 'QDDE', which iteratively refines the document set based on the query context and passage relevance. We introduce a neural ranking model that incorporates query-specific entity embeddings and semantic role labeling to better capture the question intent. Experimental results on the SQuAD dataset demonstrate that QDDE achieves significant improvements in top-1 passage accuracy and answer recall compared to state-of-the-art ODQA systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Large-Scale Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in large-scale graphs is a fundamental problem in graph-structured data analysis. Existing graph neural network (GNN) models suffer from scalability issues and fail to capture hierarchical graph structures. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture, which combines multi-scale graph attention mechanisms to capture complex node relationships. HGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, including the massive OGB-LSCII graph, and demonstrates significant improvements over existing GNN models in terms of both accuracy and scalability.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval via Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. One major challenge is the vocabulary mismatch between the query and documents. In this paper, we propose a novel neural query expansion approach that leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to improve retrieval performance. Our model, called NQE-PRF, learns to generate query expansions by predicting relevant documents based on the initial retrieval results. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NQE-PRF outperforms state-of-the-art methods, especially for queries with limited relevant documents.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition Accuracy and User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the design of voice assistants that cater to the needs of older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study to evaluate the speech recognition accuracy and user experience of popular voice assistants among older adults with varying levels of hearing impairment. Our results show that existing voice assistants struggle to recognize speech from older adults, particularly those with hearing impairments. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants, including personalized speech recognition models, simplified dialogue flows, and multimodal feedback mechanisms. Our prototype, 'ElderVoice', demonstrates improved speech recognition accuracy and user satisfaction among older adults.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Lane Changing
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient lane-changing strategies to ensure safe and smooth traffic flow. This paper presents a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (DHRL) framework for lane-changing decision-making. Our approach integrates a high-level policy network with a low-level motion planning network, enabling the vehicle to adapt to dynamic environments and unexpected events. We evaluate the DHRL framework on a realistic simulation platform and demonstrate improved performance compared to traditional rule-based and reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Enhancing Query Facets with Deep Neural Networks for Improved Result Diversification
paper_abstract: Result diversification is a critical challenge in modern search engines, as it directly impacts user satisfaction and engagement. This paper presents a novel approach to query facet generation, which leverages the representational power of deep neural networks to better capture the underlying intent behind user queries. Our proposed model, FacetNet, incorporates a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes facet generation and ranking, leading to improved result diversification and reduced redundancy. Experiments on a large-scale query log dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of FacetNet in enhancing search engine performance, with significant gains in metrics such as novelty and diversity.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the retrieval performance. Existing methods rely on heuristics or manual tuning, which may not adapt well to diverse query types and collections. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning framework, 'QL-Expander', that learns to optimize query expansion dynamically. The agent learns to select the most informative terms to add to the query, taking into account the feedback from the retrieval system. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate that QL-Expander outperforms state-of-the-art expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Users with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly popular in modern computing, but their accessibility for users with motor disabilities remains a significant concern. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive gesture-based interfaces that accommodate users with varying levels of motor abilities. We propose a machine learning-based approach to gesture recognition that incorporates personalized models and adaptive thresholding to improve accuracy and user satisfaction. A user study with 20 participants with motor disabilities demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach in reducing error rates and enhancing user experience.

title: Robustness Evaluation of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Approximations
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. Evaluating the robustness of DNNs against such attacks is critical to ensuring their reliability in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian approximation approach to efficiently evaluate the robustness of DNNs against adversarial attacks. We derive a closed-form expression for the Bayesian neural network's predictive uncertainty, which allows us to quantify the robustness of the model. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of robustness evaluation accuracy while reducing computational overhead.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Learned Index Structures in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have revolutionized data processing by minimizing disk I/O. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge.
