This paper presents a novel approach, 'LearnedIndex', which leverages machine learning to optimize index structures for main-memory databases. By learning the underlying data distribution, our method adaptively constructs a hybrid index that combines the benefits of B-trees and hash tables, achieving up to 3x query performance improvement compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques. We conduct an extensive evaluation on real-world datasets and demonstrate the effectiveness of LearnedIndex in various query scenarios.

title: Enhancing Retrieval Efficiency with Query-Specific Indexing for Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval systems (DIRS) are increasingly important for handling large-scale search queries. However, existing indexing techniques often lead to inefficient query processing and high communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel query-specific indexing approach, 'QSIndex', which dynamically adapts to the query patterns and document distributions in DIRS. QSIndex leverages a hybrid indexing structure that combines the benefits of inverted indexing and document-based indexing. Our experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that QSIndex achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency, reducing average query response time by up to 37% compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Bayesian HyperNetworks for Resource-Constrained Edge Devices
paper_abstract: The proliferation of edge devices has created a need for efficient neural networks that can operate within stringent resource constraints. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) framework, 'BayesNAS', which leverages Bayesian HyperNetworks to generate accurate and efficient models. By incorporating a probabilistic prior over the architecture space, BayesNAS can effectively explore the vast search space and identify optimal architectures under resource constraints. Our experiments on various image classification benchmarks demonstrate that BayesNAS can discover models that achieve state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational requirements by up to 50%.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval Using Graph-Based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, due to the limited context and lack of relevant keywords. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'GraphExpan', that leverages graph-based embeddings to capture semantic relationships between keywords. Our method represents queries as graphs, where nodes correspond to keywords and edges denote co-occurrence and semantic relationships. We then use graph convolutional networks to learn dense embeddings for each node, which are used to expand the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, improving retrieval performance by up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their adoption among older adults is hindered by accessibility barriers. This study investigates the design of inclusive voice assistants for older adults, focusing on multimodal interaction. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, exploring their preferences and experiences with voice, gesture, and visual modalities. Our findings highlight the importance of personalized feedback, simplified language, and adaptive error handling. We propose a set of design guidelines for creating accessible voice assistants that cater to the diverse needs of older adults, promoting digital inclusion and independent living.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that learns to fuse and align features from different modalities in a hierarchical manner. Our model consists of modality-specific graph attention layers that capture intra-modal relationships, followed by a cross-modal fusion layer that leverages attention to weigh the importance of each modality. Experimental results on the CMU-MultiModal dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions across different modalities.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Cooperation for Real-Time Resource Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing complexity of IoT networks demands efficient resource allocation strategies to ensure reliable and real-time task execution. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent framework, 'MARIA', that enables scalable cooperation among agents to optimize resource allocation. We develop a distributed negotiation protocol that leverages semantic reasoning and distributed constraint satisfaction to allocate resources in a decentralized manner. Experimental results on a real-world IoT testbed demonstrate that MARIA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of response time, resource utilization, and adaptability to dynamic network conditions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis has become a crucial task in natural language processing, but existing approaches often struggle with multi-modal data. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that effectively integrates textual, visual, and acoustic features for sentiment analysis. The proposed HAN utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on salient features across modalities, leading to improved sentiment prediction accuracy. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate the superiority of HAN over state-of-the-art approaches, highlighting its potential for real-world applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in node classification tasks, but often struggle to capture complex relationships between nodes. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, HAGNN, which leverages attention mechanisms at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant nodes and their neighbors. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical clustering strategy to group nodes based on their structural and feature similarities, enabling the model to capture both local and global patterns. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art GNN models in node classification tasks, particularly in scenarios with sparse node labels.

title: Incremental Learning for Dynamic Concept Drift in Real-World Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Autonomous systems operating in real-world environments often face dynamic concept drift, where the underlying data distribution changes over time. This paper proposes an incremental learning framework, 'DriftAdapt', that adapts to concept drift in autonomous systems. DriftAdapt combines online learning with a novel drift detection method based on statistical process control. We evaluate DriftAdapt on a real-world autonomous driving dataset and demonstrate its ability to adapt to sudden changes in the environment, outperforming traditional batch learning approaches. Our framework has significant implications for ensuring the reliability and safety of autonomous systems in dynamic environments.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-Based Planning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient exploration of the environment is crucial for tasks such as search and rescue, surveillance, and environmental monitoring. This paper introduces a novel graph-based planning approach, dubbed 'Coordinated Explorer', which enables agents to coordinate their exploration efforts in a decentralized manner. By modeling the environment as a graph, agents can share information and plan their trajectories to minimize overlap and maximize coverage. We present simulation results demonstrating the effectiveness of Coordinated Explorer in various scenarios, including urban search and rescue and environmental monitoring.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Efficient Image Search using Deep Visual Features
paper_abstract: Image search has become an essential component of modern information retrieval systems. However, existing approaches often rely on hand-crafted features or complex deep learning models, leading to suboptimal performance or computational inefficiency. This paper proposes a hybrid retrieval model, 'Hydra', that leverages both traditional computer vision features and deep visual features extracted from convolutional neural networks. Hydra combines the strengths of both approaches using a novel fusion mechanism, achieving state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets. We also introduce a query expansion strategy that adaptively refines the search results based on user feedback, further improving the model's effectiveness.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Neural Ranking
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant evidence for answer extraction. This paper introduces Hierarchical Neural Ranking (HNR), a novel retrieval framework that leverages a hierarchical representation of passages to improve retrieval efficiency and effectiveness. HNR first uses a coarse-grained neural ranker to filter out irrelevant passages, followed by a fine-grained ranker that refines the ranking using semantic similarity. Experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HNR outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods, achieving a 15% increase in retrieval accuracy while reducing computational overhead by 30%.

title: Deep Relevance Ranking with Context-Aware Query Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search queries often exhibit nuanced context and intent, which traditional retrieval models struggle to capture. We propose a novel deep relevance ranking approach, 'CARPE', that leverages context-aware query embeddings to better model query semantics. CARPE incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on salient query terms and their contextual relationships. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc search benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in ranking quality and retrieval effectiveness compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Context-Aware Neural Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in modern information retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the retrieval effectiveness. This paper presents a novel neural query expansion approach, dubbed CAQE, which incorporates contextual information from the query and documents to generate more effective expansion terms. Our model utilizes a graph attention mechanism to capture the relationships between query terms, documents, and their latent representations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in ranking metrics such as NDCG and ERR.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on heuristics or manual feature engineering. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning framework, 'RL-QE', which learns to expand queries by interacting with a simulated retrieval environment. We formulate query expansion as a Markov decision process and employ a deep Q-network to select expansion terms that maximize the expected retrieval performance. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly in cases where the initial query is noisy or incomplete.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become a cornerstone of modern data management, but optimizing queries across multiple nodes remains a complex challenge. This paper presents 'RL-Optimizer', a novel query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning to adapt to dynamic workloads and node configurations. By modeling query optimization as a Markov decision process, RL-Optimizer learns to select optimal join orders, indexing strategies, and data placement schemes that minimize latency and maximize throughput. Experimental evaluations on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate significant performance improvements over traditional rule-based optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis of multi-modal data (e.g., text, images, and videos) is a challenging task due to the inherent complexity of modeling relationships between different modalities. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that captures both intra- and inter-modality interactions. HGAT employs a hierarchical graph structure to model the relationships between modalities, and attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant information. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in multi-modal sentiment analysis tasks, achieving an average improvement of 4.5% in F1-score.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper explores the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, focusing on gesture-based interaction. We designed an experiment to investigate how users' bodily experiences influence their cognitive processing of virtual objects. Our results show that participants who used gesture-based interaction exhibited improved spatial reasoning and object recognition compared to those using traditional controllers. We also found that the sense of agency and embodiment in VR is closely tied to the user's sense of self. Our findings have implications for the design of VR systems that aim to enhance cognitive performance and user engagement.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often rely on simplistic user-item interactions or oversimplify complex relationships. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) framework that learns to generate fine-grained explanations for recommendations. By incorporating multi-level attention mechanisms and graph-based user modeling, HAGNN captures nuanced user preferences and item relationships, leading to improved recommendation accuracy and explanation quality. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in ERS, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by 12.5% in terms of explanation quality.

title: EyeTrackingLens: A Gaze-Based Interface for Enhanced Virtual Reality Experience
paper_abstract: This paper presents EyeTrackingLens, a novel gaze-based interface designed to enhance the virtual reality (VR) experience. Our system leverages machine learning-based eye tracking to infer user intentions and enable seamless interactions with virtual objects. We develop a probabilistic gaze estimation model that integrates eye movement data with scene context, achieving a significant reduction in error rates compared to existing approaches. A user study demonstrates that EyeTrackingLens improves task efficiency and user satisfaction in VR applications, while also reducing eye fatigue and discomfort.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies via Constrained Policy Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its robustness to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel constrained policy optimization approach, 'ARPO', to enhance the robustness of DRL policies against adversarial perturbations. We formulate the problem as a constrained Markov decision process and develop an efficient algorithm to optimize the policy under attack constraints. Experimental results on Atari games and robotic manipulation tasks demonstrate that ARPO significantly improves the robustness of DRL policies while maintaining their performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Multi-Modal Fusion for Explainable Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data (e.g., audio, video, and text) has seen significant progress, but most approaches lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Multi-Modal Fusion (HAMMF) framework, which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. We introduce a novel Explainable Emotion Recognition (EER) metric to quantify the model's interpretability. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAMMF outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both recognition accuracy and EER, providing insights into the emotional cues exploited by the model.

title: Emotional Feedback Loops in Human-Computer Interaction: A Study on Affective Avatar-based Interfaces
paper_abstract: This study explores the role of emotional feedback loops in human-computer interaction, focusing on the use of affective avatar-based interfaces. We developed an empirical framework to analyze users' emotional responses to avatar-mediated feedback and investigated how these responses influence their interaction experience. Our results show that embodied avatars can create a sense of emotional resonance, leading to increased user engagement and affective synchronization. However, we also found that mismatched emotional feedback can result in user frustration and disengagement. Our findings have implications for the design of emotionally intelligent interfaces that can effectively recognize and respond to users' emotional states.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Attention for Long-Sequence Natural Language Processing
paper_abstract: Transformers have revolutionized natural language processing, but their quadratic complexity hinders their applicability to long sequences. This paper presents 'Hierarchical Attention with Efficient Reduction' (HAER), a novel architecture that tackles this limitation by introducing a hierarchical attention mechanism. HAER adaptively reduces the sequence length at each layer, significantly decreasing computational cost while maintaining performance. We evaluate HAER on various long-sequence NLP tasks, demonstrating state-of-the-art results on the WikiText-103 dataset and a 3x speedup over standard transformer models.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Improving Short-Text Retrieval in Microblogging Platforms
paper_abstract: Microblogging platforms like Twitter and Weibo have become essential sources of real-time information. However, their short-text nature poses significant challenges for effective information retrieval. This paper proposes a context-aware query expansion framework, 'CAQE', which leverages semantic, syntactic, and pragmatic features to enrich short queries. CAQE incorporates a novel attention-based mechanism to weigh the importance of expanded terms based on their relevance to the original query. Experimental results on a large-scale Twitter dataset demonstrate that CAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of precision, recall, and mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Drone Navigation in Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous drone navigation in uncertain environments is a challenging problem, requiring efficient exploration and adaptation to changing conditions. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-Drone', which integrates a high-level decision-making module with a low-level control policy. The high-level module uses a probabilistic graph model to reason about the environment and select goals, while the low-level policy employs a deep reinforcement learning algorithm to execute the selected goals. Experimental results in simulated and real-world scenarios demonstrate that HRL-Drone outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of navigation efficiency and robustness to uncertainty.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) is increasingly being adopted in educational settings, but the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user engagement remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the effects of customized avatars on learners' sense of presence, motivation, and overall learning experience in a VR-based learning environment. Our results show that participants who interacted with personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of engagement, reported greater enjoyment, and demonstrated improved knowledge retention compared to those using generic avatars. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of VR-based educational systems and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Robust Time Series Forecasting with Bayesian Neural Networks and Uncertainty Quantification
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is a crucial task in many domains, but traditional methods often fail to capture uncertainty and are sensitive to noisy data. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian neural network (BNN) framework, 'TS-BNN', which leverages uncertainty quantification to improve forecasting robustness. We develop a hierarchical prior structure that incorporates domain knowledge and adapts to changing data distributions. Experiments on real-world datasets show that TS-BNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and uncertainty estimation, demonstrating its potential for reliable decision-making in applications such as finance and energy management.

title: Query Expansion via Neural Graph-Based Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal query representations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, termed 'GraphEmbed', which leverages neural graph-based document embeddings to enrich query representations. By modeling document relationships as a graph, GraphEmbed captures nuances in document semantics, enabling more effective query expansion. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks via Stealthy Node Injection
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based tasks, but their robustness against adversarial attacks remains an open challenge. This paper proposes a novel stealthy node injection attack, 'GhostNode', which can manipulate the graph structure to mislead GNNs. We demonstrate that GhostNode can achieve high attack success rates on popular graph datasets, even when the GNN is trained with existing defense mechanisms. We also provide theoretical analysis on the attack's effectiveness and propose potential countermeasures to improve GNN robustness.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed column-store Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed column-store databases have become increasingly popular for big data analytics. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of distributed processing and column-oriented storage. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost modeling and dynamic reordering of join operations. We demonstrate that ColOpt achieves up to 3x improvement in query execution time compared to state-of-the-art optimizers on a real-world dataset. Furthermore, our approach is scalable and adaptable to varying workload patterns, making it suitable for modern data warehousing applications.

title: Dynamic Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is crucial for achieving complex tasks. However, existing approaches typically assume complete information about agent capabilities and preferences. This paper presents a novel framework for dynamic coalition formation in the presence of incomplete information. We propose a probabilistic modeling approach to estimate agent characteristics and develop a distributed algorithm for coalition formation that adapts to changing environment and agent availability. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task completion rates and reducing communication overhead.

title: Scalable Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-World Autonomous Driving
paper_abstract: Autonomous driving has made significant progress in recent years, but real-world deployment remains a challenge due to the complexity and variability of urban environments. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'Hierarchical Autonomous Vehicle' (HAV), which leverages a scalable and modular architecture to tackle long-horizon decision-making tasks in autonomous driving. HAV decomposes the driving task into high-level goals and low-level actions, allowing for more efficient exploration and adaptation to new scenarios. We demonstrate the efficacy of HAV on a large-scale simulated driving dataset and a real-world autonomous vehicle platform, achieving improved performance and safety compared to state-of-the-art flat RL approaches.

title: EmoTract: Affective State Recognition using Multimodal Fusion of Facial Expressions and Physiological Signals
paper_abstract: Affective state recognition is crucial in human-computer interaction, but existing approaches rely on either facial expressions or physiological signals, neglecting the complementary information they provide. We introduce EmoTract, a novel multimodal fusion framework that leverages facial action units and physiological signals (heart rate, skin conductance, and electroencephalography) to recognize users' emotional states. Our approach employs a graph convolutional network to model the relationships between facial features and physiological signals, achieving an improvement of 12.5% in F1-score over baseline methods. EmoTract enables more accurate and robust affective state recognition, with potential applications in mental health monitoring, personalized recommendation systems, and human-centered AI.

title: Gaze-Based Error Detection for Multimodal Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on multimodal interaction, combining speech, gesture, and gaze inputs. However, incorrect recognition of user intent can lead to frustration and errors. This paper proposes a novel gaze-based error detection approach, leveraging machine learning algorithms to identify inconsistencies between gaze patterns and intended actions. We evaluate our approach on a VR-based puzzle game, demonstrating a significant reduction in error rates and improved user experience. Our results have implications for the design of more intuitive and robust multimodal interfaces in VR and beyond.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular in modern data management systems, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We formulate the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and develop a deep Q-network-based algorithm to learn optimal query plans. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database show that our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and reduces resource utilization by 25%. We also demonstrate the adaptability of our approach to changing database workloads and schemas.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agents for Real-time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized autonomous agent framework for real-time traffic management. Our approach leverages multi-agent systems and distributed optimization to dynamically adjust traffic signal timings and lane allocations. We introduce a novel negotiation protocol that enables agents to exchange information and coordinate actions in real-time, resulting in reduced congestion and travel times. Simulation results on a realistic urban traffic network demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in mitigating traffic congestion and improving overall network efficiency.

title: Neural Ranking Models for Effective Retrieval in Specialized Domains
paper_abstract: Domain-specific retrieval tasks, such as patent search or biomedical literature retrieval, require tailored ranking models that can effectively capture domain knowledge. This paper proposes a neural ranking framework, 'DomainRank', which integrates domain-specific features and knowledge graphs into a deep learning architecture. We evaluate DomainRank on three specialized domains and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art models. Further analysis reveals that the incorporation of domain knowledge enables the model to better distinguish between relevant and non-relevant documents.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition is a challenging task that requires understanding complex interactions between visual, auditory, and textual cues. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our HAN architecture consists of modality-specific attention modules that learn to weight features based on their importance, followed by a fusion layer that integrates information across modalities. We evaluate our approach on the CMU-MOSEI dataset and demonstrate state-of-the-art performance on multimodal emotion recognition tasks. Furthermore, we provide visualizations of attention weights to facilitate explainability and interpretability of our model's predictions.

title: Coordinated Exploration for Multi-Agent Systems using Decentralized Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient exploration is crucial for collective decision-making. This paper presents a novel decentralized approach, 'Dec-GNN-Explore', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to facilitate coordinated exploration among agents. Each agent maintains a local GNN that learns to represent its surroundings and shares information with neighboring agents. We introduce a decentralized entropy-based objective that encourages agents to explore diverse regions while minimizing communication overhead. Experimental results on a range of multi-agent environments demonstrate the superior exploration efficiency and robustness of Dec-GNN-Explore compared to traditional, centralized methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular in recent years, but query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of graph structures and the need to balance query performance with resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning, where an agent learns to select optimal execution plans based on a reward function that incorporates both query latency and resource utilization. We evaluate our approach on a real-world graph database and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and resource efficiency compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic signal control is a challenging problem that requires coordinating multiple agents to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. This paper presents a scalable multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, dubbed 'SmartSignal', which leverages decentralized deep Q-networks to optimize signal timing at individual intersections. We propose a novel communication protocol that enables agents to share local state information and coordinate actions in real-time, while ensuring scalability to large networks. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulation platform demonstrate that SmartSignal outperforms traditional fixed-time and traffic-responsive signal control strategies, reducing average travel times by up to 23%.

title: Designing Adaptive Touchless Gestures for Inclusive Interfaces
paper_abstract: Traditional touch-based interfaces can be inaccessible or uncomfortable for individuals with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive touchless gestures for inclusive interfaces. We propose a machine learning-based framework that leverages computer vision and user behavior modeling to recognize and adapt to individual users' gestures in real-time. Our approach enables users to interact with interfaces using personalized, intuitive gestures, and provides a more inclusive and accessible experience. We evaluate our approach through a user study with participants with and without motor impairments, demonstrating improved interaction accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Individuals with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of daily life, but individuals with visual impairments often face significant barriers to accessing VR experiences. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'AccessibleVR', a novel VR interface that leverages auditory and haptic cues to facilitate navigation and interaction for visually impaired users. We conduct a user study with 20 participants and demonstrate that AccessibleVR significantly improves task completion rates and subjective user experience compared to standard VR interfaces. Our findings inform the development of inclusive VR systems that can empower individuals with visual impairments.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for real-time traffic control. Our approach, dubbed 'TrafficMA', leverages a decentralized, communication-efficient protocol to coordinate actions among multiple agents, each responsible for controlling a specific traffic signal. By incorporating a graph attention mechanism to model complex traffic dynamics, TrafficMA achieves significant improvements in traffic flow and reduces congestion compared to traditional, rule-based control systems. We evaluate our approach using a large-scale, real-world traffic simulation platform and demonstrate its scalability and adaptability to diverse traffic scenarios.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion using Graph Convolutional Networks for Improving Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it aims to capture the underlying intent behind a user's query. Traditional methods rely on keyword extraction and synonym-based expansion, which may not fully capture the context and semantic relationships between terms. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach using graph convolutional networks (GCNs). Our model, 'GCN-Expand', leverages a knowledge graph to represent term relationships and learns to selectively expand queries based on contextual features. Experimental results on the TREC datasets show that GCN-Expand outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and robustness to query ambiguity.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Graph Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, where query expansion techniques are often employed to improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel neural query graph embedding approach, termed 'NQGE', which learns to represent queries as dense graph embeddings. By leveraging these embeddings, we develop an efficient query expansion method that selectively incorporates relevant terms from the top-retrieved documents. Experimental results on several standard ad-hoc retrieval datasets demonstrate that NQGE significantly outperforms existing query expansion methods, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of MAP and NDCG metrics.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases with Heterogeneous Storage
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases with heterogeneous storage face significant query optimization challenges. This paper presents a novel cost-based optimization framework, 'HetroOpt', which leverages statistical models to estimate query execution times on diverse storage media. HetroOpt incorporates a new storage-aware join ordering algorithm and a dynamic data placement strategy to minimize data transfer and optimize query performance. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database demonstrate that HetroOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 35% in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Hierarchical Defense Mechanism
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based tasks, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks has raised concerns. Existing defense mechanisms focus on local or global perturbations, neglecting the hierarchical structure of graphs. We propose a novel hierarchical defense mechanism, 'HierDef', which leverages the graph's hierarchical representation to detect and mitigate attacks. HierDef incorporates attention-based graph pooling to identify critical nodes and edges, and then applies a robustness-enhancing regularization technique to the affected subgraphs. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierDef outperforms existing defense methods in terms of robustness and accuracy.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Adaptive Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has revolutionized the design of deep neural networks. However, existing NAS methods are often computationally expensive and require significant resources. This paper introduces 'ARAS', an efficient NAS framework that adaptively allocates resources to promising architectures during search. We propose a novel reinforcement learning-based controller that dynamically adjusts the number of iterations and batch sizes for each architecture, thereby reducing the search cost by up to 50%. Experimental results on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets demonstrate that ARAS discovers highly accurate models with fewer computational resources.

title: Hierarchical Attentional Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have garnered significant attention in recent years, as they provide insights into the decision-making process. This paper introduces HAGN, a hierarchical attentional graph neural network that leverages item-level and user-level interactions to generate personalized explanations for recommended items. HAGN learns to identify influential nodes in the user-item graph and attends to relevant contextual information, resulting in more accurate and interpretable recommendations. We evaluate HAGN on three real-world datasets, demonstrating improved recommendation performance and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning via Model-Based State Abstraction
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but the lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel model-based state abstraction framework, 'ExplainRL', which enables efficient explainability for DRL agents. By learning a compact, symbolic representation of the environment, ExplainRL reduces the dimensionality of the state space, allowing for more interpretable policies and better understanding of the decision-making process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of ExplainRL on several Atari games, showcasing improved performance and explainability compared to existing methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, particularly when queries are short or ambiguous. We propose a novel approach, Neural Query Graphs (NQG), which leverages graph neural networks to learn query representations that incorporate semantic relationships between terms. NQG expands the original query by generating a set of relevant sub-queries, which are then used to re-rank documents. Our experiments on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, with NQG outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion methods by up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Enhancing Query Optimization with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems pose significant challenges in query optimization, where suboptimal plans can lead to substantial performance degradation. This paper introduces 'DeepOpt', a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed environments. We design a reward function that incorporates both query execution time and resource utilization, enabling the agent to learn efficient query plans that balance these competing objectives. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that DeepOpt outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time, while reducing resource utilization by up to 25%.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a challenging problem due to the exponential increase in state and action spaces with the number of agents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions. Our approach consists of two stages: intra-agent attention for learning individual policies and inter-agent attention for coordinating actions. We evaluate HAN on several MARL benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and overall rewards compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Neural Retrieval with Hierarchical Query Embeddings for Efficient Document Ranking
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural retrieval models for document ranking rely on complex query-document interaction mechanisms, leading to increased computational costs. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'HiQE', which leverages hierarchical query embeddings to efficiently capture nuanced query semantics. By recursively aggregating query term representations, HiQE generates a compact, hierarchical query embedding that can be effectively matched with document representations. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that HiQE achieves comparable ranking performance to state-of-the-art models while reducing computational overhead by up to 40%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a challenging problem in AI research, particularly in complex graph-structured environments. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages graph attention mechanisms to facilitate cooperative decision-making among agents. HGAT incorporates a hierarchical graph representation, enabling agents to selectively focus on relevant neighboring agents and learn coordinated policies. Experimental results on a range of MARL benchmarks demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving improved cooperation and scalability in large-scale graph environments.

title: Embodied Cognition in Human-Robot Collaboration: A Study on Gestural Communication
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly interact with humans in various settings, effective communication becomes crucial. This paper explores the role of embodied cognition in human-robot collaboration, focusing on gestural communication. We designed an experiment where humans and robots collaborated on a task, using either explicit language-based instructions or implicit gestural cues. Our results show that gestural communication enhances task performance, reduces errors, and increases user satisfaction. We also found that humans adapt their gestural patterns to the robot's capabilities, demonstrating a deepening of mutual understanding. Our findings have implications for the design of more intuitive and effective human-robot collaboration systems.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Indexing for Temporal Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly important for various applications, such as social media analysis and IoT sensor networks. However, existing indexing techniques struggle to efficiently handle the massive scale and dynamic nature of these databases. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'ChronoGraph', which combines a hierarchical clustering approach with an adaptive sampling strategy. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that ChronoGraph achieves up to 3x faster query performance and 2x better storage efficiency compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods, while supporting efficient insertion and deletion operations.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex systems, multiple agents often compete for shared resources, leading to inefficient allocation and suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel framework for coordinating multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. We introduce a decentralized, partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP) that models the agents' interactions and resource dependencies. Our approach, called 'MA-RLA', leverages deep Q-networks to learn policies for each agent, which are then coordinated using a hierarchical clustering algorithm to minimize resource conflicts. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate that MA-RLA outperforms traditional allocation methods in terms of resource utilization and system-wide efficiency.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning framework, 'MASTAR', which enables agents to learn autonomous task allocation strategies. By modeling the task allocation problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process, MASTAR leverages deep Q-networks to learn optimal policies. We evaluate MASTAR on a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Virtual Objects in Augmented Reality
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, effective interaction methods are crucial for a seamless user experience. This paper explores the potential of gaze-based interaction with virtual objects in AR environments. We propose a novel approach that leverages machine learning-based gaze tracking and object recognition to enable users to select and manipulate virtual objects using only their gaze. Our user study demonstrates improved interaction accuracy and reduced cognitive load compared to traditional controller-based methods. We also discuss the implications of our approach for accessibility and future AR applications.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Storage
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems with heterogeneous storage configurations are increasingly common, but optimizing query performance in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'HeteroOpt', which leverages statistical models and reinforcement learning to adapt to varying storage characteristics. HeteroOpt integrates a cost-based optimizer with a storage-aware query planner, enabling efficient query execution across a range of storage configurations. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Decentralized Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Resource Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: Resource allocation is a critical challenge in IoT networks, where agents with conflicting goals compete for limited resources. This paper proposes a novel decentralized negotiation framework that enables agents to negotiate and allocate resources efficiently. We introduce a hybrid negotiation strategy that combines heuristic-based and machine learning-based approaches to adapt to dynamic network conditions. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that our framework achieves improved resource utilization and reduced negotiation time compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
paper_abstract: Social media platforms generate vast amounts of multimodal data, comprising text, images, and videos. Sentiment analysis on such data is crucial for businesses and organizations to understand public opinions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages the strengths of both visual and textual features for multimodal sentiment analysis. Our approach incorporates a modality-agnostic attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant features from each modality, resulting in improved sentiment prediction accuracy. Experimental results on a large-scale social media dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, outperforming state-of-the-art multimodal fusion techniques.

title: Scalable Entity Matching with Deep Learning-based Similarity Metrics
paper_abstract: Entity matching is a crucial step in data integration, where the goal is to identify duplicate records referring to the same real-world entity. Traditional approaches rely on hand-crafted similarity metrics, which can be ineffective in handling complex data variations. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DeepMatch', that learns similarity metrics from data. We design a siamese network architecture that captures both local and global patterns in entity data, enabling accurate matching at scale. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepMatch outperforms state-of-the-art methods by up to 15% in terms of F1-score, while reducing the need for manual feature engineering.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Transformers through Hierarchical Attention Regularization
paper_abstract: Transformers have become the de facto standard for natural language processing tasks, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about their reliability. This paper presents a novel approach to improving the robustness of transformers by regularizing their hierarchical attention mechanism. We introduce a new penalty term that encourages the model to focus on relevant input regions, reducing the impact of perturbations. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method, 'HAR-Transformer', achieves state-of-the-art performance under various attack scenarios, while maintaining competitive results on clean data.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy is a crucial feature in modern cloud-based database systems, allowing multiple users to share the same physical infrastructure. However, optimizing query performance in such systems is challenging due to the varying workload patterns and resource constraints of each tenant. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'TenantAware', which takes into account the dynamic tenant behavior and resource utilization to optimize query plans. Our experiments on a popular cloud-based database platform show that TenantAware outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query response time and resource efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years due to their ability to provide transparent and trustworthy suggestions to users. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) framework that leverages graph-based user-item interactions to generate personalized explanations for recommended items. HGAN consists of two main components: a graph attention encoder that captures complex relationships between users and items, and a hierarchical explanation generator that produces multi-level explanations for recommended items. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAN in improving recommendation accuracy and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality Environments: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but interactions within VR environments remain limited. This paper explores the potential of gaze-based interaction (GBI) in VR, where users control objects with their gaze. We conduct a user study to evaluate the usability and performance of GBI in a VR-based puzzle game. Our results show that GBI significantly improves user experience, especially for novice users, and achieves comparable task completion times to traditional controller-based input. We discuss the implications of our findings for future VR interaction design and provide recommendations for optimizing GBI in VR applications.

title: Optimizing Concurrency Control for Real-Time Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time database systems (RTDBS) require predictable and efficient concurrency control to meet timing constraints. This paper presents a novel concurrency control protocol, 'Predictive-OCC', which leverages machine learning-based workload prediction to dynamically adjust lock timeouts and minimize aborts. We introduce a hierarchical locking mechanism that adapts to changing workload patterns, reducing lock contention and improving system throughput. Experimental results on a simulated RTDBS workload demonstrate that Predictive-OCC outperforms existing protocols in terms of response time, throughput, and resource utilization.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents for Efficient Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of renewable energy sources and electric vehicles has introduced new challenges in managing energy resources in smart grids. This paper presents a decentralized coordination framework for autonomous agents, enabling them to optimize resource allocation in real-time. Our approach leverages a novel auction-based mechanism, which considers both physical grid constraints and agent preferences. Experimental results on a realistic grid simulation demonstrate significant improvements in energy efficiency, reduced congestion, and enhanced grid stability compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Designing Accessible Multimodal Interactions for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need to design accessible interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a novel multimodal interaction framework that integrates speech, gesture, and gaze inputs to accommodate varying cognitive abilities. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults and found that our framework significantly improved task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional unimodal interfaces. We also provide guidelines for designers to create accessible multimodal interfaces that cater to the diverse needs of older adults.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are becoming increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query performance in DDS is a challenging task due to the complexities of resource allocation. This paper proposes an adaptive resource allocation framework, 'ARAF', that dynamically adjusts resource allocation based on query workload and system dynamics. ARAF uses a reinforcement learning approach to optimize query performance, reducing average query latency by up to 30% compared to existing static resource allocation strategies. Our evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates the effectiveness of ARAF in improving query performance and system throughput.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Big Data Analytics using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: The increasing volume and velocity of big data pose significant challenges to traditional query optimization techniques. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages learned index structures to accelerate query processing in big data analytics. We design a neural network-based index model that learns to predict the optimal query execution plan from historical query patterns and data distributions. Our experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks, but their computational complexity grows quadratically with the number of nodes. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages hierarchical graph representations to reduce computational costs while maintaining performance. HGAT applies attention mechanisms at multiple scales, allowing the model to focus on relevant nodes and subgraphs. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating improved scalability and competitive performance compared to existing graph neural network models.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data (e.g., speech, text, vision) is a challenging task due to the heterogeneity of modalities and the scarcity of labeled data. We propose a novel hierarchical contrastive learning framework, which leverages the shared and modality-specific representations to improve emotion recognition. Our approach consists of two stages: (1) modality-specific contrastive learning to capture intra-modality patterns, and (2) hierarchical contrastive learning to align and fuse representations across modalities. Experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 12.5% in emotion recognition accuracy.

title: Efficient Out-of-Distribution Detection Using Deep Ensemble Methods
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are prone to erroneous predictions when encountering out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs. Ensemble methods have shown promise in detecting OOD samples, but often incur significant computational overhead. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'Deep Ensemble Detector' (DED), which leverages the diversity of multiple deep models to detect OOD inputs efficiently. We introduce a lightweight fusion mechanism that adaptively weights the outputs of individual models based on their confidence levels. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that DED achieves state-of-the-art OOD detection performance while reducing computational costs by up to 50% compared to existing ensemble methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotional Intelligence
paper_abstract: Emotional intelligence (EI) is a crucial aspect of human-AI interaction, but current models struggle to capture the complexity of emotional cues across different modalities (e.g., speech, text, vision). This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates multi-modal inputs to infer emotional states. Our approach utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and temporal segments, enabling the model to capture subtle emotional patterns. Experimental results on a large-scale, multi-modal EI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in improving emotional recognition accuracy and robustness.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-based Interaction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way we interact with digital information. However, the cognitive implications of gesture-based interaction in VR remain poorly understood. This paper explores the concept of embodied cognition in VR, where users' bodily experiences influence their cognitive processes. We conducted a user study to examine how gesture-based interaction affects spatial reasoning, memory recall, and problem-solving skills. Our results show that VR environments that incorporate embodied cognition principles can enhance user performance and engagement. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR interfaces and their potential applications in education and training.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of multi-agent task allocation in dynamic environments. We propose a novel approach based on deep reinforcement learning, which enables agents to learn effective task assignment strategies through experience. Our method, called 'MATARL', uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture to coordinate agents' actions and adapt to changing task requirements and resource availability. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that MATARL outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Cooperative Route Planning for Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for cooperative route planning in autonomous vehicle systems. Our approach, called 'CoopRoute', leverages the strengths of both centralized and decentralized planning by assigning a hierarchical structure to the agents. Each agent learns to optimize its own route while adapting to the actions of other agents, resulting in improved overall system efficiency and reduced travel times. We evaluate CoopRoute on a simulated urban traffic network and demonstrate its ability to outperform traditional planning methods in complex scenarios.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, where models must adapt to new classes with limited training data. This paper introduces a hierarchical meta-learning framework, 'HierML', which leverages a nested learning structure to learn more effective task embeddings. Our approach consists of two stages: a task-agnostic meta-learner that adapts to new tasks, and a task-specific learner that fine-tunes the model using hierarchical attention. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierML on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance on few-shot image classification tasks.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-computer interaction (HCI) is a crucial task for developing empathetic systems. However, existing approaches often rely on single-modal inputs (e.g., facial expressions or speech) and struggle to capture the complexity of human emotions. We propose a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multimodal inputs from facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals. Our HAN architecture employs a novel attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of each modality based on the input context. Experiments on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions and achieving more accurate affective state tracking.

title: Towards Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Graph-Based Attention
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising approach for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, the exponential growth of the search space with increasing network complexity hinders the efficiency of NAS methods. This paper introduces GraphATT, a novel NAS framework that leverages graph-based attention mechanisms to prune the search space and focus on promising architectures. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphATT on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results while reducing the search time by an order of magnitude compared to existing methods.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) becomes increasingly prevalent, the importance of effective human-robot collaboration (HRC) in VR environments grows. This paper explores the role of embodiment in HRC, examining how robot anthropomorphism and human embodiment in VR affect collaboration outcomes. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, using a mixed-design experiment to manipulate robot anthropomorphism and human embodiment. Our results show that embodied robots and humans in VR lead to improved collaboration performance and increased user satisfaction, compared to non-embodied conditions. We discuss implications for HRC system design and future research directions.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Resource Allocation for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to a surge in resource allocation challenges. This paper presents a novel decentralized agent-based framework for efficient resource allocation in IoT networks. Our approach leverages multi-agent systems to enable autonomous decision-making at the edge, reducing latency and improving scalability. We introduce a distributed negotiation protocol that enables agents to dynamically allocate resources based on real-time demand and availability. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in resource utilization and network efficiency compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Hierarchical Neural Networks for Context-Aware Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Context-aware information retrieval (CAIR) aims to retrieve documents relevant to a user's specific context. Existing methods rely on complex feature engineering and manual tuning of hyperparameters. We propose a novel hierarchical neural network (HNN) architecture that learns to rank documents based on contextual cues. Our HNN model consists of a document encoder, context encoder, and a ranking module that leverages both local and global contextual information. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in ranking performance and contextual awareness compared to state-of-the-art CAIR methods.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gestural interface design framework, 'EasyGest', that caters to older adults with cognitive impairments. EasyGest incorporates a participatory design approach, involving older adults in the design process to identify intuitive and accessible gestures. We conducted a user study with 20 older adults and found that EasyGest outperforms existing gestural interfaces in terms of task completion time and user satisfaction. Our results also highlight the importance of considering cognitive load and motor abilities when designing gestural interfaces for this population.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Learning-based Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on handcrafted rules or simple statistical models. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DLQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to generate contextualized query expansions. Our method incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to weigh the importance of expansion terms and a reinforcement learning framework to optimize the retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DLQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score.

title: Deep Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Task-Aware Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, requiring models to adapt quickly to new tasks with limited data. This paper proposes a novel deep meta-learning approach, 'TaskEMB', which learns task-aware embeddings that capture the essence of each task. Our framework consists of a meta-learner that generates task-specific weights, and a task-encoder that produces embeddings based on the task description. We evaluate TaskEMB on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance and demonstrating its ability to generalize to unseen tasks. Furthermore, we analyze the learned embeddings, revealing insights into the task structure and relationships.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Graph Attention Networks for Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has gained popularity in recommendation systems due to its ability to incorporate semantic relationships between entities. However, existing KGE methods often suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network-based KGE approach, called GraphAtt-KGE, which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant graph neighborhoods and reduce computational overhead. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate that GraphAtt-KGE achieves state-of-the-art performance in recommendation tasks while reducing computational time by up to 60% compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their accessibility for visually impaired users remains limited. This paper presents a novel design framework, 'TalkToMe', which integrates audio-based interaction, tactile feedback, and machine learning-driven dialogue management to facilitate inclusive human-computer interaction. We conducted a user study with 20 visually impaired participants, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rate, user satisfaction, and perceived accessibility compared to commercial virtual assistants. Our findings inform the development of more accessible conversational interfaces and provide insights for future research in this area.

title: Efficient Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large volumes of data and provide high availability. However, query optimization in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization that exploits the inherent parallelism in distributed databases. We introduce a dynamic query rewriting technique that leverages statistical models to predict query execution times and adapt to changing workloads. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate significant improvements in query execution times and resource utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems rely on knowledge graphs (KGs) to provide transparency into their decision-making processes. However, existing KG embedding methods suffer from scalability issues and limited interpretability. This paper introduces 'ExplainKG', a novel framework that leverages graph attention networks and sparse linear layers to learn efficient and interpretable KG embeddings. We evaluate ExplainKG on three real-world datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and explainability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and Feedback Strategies
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by speech recognition errors and inadequate feedback mechanisms. This study investigates the impact of speech recognition accuracy and feedback strategies on the user experience of older adults interacting with voice assistants. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65-85, employing a mixed-methods approach to evaluate the effects of error rates and feedback types on user satisfaction, trust, and task completion. Our results show that personalized feedback strategies, such as semantic error correction and explicit error acknowledgment, significantly improve user experience and reduce frustration. We provide design recommendations for inclusive voice assistants tailored to the needs of older adults.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to accurately capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'EmbedExpan', which leverages neural embeddings to model semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. By incorporating a self-attention mechanism, EmbedExpan adaptively weights the importance of expansion terms based on their contextual relevance, resulting in improved retrieval performance. Experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant gains in mean average precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art expansion techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Multimodal Interaction for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their interaction modalities often exclude users with disabilities. This paper presents a multimodal interaction framework for voice assistants that incorporates alternative input methods, such as gesture recognition, eye-tracking, and tactile feedback. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with varying abilities, revealing significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction. Our findings inform the design of more inclusive voice assistants, highlighting the importance of considering diverse user needs in HCI research.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems struggle to retrieve relevant documents when users submit ambiguous or incomplete queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to automatically generate effective expansion terms. Our model learns to balance the trade-off between query drift and relevance by interacting with a simulated search environment. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Task Learning in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning (MTL) has become a cornerstone of computer vision, enabling models to jointly learn multiple tasks and improve overall performance. However, existing MTL approaches suffer from scalability issues, particularly when dealing with large-scale datasets and numerous tasks. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that efficiently learns task relationships and selectively attends to relevant features for each task. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, including Cityscapes and NYUv2, while requiring significantly fewer computational resources. We also provide theoretical insights into the learnability of HANs and their advantages over flat attention mechanisms.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gestural Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: The proliferation of gestural interfaces has transformed the way people interact with technology. However, individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers when using these systems. This study investigates the usability and accessibility of a novel gestural interface, 'Easy Gesture', designed specifically for individuals with motor impairments. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that Easy Gesture significantly reduced error rates and improved user satisfaction compared to existing commercial systems. Our results demonstrate the potential of tailored gestural interfaces to enhance the overall user experience for individuals with motor impairments.
