title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Label Classification with Limited Annotations
paper_abstract: Multi-label classification is a fundamental problem in machine learning, where a single instance can be associated with multiple labels. However, annotating large datasets with multiple labels can be time-consuming and expensive. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that selectively focuses on relevant labels and instances, reducing the annotation burden. Our approach leverages label correlations and instance relationships to learn a hierarchical representation, enabling efficient learning from limited annotations. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and annotation efficiency.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments, but current systems often fall short in terms of usability and accessibility. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to developing voice assistants that accommodate the needs of this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers to identify key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our findings inform the design of a novel voice assistant system, 'ElderVoice', which incorporates features such as simplified language processing, personalized feedback, and multimodal input. A pilot study with 20 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Industrial Settings
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly enter industrial workplaces, understanding human-robot collaboration (HRC) is crucial for efficient and safe task execution. This paper explores the role of embodiment in HRC, examining how robots' physical presence and gestural cues influence human trust, workload, and task performance. We conduct a user study with 30 participants, comparing a robot with a humanoid upper body to a screen-based interface. Our results show that the embodied robot enhances user experience and performance, particularly in tasks requiring precise object manipulation. We discuss implications for designing effective HRC systems and provide recommendations for future research.

title: Learning to Rank with Hierarchical Attention for Explainable Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Explainable document retrieval is crucial for building trust in search engines. This paper proposes a novel learning-to-rank framework, 'HierAtt', which incorporates hierarchical attention mechanisms to model document relevance. Our approach leverages both local and global context to identify relevant passages and sentences within documents, enabling more interpretable ranking decisions. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HierAtt outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models while providing insightful attention weights for explainability.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing complex relationships between data entities. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to select optimal query plans based on a reward function that balances query latency and resource utilization. Experimental results on a large-scale graph database benchmark demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of resource efficiency.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-time Strategic Decision-making in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require real-time decision-making capabilities to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'StratAvail', that enables strategic decision-making in autonomous vehicles. We integrate a graph neural network with a multi-agent Q-learning approach to model dynamic interactions between vehicles and the environment. Experimental results demonstrate that StratAvail outperforms existing methods in real-world scenarios, achieving improved safety, efficiency, and adaptability. Our approach has significant implications for the deployment of autonomous vehicles in real-world settings.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation for heterogeneous multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'HeteroRL', which enables agents to learn optimal task assignments based on their individual capabilities and preferences. HeteroRL leverages a combination of Deep Q-Networks and Graph Convolutional Networks to capture complex agent-agent and agent-task interactions. Experimental results on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios demonstrate that HeteroRL outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion efficiency and robustness to agent failures.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Few-shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification is a challenging task in graph-structured data, where only a few labeled nodes are available for training. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that leverages both node and graph-level attention mechanisms to learn robust representations. Our approach adapts to new graphs and nodes by employing a meta-learning framework, which enables fast adaptation to new tasks with limited labeled data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in few-shot node classification, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by a significant margin.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval using BERT-based Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents given a user query. In this paper, we propose a neural query expansion approach that leverages BERT-based document embeddings to improve retrieval performance. Our method, NQE-BERT, uses a query-document interaction model to generate expansion terms, which are then weighted using a learned scoring function. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset show that NQE-BERT outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Skyline Query Processing on Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Skyline queries are crucial in decision-making applications, but their processing remains a challenge in distributed databases. This paper presents a novel approach, 'Distributed Skyline Processing' (DSP), which leverages a hierarchical clustering-based indexing technique to efficiently prune the search space. DSP exploits the parallelism of distributed systems by assigning clusters to nodes based on data locality and query-pattern analysis. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DSP outperforms existing methods by up to 3x in terms of response time and reduces network communication by 40%.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that affects the overall performance and efficiency of the system. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task allocation framework that utilizes reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments. Our approach employs a two-level hierarchy, where high-level agents allocate tasks to low-level agents based on their capabilities and availability. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through simulations on a disaster response scenario, showing significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their usability and accessibility for older adults remain a concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop an inclusive voice assistant, focusing on speech recognition and dialogue management. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, exploring their communication patterns, speech characteristics, and preferences for voice interactions. Our findings inform the design of a novel dialogue management framework that accommodates age-related speech difficulties, incorporates empathy and feedback mechanisms, and prioritizes transparency and control. We evaluated our prototype with 20 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Task-Oriented Dialogue Management for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective dialogue management is crucial for task-oriented communication. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'RL-Dialogue', that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize dialogue policies for multiple agents. Our approach utilizes a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture, comprising a high-level task manager and low-level dialogue generators, to adaptively generate responses that balance task progress with dialogue coherence. Experimental results show that RL-Dialogue outperforms traditional rule-based and supervised learning approaches in terms of task completion rate and dialogue fluency.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed NoSQL Databases with Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: As NoSQL databases continue to grow in popularity, optimizing query performance becomes increasingly critical. This paper presents 'AdaptIx', a novel indexing framework designed for distributed NoSQL databases. AdaptIx dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query patterns, data distribution, and system workload, resulting in improved query response times and reduced resource utilization. Our evaluation on a large-scale Apache Cassandra cluster demonstrates that AdaptIx outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 35% in query latency and 27% in resource usage.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents are increasingly being used in various applications, such as robotics, drones, and smart homes. One of the key challenges in multi-agent systems is task allocation, where agents need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a distributed task allocation framework using reinforcement learning, which enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing environments. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through simulations and real-world experiments, showing significant improvements in task completion time and agent utilization.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized approach for coalition formation in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. Our method, called Decentralized Coalition Optimization (DCO), enables agents to learn cooperative policies in a distributed manner without relying on a centralized controller. We employ a hierarchical framework consisting of a high-level coalition formation module and a low-level task allocation module. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that DCO achieves significant improvements in coalition stability and task efficiency compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Co-Designing Augmented Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technology has the potential to support older adults with cognitive impairments in their daily lives. However, designing effective AR interfaces for this population requires a deep understanding of their needs and abilities. This paper presents a co-design approach that involves older adults with cognitive impairments as active participants in the design process. We conducted a series of workshops and usability studies to identify key design principles and features that support cognitive accessibility in AR interfaces. Our findings highlight the importance of simplicity, consistency, and multimodal feedback in AR design, and demonstrate the feasibility of co-designing AR interfaces with older adults.

title: Efficient Indexing and Query Optimization for Temporal Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have gained significant attention in recent years due to their ability to model complex relationships between entities across time. However, efficient querying and indexing of such databases remain challenging tasks. This paper proposes a novel indexing scheme, 'TempoIndex', which leverages a combination of timestamp-based partitioning and graph-based clustering to accelerate query execution. We also present a query optimization framework that rewrites temporal graph queries to minimize the number of index lookups. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that TempoIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query response times.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Agents for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have the potential to improve the daily lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but their design often neglects the unique needs of this population. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing accessible conversational agents, focusing on simplicity, clarity, and error tolerance. We conducted a series of usability studies with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments, identifying key design recommendations for agent dialogue, visual feedback, and error handling. Our findings inform the development of more accessible and effective conversational agents, enabling older adults to engage in meaningful interactions and maintain their independence.

title: Hybrid Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning via Symbolic Model Extraction
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) models have achieved impressive results in complex decision-making tasks, but their opacity hinders trust and interpretability. We propose a novel hybrid explainability approach, 'SymExplain', which combines the strengths of symbolic model extraction and attention-based attribution methods. SymExplain extracts a symbolic representation of the DRL policy, enabling the identification of causal relationships between state features and actions. Our experiments on Atari games and a real-world robotics task demonstrate that SymExplain outperforms existing explainability methods in terms of accuracy and fidelity, providing actionable insights for DRL model improvement.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their effectiveness for older adults with cognitive impairments is hindered by limitations in speech recognition, dialogue flow, and overall usability. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'EASE', a novel voice interface specifically tailored to the needs of this population. EASE incorporates a cognitive load-aware dialogue manager, adaptive speech recognition thresholds, and personalized feedback mechanisms to facilitate successful interactions. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates, user satisfaction, and perceived cognitive load compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Enhancing Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Query Expansion and Neural Ranking
paper_abstract: Query expansion and neural ranking have been shown to improve document retrieval performance, but existing approaches often rely on simple keyword-based expansion or vanilla neural architectures. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'HierarchicalQE', which integrates hierarchical query expansion with a neural ranking model. Our approach leverages entity disambiguation and semantic role labeling to generate a hierarchical representation of the query, which is then used to expand the query terms. The expanded query is fed into a neural ranking model that incorporates contextualized embeddings and attention mechanisms. Experiments on the TREC-8 and rob04 datasets demonstrate that HierarchicalQE outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for People with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance the quality of life for people with motor impairments. However, existing systems often fail to account for the variability and inconsistency in gestures exhibited by individuals with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel adaptive gesture recognition system that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to recognize and adapt to the unique gesture patterns of individuals with motor impairments. Our system incorporates a personalized gesture modeling approach that updates the recognition model based on user feedback, enabling accurate recognition of gestures despite variations in speed, orientation, and movement quality. We evaluate our system with a group of participants with motor impairments and demonstrate significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has tremendous potential for immersive experiences, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalized avatars on user engagement in VR environments. We designed an experiment with 120 participants, randomly assigning them to either a personalized avatar group or a generic avatar group. Our results show that users with personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of engagement, measured through self-reported surveys and behavioral metrics such as time spent in the VR environment. We also found that personalized avatars increased users' sense of presence and embodiment in the virtual environment. The implications of these findings are discussed in the context of future VR applications.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers when interacting with gestural interfaces. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible gestural interfaces that accommodate a wide range of motor abilities. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with varying levels of motor impairment, and identified key design principles for reducing error rates and improving user experience. Our proposed interface, 'AccessibleGest', incorporates machine learning-based gesture recognition and real-time feedback mechanisms to facilitate more accurate and efficient interactions. Results show that AccessibleGest outperforms existing interfaces in terms of user satisfaction and task completion rates.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinated task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and constraints need to work together to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'HTA-RL', that learns to allocate tasks to agents based on their individual characteristics and the task requirements. Our approach leverages a graph neural network to model the agent-task interactions and a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture to optimize the allocation policy. Experimental results on a variety of scenarios demonstrate that HTA-RL outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and system adaptability.

title: Efficient Maintenance of Materialized Views in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Materialized views (MVs) are a crucial optimization technique in distributed database systems, as they enable fast query execution by pre-computing and storing intermediate results. However, maintaining MVs in the presence of frequent data updates is a challenging task. This paper presents a novel approach, called 'DynViews', which leverages incremental view maintenance and adaptive sampling to minimize the overhead of MV updates. Our experimental evaluation on a distributed database system demonstrates that DynViews reduces maintenance costs by up to 70% compared to traditional recomputation-based approaches, while ensuring data freshness and consistency.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in enhancing learning outcomes, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in VR-based learning environments. We designed an experiment involving 120 participants, who interacted with a VR-based educational platform using either a generic or personalized avatar. Results indicate that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, motivation, and self-efficacy, particularly among learners with lower prior experience with VR. We discuss implications for VR-based learning and provide recommendations for designing effective personalized avatars.

title: Multi-Modal Attention Fusion for Explainable Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models have achieved impressive performance, but their lack of transparency hinders their adoption in real-world applications. We propose a novel multi-modal attention fusion framework, 'MMAF', which integrates visual, linguistic, and spatial attention mechanisms to generate interpretable explanations for VQA models. MMAF leverages a hierarchical graph-based architecture to capture complex relationships between visual objects, question keywords, and spatial contexts. Our experiments on the VQA-X dataset demonstrate that MMAF improves both VQA accuracy and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art models, while providing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in Information Retrieval (IR) due to the inherent complexity of natural language queries. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) and deep neural networks. Our proposed model, 'HierExpan', learns to generate effective query expansions by exploring a hierarchical action space, where the agent selects relevant terms and phrases to add to the original query. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and Robust04 datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for short and ambiguous queries, outperforming state-of-the-art expansion methods.

title: Exploring Hierarchical Attention for Explainable Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition (MER) systems struggle to provide interpretable insights into their decision-making processes. We propose a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HierAttnMER', which leverages visual, acoustic, and linguistic cues to recognize emotions in videos. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant features and modalities, enabling more accurate and explainable MER. Experiments on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that HierAttnMER outperforms state-of-the-art MER models while providing saliency maps that highlight the most influential features for emotion recognition.

title: Hierarchical Attention Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the heterogeneity of modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Neural Network (HANN) architecture that leverages the strengths of each modality and captures intricate relationships between them. Our model uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant features and modalities, outperforming state-of-the-art methods on the CMU-MOSEI and IEMOCAP datasets. Experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of HANN in recognizing emotions from diverse modalities, with potential applications in affective computing and human-computer interaction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Neural Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a critical task in various domains, but existing methods often lack interpretability. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Neural Network (HANN) that detects anomalies while providing explanations. HANN uses a hierarchical structure to capture multi-scale patterns and an attention mechanism to highlight relevant features. We evaluate HANN on several real-world datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and explainability. Additionally, we introduce a novel visualization technique to illustrate the attention weights, enabling users to understand the decision-making process.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Multi-Modal Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, MultiModalRank, designed for efficient multi-modal retrieval in information retrieval systems. By leveraging a hierarchical attention mechanism and a knowledge distillation approach, MultiModalRank effectively fuses textual and visual features to improve retrieval accuracy. Experiment results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that MultiModalRank outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Deep Learning-based Query Expansion for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it aims to bridge the vocabulary gap between user queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach to query expansion, dubbed 'DeepQE', which leverages a encoder-decoder architecture to generate expanded query representations. Our approach not only outperforms traditional query expansion methods but also reduces the computational overhead associated with filtering large document collections. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that DeepQE achieves significant improvements in precision and recall, especially for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is crucial for achieving common goals. However, in real-world scenarios, agents often possess incomplete information about each other's capabilities, preferences, or intentions. This paper proposes a decentralized coalition formation framework that addresses this challenge by integrating belief revision and probabilistic planning. Our approach enables agents to iteratively refine their beliefs about other agents and adapt their coalition strategies accordingly. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our framework outperforms existing methods in terms of coalition stability and overall system performance.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: The rise of Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms has led to a surge in multi-tenancy, where multiple clients share the same database instance. However, this sharing can result in performance degradation and increased latency due to resource contention. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MTQO', designed specifically for multi-tenant DBaaS platforms. MTQO leverages machine learning-based prediction models to identify performance-critical queries and dynamically adjusts resource allocation to minimize latency and improve overall system throughput. Experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform show that MTQO achieves an average query latency reduction of 35% compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of ad-hoc retrieval systems, yet its effectiveness is often limited by the quality of the expansion terms. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'RL-QE', which learns to select optimal expansion terms by maximizing a reward function that balances retrieval effectiveness and query drift. We employ a hierarchical attention mechanism to model the complex relationships between the query, documents, and candidate terms. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that RL-QE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We model the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and design a reinforcement learning algorithm that learns to select optimal query plans based on graph statistics and query patterns. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval with Query-Document Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'QRIM', that incorporates query-document interaction into the ranking process for ad-hoc retrieval tasks. QRIM uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture complex contextual relationships between query terms and document passages. We demonstrate that QRIM outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models on several benchmarks, including the TREC CAR dataset. Furthermore, we show that QRIM's query-document interaction module improves the model's ability to generalize to unseen queries and documents.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Specialized Domains
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, particularly in specialized domains where terminology is nuanced. This paper proposes a novel neural embedding-based approach, 'DomainEmb', which learns to represent domain-specific keywords and phrases in a dense vector space. By leveraging these embeddings, our method generates high-quality expansion terms that capture subtle semantic relationships, leading to significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on a large-scale biomedical dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of DomainEmb in retrieving relevant documents, outperforming traditional lexical-based and knowledge graph-based expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Supervised Neural Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short queries and scarce relevance feedback. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages supervised neural document embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. Our model, dubbed 'QNDE', is trained on a large dataset of annotated query-document pairs and learns to project queries and documents into a shared latent space. Experimental results on several TREC benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional pseudo-relevance feedback and word embedding-based methods.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper presents a novel approach based on distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to allocate tasks to agents in a cooperative manner. We propose a hierarchical DCOP framework that leverages the agents' local problem-solving capabilities to reduce the communication overhead and improve the overall system performance. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving better task allocation quality and adaptability to dynamic environments compared to traditional centralized methods.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Conventional document retrieval systems rely on handcrafted ranking models or supervised learning approaches, which often struggle to generalize to diverse query types and document collections. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'DocHRL', that learns to optimize document retrieval by modeling the search process as a Markov decision process. Our approach leverages a hierarchical policy that adaptively selects the most relevant documents at each level of the retrieval process, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of DocHRL over state-of-the-art retrieval models.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize learning experiences, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the role of haptic feedback in enhancing user engagement in VR-based learning environments. We designed an experimental study with 120 participants, who completed a series of learning tasks in a VR environment with and without haptic feedback. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly increases user engagement, measured through self-reported satisfaction, time spent on tasks, and physiological responses. We also identify key factors influencing the effectiveness of haptic feedback, including task complexity and individual differences in haptic perception. The findings have implications for the design of immersive learning systems that incorporate haptic feedback to promote user engagement and learning outcomes.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but its adoption is hindered by the lack of accessible interfaces for users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel VR interface designed to facilitate navigation and interaction for visually impaired users. We employ a multimodal approach, combining audio, tactile, and gestural feedback to provide an immersive experience. Our user study involving 20 visually impaired participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to existing VR systems. We also discuss design implications and future directions for inclusive VR design.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Cold Start Problem in Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Cold start problem in recommendation systems hinders the performance of collaborative filtering-based models. This paper proposes a hybrid retrieval model that combines the strengths of content-based filtering and collaborative filtering to tackle the cold start problem. The proposed model uses a neural network-based retrieval module to generate item embeddings and a matrix factorization-based ranking module to generate personalized rankings. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of precision, recall, and A/B testing metrics.

title: EyeGazeType: A Gaze-Driven Typing Interface for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges when interacting with computers. Eye-tracking technology offers a promising solution, but existing gaze-driven interfaces often suffer from low typing speeds and high error rates. This paper presents EyeGazeType, a novel interface that leverages machine learning-based gaze prediction and adaptive dwell-time algorithms to enable efficient typing. Our user study with 20 participants with motor impairments shows that EyeGazeType achieves an average typing speed of 15.2 words per minute with an accuracy of 92.5%, outperforming existing state-of-the-art gaze-driven interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics in distributed database systems require efficient query optimization to meet stringent latency and throughput requirements. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'DynaOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and dynamic re-optimization to adapt to changing workload conditions. We introduce a hybrid approach that combines traditional rule-based optimization with neural network-based cost modeling, achieving an average improvement of 35% in query response time compared to state-of-the-art optimizers. Experiments on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate the effectiveness of DynaOpt in handling complex analytical queries.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in recent years, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach to query optimization, which leverages graph theory to model query plans and identify efficient execution paths. Our method, called GraphOpt, uses a combination of graph clustering and shortest path algorithms to reduce the search space of possible query plans. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that GraphOpt outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, vision, text) is a challenging task that requires robust fusion and interpretation of heterogeneous features. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages self-attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. We demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art multi-modal fusion methods on two benchmark datasets, achieving improved emotion recognition accuracy and providing interpretable attention weights that reveal the most salient input features. Our approach has implications for affective computing, human-computer interaction, and AI-driven decision-making.

title: Designing Adaptive Haptic Feedback for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) systems often lack realistic haptic feedback, limiting user immersion and interaction. This paper presents a novel approach to adaptive haptic feedback design, which incorporates real-time user behavior analysis and machine learning-based feedback optimization. Our system, 'HapticAdapt', uses a combination of sensor data and user feedback to dynamically adjust the intensity and frequency of haptic stimuli, enhancing user experience and task performance. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional fixed-haptic feedback methods.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for efficient traffic management in autonomous vehicles. We propose a novel algorithm, 'Traffic Harmony', which enables agents to learn from their local observations and interactions with neighboring agents to optimize traffic flow. Our approach integrates graph neural networks with deep Q-learning to learn complex traffic patterns and adapt to changing road conditions. Experimental results in a simulated environment demonstrate significant reductions in travel time and congestion compared to traditional traffic management systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Fusion in Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years. However, most existing ERS methods rely on shallow feature interactions and fail to capture complex relationships between user and item attributes. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) model that integrates multi-modal data (e.g., text, images, and ratings) to provide personalized explanations for recommendations. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to learn hierarchical representations of user and item entities, enabling the model to capture both local and global patterns in the data. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for document retrieval often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking architecture, 'HNRM', which leverages a coarse-to-fine retrieval strategy to reduce the number of documents required for ranking. We employ a combination of dense passage retrieval and hierarchical clustering to prune the document set, followed by a fine-grained ranking module that incorporates semantic and syntactic features. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate that HNRM achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness compared to existing neural ranking models.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, but existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages hierarchical graph representations to reduce the computational cost while maintaining high accuracy. HGAT uses a multi-scale attention mechanism to aggregate features from neighboring nodes at different hierarchical levels, allowing it to capture both local and global graph structures. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Edge Computing Environments
paper_abstract: Edge computing has emerged as a promising paradigm for reducing latency and improving performance in IoT and real-time applications. However, resource allocation in edge environments remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a decentralized agent-based framework, 'EdgeAgent', which leverages autonomous agents to allocate resources dynamically based on real-time demand and availability. We introduce a novel multi-agent negotiation protocol that enables agents to coordinate and optimize resource allocation, resulting in improved system utilization and reduced latency. Experimental results on a simulated edge computing platform demonstrate the effectiveness of EdgeAgent in adapting to changing workload conditions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multi-modal sentiment analysis has become increasingly important in various applications, such as customer feedback analysis and social media monitoring. However, existing approaches often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that effectively integrates visual, textual, and acoustic features for efficient multi-modal sentiment analysis. The proposed HAN model leverages attention mechanisms at both local and global levels to selectively focus on salient features and modalities, reducing the computational overhead while improving sentiment prediction accuracy. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of our approach over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatar Customization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized the way we interact with digital information. However, user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the effect of personalized avatar customization on user experience in VR environments. We designed an experiment with 120 participants, randomly assigning them to either a customized avatar group or a standard avatar group. Our results show that participants in the customized avatar group exhibited increased engagement, measured by time spent in the VR environment and self-reported enjoyment. We also found that users with high levels of avatar identification reported higher feelings of presence and immersion. Our findings have implications for the design of VR systems, suggesting that personalized avatars can enhance user engagement and overall VR experience.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often rely on query expansion techniques to improve retrieval performance. However, existing methods suffer from issues such as query drift and term mismatch. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DocEmbQE', which leverages document embeddings to generate query expansions. Our method learns a dense representation of documents and uses this to identify relevant terms for expansion. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DocEmbQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases pose significant query optimization challenges due to varying data distributions, network latencies, and workload dynamics. This paper presents 'RL-QOpt', a novel adaptive query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed settings. RL-QOpt uses a deep Q-network to learn from query execution feedback, adapt to changing database conditions, and improve query performance. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database show that RL-QOpt outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in query latency and 25% in resource utilization.

title: Efficient Anomaly Detection in High-Dimensional Data Streams using Online Isolation Forest
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in high-dimensional data streams is a challenging task due to the curse of dimensionality and concept drift. This paper proposes an online isolation forest algorithm, 'OiF', which leverages the strengths of isolation forest and online learning. OiF adaptively updates the isolation forest model as new data arrives, using a novel incremental learning strategy that balances model accuracy and computational efficiency. Our experiments on several real-world datasets demonstrate that OiF outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy, speed, and memory usage.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Enhancing Retrieval Effectiveness in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to the limitations of the initial query. This paper proposes a query-driven document expansion approach, which leverages the query context to identify and incorporate relevant terms from the top-retrieved documents. Our method, QEDE, iteratively refines the query representation by incorporating contextualized embeddings and feedback-based term weighting. Experimental results on the TREC-8 Ad-Hoc dataset demonstrate that QEDE significantly improves retrieval effectiveness, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision compared to state-of-the-art baseline models.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Learning Models via Input Gradient Regularization
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which compromise their reliability in safety-critical applications. We propose a novel regularization technique, Input Gradient Regularization (IGR), to enhance the robustness of deep learning models against adversarial perturbations. IGR leverages the input gradient information to penalize the model's sensitivity to perturbations, thereby promoting robust feature learning. We conduct extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets and demonstrate that IGR outperforms state-of-the-art adversarial training methods in terms of robustness and accuracy. Our approach provides a promising direction for developing robust deep learning models.

title: Autonomous Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous negotiation strategies for multi-agent systems in dynamic environments. We propose a hybrid framework that combines machine learning and game-theoretic techniques to enable agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and negotiate with each other effectively. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated smart grid scenario, where agents representing households and energy providers negotiate energy trading prices and quantities. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms traditional negotiation strategies in terms of social welfare, fairness, and convergence time.

title: Context-Aware Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval models often neglect the rich contextual information present in queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach, Hierarchical Context Encoder (HCE), which leverages graph neural networks to capture complex relationships between entities, keywords, and semantic concepts. HCE hierarchically represents queries and documents as graphs, and learns to encode contextual information through a novel attention mechanism. Experimental results on the TREC news dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and relevance over state-of-the-art baseline models.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Unsupervised Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Unsupervised anomaly detection is a crucial task in various applications, but existing methods often struggle with high-dimensional data and limited computational resources. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical contrastive learning approach, 'HCLAD', which leverages a multi-scale representation learning framework to identify anomalies in an efficient and effective manner. By incorporating a hierarchical clustering module and a contrastive loss function, HCLAD learns to encode robust and discriminative features that distinguish anomalies from normal patterns. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HCLAD over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines face significant challenges in retrieving relevant documents from large-scale, heterogeneous collections. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of both local and global context to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of document retrieval. Our approach integrates a hierarchical document representation with attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant segments and passages. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HAN achieves substantial improvements in retrieval performance and latency reduction compared to existing state-of-the-art models.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalization for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their one-size-fits-all design often falls short for users with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive voice assistants that cater to individual needs. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants with disabilities, exploring their experiences and preferences for personalized voice assistant interactions. Our findings highlight the importance of adaptive speech recognition, customizable feedback modalities, and accessible tutorials. We propose a novel framework for inclusive voice assistant design, incorporating user profiling, adaptive feedback, and multimodal interaction. The implications of our work have significant potential for promoting digital accessibility and independence for users with disabilities.

title: EmoReact: Affective State Recognition using Multimodal Fusion of Facial Expression, Speech, and Physiological Signals
paper_abstract: Accurate recognition of human affective states is crucial for developing empathetic human-computer interfaces. This paper presents EmoReact, a multimodal framework that combines facial expression, speech, and physiological signal processing to recognize emotions in real-time. We propose a novel deep learning architecture that fuses the outputs of multiple modalities using a hierarchical attention mechanism, achieving improved recognition accuracy and robustness. Our evaluation on a publicly available dataset demonstrates EmoReact's superiority over state-of-the-art unimodal and multimodal approaches, with an average F1-score of 0.92 across seven emotions.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize assistive technology, but existing VR systems often overlook the needs of users with visual impairments. This paper presents 'AccessibleVR', a novel framework for designing and evaluating VR experiences that are inclusive of visually impaired users. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key usability challenges and developed a set of guidelines for accessible VR interaction design. Our evaluation shows thatAccessibleVR significantly improves user experience and task performance for visually impaired users, highlighting the importance of inclusive design in VR development.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Efficient task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and constraints need to cooperate to achieve complex goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize agent assignments. Our approach, called 'DRL-TA', uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn agent policies that adapt to dynamic task requirements and environmental changes. Experimental results on a simulated robotics domain demonstrate that DRL-TA outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency.

title: Adversarial Training with Hierarchical Graph Attention for Robust Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-based machine learning, but existing methods are vulnerable to adversarial attacks. This paper presents a novel approach to robust node classification, incorporating hierarchical graph attention and adversarial training. We propose a graph attention mechanism that captures hierarchical relationships between nodes and a robust loss function that accounts for adversarial perturbations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving node classification accuracy under adversarial attacks.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification in Dynamic Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in dynamic graphs is a challenging task due to the constantly changing graph structure and node features. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) framework that captures both local and global graph structural information. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant nodes and their features at different scales, enabling more accurate node classification. Experimental results on several real-world dynamic graph datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in improving node classification performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but its adoption is hindered by accessibility barriers for users with disabilities. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for designing inclusive VR interfaces, focusing on users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. We develop a set of guidelines and recommendations based on a mixed-methods approach, combining user studies, expert interviews, and usability testing. Our results demonstrate significant improvements in user experience and task performance for users with disabilities, highlighting the importance of inclusive design in VR development.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Reinforcement Learning using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its performance heavily relies on careful hyperparameter tuning. This process is often time-consuming and computationally expensive, particularly when dealing with high-dimensional search spaces. We propose a novel Bayesian optimization method, 'BO-DRL', which leverages a probabilistic surrogate model to efficiently search for optimal hyperparameters. Our approach incorporates a customized acquisition function that balances exploration and exploitation, and we demonstrate its effectiveness on several benchmark DRL tasks. Experimental results show that BO-DRL significantly outperforms traditional grid search and random search methods, achieving comparable performance to state-of-the-art techniques at a fraction of the computational cost.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Databases using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, optimizing query performance in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing technique, 'DynaIndex', which dynamically adjusts the index structure based on query patterns and data distribution. Our approach leverages machine learning algorithms to predict query loads and optimize index maintenance, resulting in significant performance improvements. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database setup demonstrate that DynaIndex outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of deep reinforcement learning to coordinate multi-agent systems in complex, dynamic environments. We propose a novel architecture, 'MARL-COM', which combines a centralized critic with decentralized actor networks to learn effective coordination policies. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to focus on relevant agents and incorporates curriculum learning to adapt to changing task requirements. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate improved coordination efficiency and scalability compared to traditional decentralized MARL methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-modal AI Decision-Making
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of AI systems in high-stakes applications has highlighted the need for transparency and interpretability. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that facilitates explainable decision-making in multi-modal AI systems. Our HAN model integrates attention mechanisms across different modalities (vision, language, and sensors) to identify relevant features and relationships that contribute to the AI's decision. We evaluate our approach on a real-world autonomous driving dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in model interpretability while maintaining state-of-the-art performance.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in E-Commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines face the challenge of accurately retrieving relevant products from large catalogs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE-ECOM', which leverages the hierarchical structure of product categories to improve retrieval efficiency. HQE-ECOM adaptively selects expansion terms based on the query context and product correlations, reducing the search space and improving precision. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate a 25% increase in retrieval efficiency and a 15% improvement in precision compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, which aims to improve the retrieval performance by reformulating the original query. Traditional query expansion methods rely on statistical techniques, which may not capture the semantic relationships between query terms effectively. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks, which can learn to identify relevant expansion terms from a large corpus of text. Our approach, called 'NeuroExp', utilizes a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query term embeddings and expansion term selection. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroExp significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving an average improvement of 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Gradient-based Methods
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be crafted by adding imperceptible perturbations to the input data. In this paper, we investigate the robustness of deep neural networks against adversarial attacks using gradient-based methods. We propose a novel approach to analyze the robustness of neural networks by computing the gradient of the loss function with respect to the input data. Our approach provides a more accurate estimate of the robustness of neural networks compared to existing methods, and we demonstrate its effectiveness on several benchmark datasets. Furthermore, we show that our approach can be used to improve the robustness of neural networks by incorporating it into the training process.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Semantic Word Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it helps to disambiguate user queries and improve retrieval accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep semantic word embeddings to capture the nuanced relationships between words. Our method uses a convolutional neural network to learn a dense representation of words and their contexts, which are then used to generate expanded queries. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that our approach outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and reciprocal rank.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: As distributed database systems continue to grow in scale and complexity, query optimization has become a critical challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to select optimal query plans based on runtime statistics and system workload. Experiments on a real-world distributed database system show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization. We also demonstrate the adaptability of our approach to changing workload patterns and system configurations.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to coordinate task allocation among agents. Our method, called GraphCAT, represents the agent-task graph as a neural network and learns to optimize task assignments based on agent capabilities, task priorities, and graph structure. Experimental results on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios demonstrate that GraphCAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time, agent utilization, and overall system efficiency.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has made significant strides in recent years, but the importance of embodiment in VR experiences remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study examining the effects of embodied interaction on user experience in VR. We designed three VR scenarios with varying levels of embodiment, from low (controller-based) to high (full-body tracking), and collected both quantitative and qualitative data from 30 participants. Our results show that increased embodiment leads to higher user engagement, presence, and overall satisfaction, while also influencing users' emotional responses to virtual stimuli. The findings have implications for the design of future VR systems and applications.

title: Elastic Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Efficient Retrieval in High-Dimensional Spaces
paper_abstract: In modern information retrieval systems, the curse of dimensionality poses significant challenges for efficient document ranking. We propose a novel neural ranking model, ElasticRank, which leverages deep neural networks to learn a flexible, hierarchical representation of documents. By incorporating a carefully designed attention mechanism, ElasticRank adaptively focuses on relevant features in high-dimensional spaces, enabling accurate ranking with reduced computational cost. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of ElasticRank in improving retrieval efficiency while maintaining state-of-the-art ranking performance.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of data distribution and communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach for query optimization in distributed relational databases. We model the query plan as a graph and apply graph-based heuristics to minimize the communication cost and maximize parallelism. Experimental results on a realistic dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Dynamic IoT Environments
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has created a pressing need for efficient resource allocation mechanisms that can adapt to dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel autonomous agent-based approach, 'AARA', which leverages multi-agent systems to allocate resources in real-time. AARA agents employ a decentralized, self-organizing architecture that facilitates robust and scalable decision-making. We evaluate AARA using a simulated IoT testbed and demonstrate improved resource utilization, reduced latency, and enhanced system resilience compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must cooperate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel approach based on graph-based reinforcement learning, where agents learn to allocate tasks by interacting with a graph-structured environment. We introduce a decentralized policy gradient algorithm that allows agents to learn from local observations and communicate with their neighbors to achieve global optimality. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness and scalability of our approach compared to traditional centralized methods.

title: Secure Agent Coordination using Homomorphic Encryption and Multi-Party Computation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, secure coordination is crucial to prevent malicious attacks and maintain confidentiality. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'SecureAgent', which leverages homomorphic encryption and multi-party computation to enable secure coordination among agents. We design a protocol that allows agents to jointly compute a coordination plan while maintaining the secrecy of their individual inputs. Our evaluation on a real-world supply chain management scenario demonstrates that SecureAgent reduces the risk of collusion attacks by 95% compared to traditional encryption schemes, while incurring only a moderate overhead in computation time.

title: Investigating Gesture Recognition for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but current VR systems often exclude individuals with disabilities. This paper focuses on developing a gesture recognition system that enables users with motor impairments to interact with VR environments more effectively. We propose a novel deep learning architecture that leverages transfer learning and multi-modal fusion to recognize gestures from electromyography (EMG) and computer vision inputs. Our user study involving 20 participants with motor impairments demonstrates that our system achieves an average recognition accuracy of 92.5%, outperforming existing state-of-the-art approaches. Our work has significant implications for promoting inclusivity in VR and enhancing the overall user experience.

title: Efficient Document Representation using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Information retrieval (IR) systems rely on effective document representation to retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) for document representation, which captures both local and global contextual information. Our approach represents documents as graphs, utilizing node attention to selectively focus on relevant keywords and sentence-level attention to model contextual relationships. Experimental results on the TREC-COVID dataset demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, including BERT-based models, in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation in multi-agent systems using graph attention networks. The proposed method, 'GAT-Allocator', leverages the structural properties of the agent interaction graph to efficiently allocate tasks to agents while minimizing communication overhead. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GAT-Allocator in various simulated scenarios and show that it outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization. Theoretical analysis and experiments validate the scalability and robustness of our approach in real-world applications.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Large-Scale Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based tasks. However, their scalability is limited by the computational complexity of graph clustering. We propose a novel hierarchical clustering algorithm, 'HierGNN', which leverages a cascade of k-means clustering and graph coarsening to reduce the graph size. Our method achieves a significant speedup in GNN training while maintaining the clustering quality. We evaluate HierGNN on several large-scale graph datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving the efficiency of GNN-based graph classification and node embedding tasks.

title: Efficient Indexing for Scalable Neural Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for open-domain question answering. However, the efficiency of DPR systems is hindered by the need to compute dense embeddings for large Passage collections. This paper presents a novel indexing strategy, 'Neural Inverted Index' (NII), that leverages the structure of neural networks to accelerate passage retrieval. NII combines a hierarchical clustering of passages with a learned, sparse indexing scheme, reducing the number of required neural computations by up to 75%. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of NII, achieving a 30% improvement in retrieval efficiency while maintaining state-of-the-art accuracy.

title: Deep Hierarchical Clustering for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, but existing approaches often rely on uni-modal features, failing to capture the complexity of human emotions. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical clustering framework, 'EmoClus', which integrates multimodal features from speech, text, and facial expressions. We introduce a hierarchical clustering algorithm that iteratively refines emotion clusters, resulting in more accurate and nuanced recognition of emotions. Experiments on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate the superiority of EmoClus over state-of-the-art approaches, achieving an average emotion recognition accuracy of 85.2%.

title: Enhancing Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Current information retrieval (IR) models often struggle to capture nuanced semantic relationships between documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical contrastive learning framework, 'HiCoL', which leverages both local and global contextual information to improve retrieval performance. By integrating a contrastive objective into a hierarchical transformer architecture, HiCoL learns to distinguish between relevant and irrelevant documents at multiple granularities. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiCoL outperforms state-of-the-art IR models, particularly in scenarios involving ambiguous or multi-faceted queries.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. Our proposed framework, 'RL-MASTA', enables agents to learn optimal task assignments in real-time, adapting to dynamic changes in the environment and agent capabilities. We introduce a decentralized, asynchronous learning protocol that leverages sparse rewards and communication constraints to improve task allocation efficiency. Experimental results on a realistic logistics scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utilization compared to traditional auction-based approaches.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component of many information retrieval systems, but it can be computationally expensive, especially for large document collections. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical document representation scheme that enables efficient passage retrieval. Our approach represents each document as a hierarchical graph, where nodes correspond to passages, and edges capture semantic relationships between them. We propose a graph-based ranking model that leverages this representation to retrieve relevant passages. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Adaptive Social Network Analysis
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for coordinating multi-agent systems (MAS) using adaptive social network analysis. We leverage graph neural networks to model agent interactions and adaptively learn the social structure of the MAS. Our approach, called Adaptive Social Network-based Coordination (ASNC), enables agents to dynamically adjust their behavior based on the evolving social network.
