We evaluate ASNC in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved coordination and response times compared to traditional distributed coordination methods.

title: Neural Query Graph Generation for Efficient Document Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has emerged as a promising approach for open-domain question answering. However, the complexity of neural query graph construction hinders its efficiency. This paper proposes a novel neural query graph generation framework, 'NQG-Gen', which learns to generate query graphs from input questions. NQG-Gen leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively attend to relevant passages and iteratively refine the query graph. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that NQG-Gen achieves comparable retrieval performance to state-of-the-art DPR methods while reducing inference time by up to 30%.

title: Noise-Robust Deep Learning for Real-World Image Denoising
paper_abstract: Real-world image denoising remains a challenging task due to the complexity of noise patterns in camera-captured images. This paper introduces a novel noise-robust deep learning framework, 'NoiseShield', which combines a noise estimation module with a denoising network. Our approach leverages a large-scale dataset of real-world noisy images and incorporates a noise-aware loss function that adaptively weighs the importance of noise estimation during training. Experimental results demonstrate that NoiseShield outperforms state-of-the-art denoising methods on various benchmark datasets and real-world images, achieving improved visual quality and robustness to diverse noise types.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Reinforcement Learning and Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a challenging problem in AI research, requiring efficient decision-making and communication among agents. This paper presents a novel approach that combines reinforcement learning (RL) with graph neural networks (GNNs) to coordinate agent behavior. We propose a decentralized RL framework, where each agent learns to optimize its policy based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. The GNN is used to process the graph-structured data and learn effective message passing between agents. Experimental results on a traffic management scenario demonstrate improved coordination and reduced congestion compared to traditional RL methods.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: We present a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'GraphMA', which leverages graph attention networks to improve coordination and communication among agents in complex environments. By learning to focus on relevant graph structures, GraphMA reduces the curse of dimensionality and achieves faster convergence compared to existing methods. We evaluate our approach on a range of cooperative and competitive tasks, demonstrating improved performance and scalability in simulations of robotic swarm control and traffic management.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis is a crucial task in natural language processing, but existing approaches often struggle to capture complex relationships between text and visual modalities. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates multi-modal inputs and provides interpretable explanations for sentiment predictions. Our HAN model employs a coarse-to-fine attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant regions of images and sentences, allowing for more accurate sentiment classification. Experimental results on the Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis (MMSA) benchmark demonstrate the efficacy of our approach, with significant improvements in both performance and explainability.

title: Elastic Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a critical component of modern business intelligence. However, optimizing query performance in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'ElasticQ', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and statistical models to predict query execution times and dynamically adjust query plans. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group similar queries and a cost-based optimizer to select the most efficient execution strategy. Experimental results on a popular open-source data warehousing platform demonstrate that ElasticQ achieves up to 3x query performance improvement and reduces query latency by 40% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Indexing for Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has become a prominent approach in information retrieval, leveraging neural networks to encode documents and queries into dense vectors. However, indexing and searching these dense representations efficiently remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural indexing (HNI) method, which organizes documents into a hierarchical structure using a combination of clustering and dimensionality reduction techniques. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNI achieves significant speedup and storage reduction compared to existing indexing methods, while maintaining or improving retrieval performance.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems via Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating the actions of multiple agents to achieve a common goal is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model agent interactions and dependencies. By representing the agent network as a graph, our method can capture complex relationships between agents and tasks, and learn to allocate tasks that maximize system efficiency. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion rate and system adaptability.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Menus for Improving Interactions in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces often suffer from cluttered menus, leading to user frustration and decreased immersion. This paper presents 'GazeMenu', a novel gaze-based adaptive menu system that dynamically reorganizes menu items based on user attention and interaction patterns. We introduce a machine learning model that predicts user intent from gaze data and adapts menu layouts to reduce visual search time and improve selection accuracy. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates that GazeMenu significantly reduces menu interaction time and improves overall VR experience compared to traditional menu systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Interpretable Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal inputs (e.g., facial expressions, speech, and text) remains a challenging task, especially when it comes to model interpretability. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that captures both intra- and inter-modality relationships to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our approach incorporates a feature-wise attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and a hierarchical fusion strategy that aggregates features at multiple levels. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal emotion recognition methods while providing insightful attention visualizations for better model interpretability.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Social Presence in Virtual Reality Mediated Communication
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize remote communication by providing an immersive and interactive environment. However, the impact of embodiment on social presence in VR-mediated communication remains understudied. This paper presents an empirical study investigating the effects of embodied avatars on social presence, trust, and rapport-building in VR-mediated dyadic conversations. Our results show that participants in embodied conditions reported higher social presence and trust compared to non-embodied conditions, with significant implications for the design of VR-based communication systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Sparse Attention
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but they often suffer from the query mismatch problem. Query expansion techniques can alleviate this issue, but existing methods can be computationally expensive or require extensive domain knowledge. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'SparseQE', which leverages sparse attention mechanisms to selectively expand relevant terms. We show that SparseQE improves the retrieval performance of state-of-the-art neural models on several benchmark datasets while reducing the computational overhead. Furthermore, we provide an in-depth analysis of the attention patterns, revealing insights into the underlying retrieval mechanisms.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating accessible gestural interfaces for older adults with motor impairments. We conducted a participatory design study with 15 older adults with varying levels of motor impairment, resulting in the development of a gestural interface framework that incorporates compensatory strategies and adaptive feedback mechanisms. A usability evaluation of the framework with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing gesture-based systems. Our findings have implications for the design of inclusive and accessible interfaces for older adults with motor impairments.

title: Scalable and Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data and provide high availability. However, query optimization in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization technique, 'Distributed Query Rewriter' (DQR), which leverages machine learning and graph-based methods to optimize query plans in real-time. Our approach uses a hybrid cost model that incorporates both statistical and machine learning-based cost estimation techniques to accurately predict query execution times. Experimental results on a distributed database system show that DQR outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph Neural Networks and Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches suffer from scalability issues when dealing with large, heterogeneous graphs. This paper proposes a novel entity disambiguation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) and knowledge graph embeddings. Our approach, called 'GED-GNN', represents entities as graph-structured data and utilizes GNNs to learn entity representations that capture both local and global graph properties. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GED-GNN on two large-scale knowledge graphs, achieving state-of-the-art performance and significant scalability improvements over existing methods.

title: Efficient Ranking Model for Neural Search with Sparse Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search systems have gained popularity in recent years, but their performance is often bottlenecked by the computational cost of dense document embeddings. This paper proposes a novel ranking model, 'SparseRank', which leverages sparse document embeddings to reduce the dimensionality of the search space. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively selects relevant document features, resulting in improved retrieval efficiency without sacrificing ranking accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of SparseRank in reducing computational overhead while achieving state-of-the-art retrieval performance.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph-based Embeddings for Entities
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in Information Retrieval (IR) systems, as it enables users to retrieve relevant documents that may not contain the exact query terms. Traditional query expansion methods rely on term co-occurrence statistics or word embeddings, which may not capture complex relationships between entities. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GraphEntityExpand', which leverages hierarchical graph-based embeddings to model entities in a query. We demonstrate that GraphEntityExpand outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets, particularly for entity-centric queries.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition for Enhancing Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility for individuals with motor impairments. However, current gesture recognition systems often fail to accommodate diverse abilities and user preferences. This paper presents 'AdaptiGesture', a novel framework that leverages machine learning and user-centered design to create personalized, adaptive gesture recognition models for VR. Our approach incorporates multimodal sensor data and user feedback to iteratively refine gesture recognition, ensuring high accuracy and user satisfaction. A user study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and overall VR experience compared to existing systems.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Specialized Domains
paper_abstract: Document retrieval in specialized domains often requires nuanced understanding of domain-specific terminology and semantics. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach, 'DomainQE', which leverages domain-specific knowledge graphs to generate context-aware query expansions. Our approach incorporates a novel graph attention mechanism to selectively weigh and combine knowledge graph embeddings, resulting in more accurate and relevant document retrievals. Experiments on a large biomedical dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Indexing for Range Queries in Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: Column-oriented NoSQL databases have gained popularity for storing and querying large-scale data. However, supporting efficient range queries remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'CRex', which leverages the column-oriented storage layout to accelerate range queries. CRex employs a combination of bitmapped indexing and column-grouping to reduce the query search space. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that CRex outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 3x in query execution time, while maintaining a low storage overhead.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it significantly impacts the quality of search results. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks, which leverages the semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our model, 'NeuralQE', employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively emphasize relevant terms and passages in the document, resulting in more accurate and diverse query expansions. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate that NeuralQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score.

title: Hybrid Attention Mechanisms for Explainable Multimodal Fusion in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: As human-robot interaction (HRI) systems become increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for explainable multimodal fusion methods that can effectively integrate visual, auditory, and linguistic cues. This paper proposes a novel hybrid attention mechanism that combines the strengths of both spatial and channel attention to enable more accurate and interpretable fusion of multimodal inputs. We evaluate our approach on a real-world HRI dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in both performance and explainability compared to state-of-the-art fusion methods.

title: Robustness Evaluation of Deep Learning Models against Adversarial Attacks on Graph-Structured Data
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance on graph-structured data, but their robustness against adversarial attacks remains a concern. This paper proposes a novel evaluation framework, 'GraphAdv', to assess the robustness of graph neural networks (GNNs) against targeted attacks. We design a set of graph perturbation methods that simulate real-world attacks, such as node manipulation and edge rewiring. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphAdv can effectively identify vulnerabilities in popular GNN architectures, providing insights for improving their robustness. We also propose a simple yet effective defense mechanism based on graph attention, which enhances model robustness without sacrificing performance.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, especially when agents have diverse capabilities and tasks require collaborative efforts. This paper introduces a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'CATALYST', that enables agents to learn coordinated exploration strategies for efficient task allocation. Our approach combines graph neural networks with multi-agent Q-learning to facilitate information sharing and joint decision-making. Experimental results on a realistic disaster response scenario demonstrate that CATALYST outperforms traditional approaches in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Efficient Online Learning with Adaptive Regularization for Non-Stationary Environments
paper_abstract: Online learning algorithms often struggle with non-stationary environments, where the underlying data distribution changes over time. This paper proposes an adaptive regularization technique, 'AROS', which dynamically adjusts the regularization strength based on the observed data drift. We prove that AROS achieves a tighter regret bound compared to existing methods, and demonstrate its effectiveness in various online learning scenarios, including stock prediction and recommender systems. Our experiments show that AROS outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of both accuracy and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Hybrid Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: With the increasing complexity of modern information networks, traditional ranking models struggle to effectively retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a hybrid ranking model, 'HetRank', which integrates graph-based and learning-to-rank approaches to leverage the strengths of both. HetRank incorporates network embedding and graph attention mechanisms to capture structural relationships between documents and entities. Experimental results on a large-scale heterogeneous information network demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for cold-start and sparse data scenarios.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Short Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Short text retrieval is a challenging task due to the limited context and sparse term frequencies. Query expansion techniques can improve retrieval performance, but traditional methods often rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well. We propose a deep neural network-based approach, 'DQE-Net', which learns to expand queries by modeling semantic relationships between terms. Our experiments on several short text datasets demonstrate that DQE-Net outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Graph Neural Networks via Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based applications. However, their robustness to adversarial attacks remains a concern. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention mechanism to enhance the adversarial robustness of GNNs. Our approach leverages attention weights to identify and down-weight noisy or anomalous nodes, thereby improving the model's resilience to targeted attacks. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method achieves significant improvements in robustness while maintaining competitive performance on clean data.

title: Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Efficient Node Representation Learning
paper_abstract: Learning node representations is a fundamental task in graph-structured data analysis. However, existing methods often suffer from scalability issues or fail to capture complex relationships between nodes. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Neural Network (HGNN) architecture that leverages a hierarchical clustering strategy to learn efficient node representations. By recursively applying graph pooling and node aggregation, HGNN effectively reduces the dimensionality of node features while preserving essential structural information. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of node classification accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) agents have achieved remarkable success in complex tasks, but their decision-making processes often remain opaque. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that enhances the explainability of RL policies. By modeling the environment as a graph and applying hierarchical attention mechanisms, HGAT disentangles the agent's decision-making process into interpretable components. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT on several Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing improved transparency and performance over state-of-the-art RL methods.

title: Eye-Gaze Driven Adaptive Interface for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but existing interfaces often neglect the user's attention and intentions. This paper introduces a novel eye-gaze driven adaptive interface, 'EGAIA', which leverages pupillometry and machine learning to infer user interests and adapt the VR environment accordingly. EGAIA incorporates a probabilistic model of user attention, which is updated in real-time using eye-tracking data. We conducted a user study with 30 participants and found that EGAIA significantly improves user engagement, reduces cognitive load, and enhances overall VR experience.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) face complex decision-making challenges, particularly in dynamic environments. This paper introduces a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'AV-HRL', which decomposes the decision-making process into high-level goal-setting and low-level control optimization. We propose a novel, attention-based abstraction mechanism that enables the high-level policy to focus on relevant contextual information. Experimental results in a simulated urban driving scenario demonstrate that AV-HRL outperforms flat RL approaches in terms of task completion rate and safety metrics.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Robot Arm Control
paper_abstract: Robot arm control is a challenging problem in robotics, requiring precise and efficient motion planning. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'HierArm', which leverages a two-level hierarchy to learn complex tasks. The high-level policy learns to select sub-goals, while the low-level policy executes the corresponding motor controls. We demonstrate HierArm's effectiveness in a real-world robot arm platform, achieving a 30% reduction in task completion time compared to state-of-the-art flat reinforcement learning methods.

title: Adaptive Trust Management for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Trust management is a crucial aspect of multi-agent systems, as it enables agents to make informed decisions about cooperation and communication. This paper proposes a novel adaptive trust management framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize trust dynamics in dynamic environments. Our approach, dubbed 'ATMA', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal trust update strategy based on agent interactions and environmental feedback. We demonstrate the effectiveness of ATMA in a simulated disaster response scenario, where it outperforms traditional trust management methods in terms of cooperation efficiency and system resilience.

title: Query Expansion via Hierarchical Topic Modeling for Enhanced Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial technique in information retrieval (IR) to improve the retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. However, existing QE methods often rely on simplistic term-weighting schemes, overlooking the underlying topic structure of the documents. This paper proposes a novel QE approach, Hierarchical Topic-based Query Expansion (HTQE), which leverages hierarchical topic modeling to capture the semantic relationships between terms and documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HTQE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance and robustness.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but existing VR systems often neglect the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences, focusing on users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key accessibility barriers and developed a set of design guidelines and recommendations for VR developers. Our evaluation shows that incorporating these guidelines can significantly improve the overall VR experience for users with disabilities, enhancing their sense of presence, engagement, and satisfaction.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Distributed resource allocation is a crucial problem in many real-world applications, such as smart grids, traffic management, and cloud computing. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARLA', that addresses the scalability challenges in large-scale distributed systems. MARLA employs a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to optimize its local policy while communicating with its neighbors to achieve global coordination. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MARLA in a simulated smart grid environment, showing improved convergence rates and resource allocation efficiency compared to existing methods.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Natural Language Processing with Hierarchical Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot natural language processing (NLP) has gained significant attention in recent years. However, most existing approaches rely on complex task-specific architectures or require large amounts of annotated data. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning framework, 'HiTE', which leverages hierarchical task embeddings to adapt to new NLP tasks with only a few examples. Our approach enables the model to capture task relationships and transfer knowledge across tasks, resulting in improved performance on a range of benchmark datasets. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HiTE on several few-shot NLP tasks, including text classification, sentiment analysis, and question answering.

title: Deep Retrieval-based Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Search
paper_abstract: Traditional learning-to-rank approaches for document search rely on pairwise or listwise training, which can be computationally expensive and limited in their ability to model complex relevance relationships. This paper proposes a novel deep retrieval-based neural ranking model, 'DRR', which leverages a dense passage retrieval approach to efficiently identify relevant documents. Our model utilizes a hierarchical transformer architecture to capture both local and global contextual information, and is trained using a contrastive learning objective that minimizes the distance between relevant document pairs. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of DRR in improving search efficiency and ranking accuracy.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning via Graph-Based Communication
paper_abstract: In multi-agent reinforcement learning, independent exploration can lead to inefficient learning and suboptimal policies. We propose a novel framework, Graph-CE, which enables agents to share information and coordinate exploration through a graph-based communication protocol. By modeling the agents' interactions as a graph, we can identify and exploit structural dependencies between agents, leading to faster convergence and improved policy performance. Experimental results in a variety of multi-agent environments demonstrate the effectiveness of Graph-CE in reducing exploration time and improving overall team performance.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Robot Swarms using Swarm Intelligence-based Negotiation Protocols
paper_abstract: Autonomous robot swarms have demonstrated great potential in various applications, such as search and rescue, environmental monitoring, and warehouse management. However, efficient task allocation remains a significant challenge, especially in decentralized settings. This paper proposes a novel swarm intelligence-based negotiation protocol for decentralized task allocation in autonomous robot swarms. Our approach leverages the concept of stigmergy to enable robots to negotiate tasks through indirect communication. We evaluate our protocol using simulations and real-world experiments, demonstrating improved task allocation efficiency, flexibility, and scalability compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly interact with humans in various settings, recognizing emotions from multi-modal cues (e.g., speech, facial expressions, and body language) becomes crucial for effective human-robot collaboration. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates and weighs the contributions of different modalities to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention modules and a hierarchical fusion mechanism that captures complex relationships between modalities. Experimental results on the MPI-EMO dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions in human-robot interaction scenarios, achieving an F1-score of 0.92.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Graph Neural Networks via Topology-Aware Adversarial Training
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-structured data tasks. However, recent studies have shown that GNNs are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their reliability in real-world applications. In this paper, we propose a novel topology-aware adversarial training framework for GNNs, which leverages the structural properties of graphs to improve robustness against adversarial attacks. Our approach incorporates a topology-based perturbation strategy that adapts to the graph structure, resulting in more effective and efficient adversarial training. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly enhances the robustness of GNNs against various types of adversarial attacks.

title: Improving Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale search queries. However, query efficiency remains a significant bottleneck in these systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach that partitions the document collection into multiple layers, each optimized for a specific query type. Our method, called HiIndex, adaptively selects the most suitable index layer based on query characteristics, reducing the number of nodes involved in query processing. Experimental results on a large-scale DIR testbed demonstrate that HiIndex achieves an average query response time reduction of 37% compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Neural Document Ranking with Hierarchical Aspect Modeling for Multifaceted Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document ranking models often fail to capture the multifaceted nature of user information needs. This paper proposes a neural document ranking approach, HierAspRank, which incorporates hierarchical aspect modeling to better align retrieved documents with user queries. Our model learns to represent documents as a hierarchical composition of aspects, enabling more fine-grained matching with query facets. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ranking performance and facet-level relevance over state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents for Efficient Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, efficient task allocation is crucial for autonomous agents to achieve their goals. This paper presents a novel framework, 'DynAlloc', which enables agents to adaptively coordinate task assignment based on real-time environment changes. DynAlloc integrates a decentralized decision-making mechanism with a probabilistic model of task dependencies, allowing agents to dynamically adjust their task allocations to minimize expected latency and maximize overall utility. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that DynAlloc outperforms existing static allocation methods by up to 30% in terms of task completion rate and reduces average response time by 25%.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging problem in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short or ambiguous queries. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural document embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed 'NeuroQE', uses a graph-based neural network to learn dense representations of documents and expand the original query with relevant terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for autonomous vehicle control. Our approach, dubbed 'HMAVC', leverages a decentralized architecture where each vehicle is modeled as an agent that learns to interact with its surroundings and other agents. We introduce a hierarchical policy structure that enables agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and learn high-level decision-making strategies. Experimental results in a simulated urban driving environment demonstrate that HMAVC outperforms state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods in terms of safety, efficiency, and scalability.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Virtual Assistants: A Study on User Experience and Error Mitigation
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants are increasingly prevalent in smart home and IoT environments, but their voice-based interaction modalities can be limiting. This paper explores the potential of gaze-based interaction with virtual assistants, leveraging eye-tracking technology to enable more natural and intuitive user experiences. We conduct a user study to investigate the impact of gaze-based interaction on user satisfaction, error rates, and task completion times. Our results show that gaze-based interaction can significantly reduce error rates and improve user experience, especially for users with disabilities. We also propose a novel error mitigation strategy that leverages machine learning-based gaze prediction to detect and correct user errors.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Model Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The proliferation of multi-model databases has led to an increased complexity in query optimization. Traditional cost-based optimizers struggle to navigate the vast space of possible query plans, resulting in suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'QueryRLE', which leverages reinforcement learning to efficiently explore the query optimization space. By formulating the optimization problem as a Markov decision process, QueryRLE learns to adapt to changing database workloads and query patterns, outperforming state-of-the-art optimizers in experiments on real-world datasets.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Learning on Molecular Structures
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning on molecular structures is crucial for rapidly discovering new materials and drugs. However, existing graph neural networks (GNNs) struggle to generalize to unseen molecular structures with limited labeled data. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) that leverages attention mechanisms at multiple scales to capture complex structural patterns. HiGAT learns to focus on relevant substructures and adapt to new molecular structures with as few as 5 labeled examples. Experimental results on benchmark molecular datasets demonstrate that HiGAT outperforms state-of-the-art GNNs and achieves competitive performance with traditional machine learning methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Deep Neural Networks for Retrieval of COVID-19 Related Literature
paper_abstract: The rapid growth of COVID-19 research literature has created a significant challenge for researchers to identify relevant studies. This paper introduces a novel query expansion approach, 'COVID-Expand', that leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of keywords and expand user queries. Our method utilizes a combination of context-aware embeddings and attention mechanisms to capture nuanced relationships between terms. Experimental results on a large COVID-19 literature dataset demonstrate that COVID-Expand outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision and a 17% increase in recall.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: An Empirical Study on Speech Recognition Accuracy
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by speech recognition inaccuracies. This study investigates the impact of age-related speech changes on voice assistant interactions. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults, analyzing their speech patterns and evaluating the performance of three commercial voice assistants. Our results show that existing systems struggle to recognize older adults' speech, particularly with respect to pronunciation, vocabulary, and prosody. We propose a set of design recommendations for developing more inclusive voice assistants, including personalized acoustic models and adaptive error correction mechanisms.

title: Efficient Indexing for Scalable Neural Ranking Models in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but their computational complexity hinders their adoption in large-scale search engines. This paper presents a novel indexing strategy, 'NeurIX', which leverages the inherent structure of neural networks to reduce the number of required model evaluations. We propose a hierarchical indexing scheme that caches intermediate representations and employs a probabilistic pruning mechanism to eliminate irrelevant documents. Experimental results on a large web corpus demonstrate that NeurIX achieves significant speedups over existing indexing methods while maintaining retrieval effectiveness.

title: Multi-Modal Fusion for Enhanced Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces can greatly benefit from accurate gesture recognition, enabling more immersive and interactive experiences. This paper presents a novel multi-modal fusion approach that combines computer vision, electromyography (EMG), and inertial measurement unit (IMU) data to recognize hand gestures in VR. Our proposed framework, 'FusionVR', leverages a deep learning architecture to integrate the strengths of each modality, achieving a 25% increase in recognition accuracy compared to state-of-the-art vision-only methods. We evaluate FusionVR on a dataset of 20 participants performing 10 distinct gestures, demonstrating its potential for enhancing VR interactions.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Graph Neural Networks via Bayesian Graph Mutation
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved remarkable success in various graph-based applications, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks has raised significant concerns. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian approach to improve the robustness of GNNs against graph perturbations. We introduce a probabilistic graph mutation strategy that generates a distribution of perturbed graphs, allowing the GNN to learn from diverse, adversarial scenarios. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed method significantly enhances the robustness of GNNs against various types of graph attacks, while maintaining their performance on clean graphs.

title: EyeGazeExplorer: A Gaze-Based Interface for Visualizing and Exploring Large Graphs
paper_abstract: Visualizing and exploring large graphs is a fundamental task in many domains, including social network analysis, bioinformatics, and recommender systems. However, existing interfaces often rely on manual navigation, leading to cognitive overload and decreased productivity. We present EyeGazeExplorer, a novel gaze-based interface that leverages eye-tracking technology to facilitate efficient and intuitive graph exploration. By combining gaze-based selection, semantic zooming, and dynamic filtering, our system enables users to explore large graphs with reduced cognitive load and improved comprehension. A user study demonstrates the effectiveness of EyeGazeExplorer in reducing navigation time and improving user satisfaction.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Ant Colony Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem that involves assigning tasks to agents in a way that maximizes efficiency and minimizes communication overhead. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation algorithm inspired by ant colony optimization. Each agent maintains a local pheromone trail that guides task allocation decisions, and agents communicate through indirect interactions. We show that our approach outperforms traditional auction-based methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the scalability and robustness of our algorithm.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Indexing for Real-Time Graph Database Query Optimization
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex network data. However, optimizing queries in real-time remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces 'GraphAdapt', a novel indexing framework that dynamically adapts to changing query patterns and graph structures. GraphAdapt employs a hybrid indexing approach, combining vertex-centric and edge-centric indexing techniques. Our experiments on large-scale graph datasets demonstrate significant performance improvements, with query execution times reduced by up to 75% compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods.

title: Query Optimization for Real-time Analytics on Column-store Databases
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics on column-store databases is crucial for various applications, including IoT and financial data processing. However, existing query optimization techniques are often inadequate for column-store databases, leading to poor query performance. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages column-level statistics and machine learning-based predicate estimation to optimize query plans. We introduce a cost-based optimization approach that considers both CPU and memory access patterns, resulting in improved query execution times and reduced memory usage. Experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates the effectiveness of ColOpt in achieving up to 3x query performance improvements compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has emerged as a powerful technique for incorporating semantic information into recommendation systems. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity and limited context-awareness. This paper proposes a novel KGE approach, 'HierAtt-KGE', which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant entities and relationships. Our experiments on three real-world datasets demonstrate that HierAtt-KGE outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in terms of recommendation accuracy, while reducing computational overhead by up to 40%. We also provide insights into the interpretability of learned attention weights, shedding light on the importance of specific knowledge graph structures.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems with Dynamic Resource Constraints
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem, especially when agents operate under dynamic resource constraints. This paper presents a novel decentralized algorithm, 'DynaTA', which enables agents to coordinate task allocation in real-time. DynaTA leverages a distributed constraint optimization framework to accommodate changing resource availability and agent capabilities. We evaluate DynaTA through extensive simulations, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving overall system utility and reducing task allocation latency compared to existing methods.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Negotiation Framework for Multi-Stakeholder Decision Making
paper_abstract: Multi-stakeholder decision making (MSDM) is a complex problem that requires efficient negotiation strategies to reach mutually beneficial agreements. This paper proposes a novel autonomous agent-based negotiation framework, 'aNego', which leverages reinforcement learning and graph-based reasoning to facilitate effective negotiation between multiple stakeholders. aNego agents learn to identify and prioritize stakeholder interests, generate counter-proposals, and adapt to changing negotiation contexts. Experimental results on a simulated MSDM scenario demonstrate that aNego outperforms traditional negotiation protocols in terms of agreement quality, negotiation speed, and stakeholder satisfaction.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel reinforcement learning approach for autonomous task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems. We propose a hierarchical framework that integrates a high-level task allocator with low-level agent controllers. The task allocator learns to assign tasks to agents based on their capabilities, workload, and communication constraints, while the agent controllers learn to execute tasks efficiently. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional planning-based methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding for Explainable AI Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Explainability in AI decision-making is crucial for building trust in autonomous systems. Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has shown promise in modeling complex relationships between entities. However, existing KGE methods suffer from scalability issues and lack interpretability. This paper proposes 'ExplainKG', a novel KGE framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms and hierarchical clustering to encode knowledge graphs efficiently. We evaluate ExplainKG on a benchmark dataset and demonstrate its ability to provide interpretable explanations for AI-driven decision-making while maintaining predictive performance.

title: Autonomous Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Real-World Scenarios
paper_abstract: Negotiation is a crucial aspect of multi-agent systems, where agents must reach agreements to achieve common goals. However, existing approaches often rely on oversimplifying assumptions, neglecting the complexities of real-world scenarios. This paper proposes a novel autonomous negotiation strategy, 'RealNegotiator', which integrates machine learning and game theory to adapt to dynamic environments. Our approach learns from historical data and incorporates domain knowledge to improve negotiation outcomes. We evaluate RealNegotiator in a realistic supply chain management scenario, demonstrating improved negotiation efficiency and profit compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, task allocation is a challenging problem that requires adapting to changing conditions and coordinating among multiple agents. This paper proposes a multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for distributed task allocation. We introduce a novel communication protocol that enables agents to share information and learn from each other's experiences. Our approach, called 'Dyna Alloc', is evaluated in a simulated disaster response scenario, where agents must allocate tasks to rescue teams in response to uncertain and changing environmental conditions. Results show that Dyna Alloc outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods and achieves near-optimal performance in dynamic environments.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Turn Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-turn dialogue systems have become increasingly prevalent in AI applications, but their opaqueness hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for explainable dialogue systems. Our HAN framework consists of two levels of attention: utterance-level and token-level. The utterance-level attention weights capture the contextual relevance of each utterance, while the token-level attention weights highlight the important words and phrases contributing to the response generation. We evaluate our approach on three benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in both response quality and explainability.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) aim to provide transparent and interpretable user-item interactions. This paper introduces HeteroGAT, a novel heterogeneous graph attention network that incorporates item, user, and contextual features to generate personalized explanations for recommendations. We propose a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes recommendation accuracy and explanation quality. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HeteroGAT outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of recommendation accuracy, explanation coherence, and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Ranking Models with Hyperbolic Embeddings
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to document retrieval using deep neural ranking models with hyperbolic embeddings. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures the semantic relationships between queries and documents in a hyperbolic space, allowing for more accurate and efficient retrieval. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art models, while also reducing the computational complexity. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the learned hyperbolic embeddings, shedding light on the role of curvature in capturing document semantics.

title: Emotion Recognition in Virtual Reality using Multimodal Fusion and Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but understanding user emotions in VR remains a significant challenge. We propose a novel multimodal fusion approach that combines facial expression, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions in VR. Our framework utilizes a deep learning architecture that integrates convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to extract and fuse features from each modality. Experimental results with a custom-built VR dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art emotion recognition accuracy, outperforming existing unimodal and multimodal approaches.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. Existing methods often rely on centralized controllers or assume a complete communication graph, limiting their scalability and applicability. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework, 'GATask', which leverages graph attention networks to learn agent-specific representations and allocate tasks based on local observations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GATask in various benchmarks, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component of task-oriented dialogue systems, but existing approaches often lack interpretability. We propose a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for DST, which incorporates both turn-level and dialogue-level attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant context. Our model, HAT-DST, learns to extract relevant information from the dialogue history and generate explicit state representations, enabling explainability and improved tracking accuracy. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HAT-DST in achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing transparent and interpretable DST.

title: Hierarchical Task Modeling for Adaptive Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems rely on accurate gesture recognition to provide immersive experiences. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task modeling approach for adaptive gesture recognition, exploiting the inherent structure of VR tasks. Our method, 'HTMR', represents tasks as a hierarchical composition of sub-tasks, enabling the model to focus on relevant gesture patterns. We evaluate HTMR on a large-scale VR gesture dataset, demonstrating improved recognition accuracy and adaptability to new tasks compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Adversarial Training of Graph Convolutional Networks for Robust Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks. However, they remain vulnerable to adversarial attacks that manipulate the graph structure or node features. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'AdvGCN', which incorporates a perturbation-based adversarial loss function into the GCN training process. We demonstrate that AdvGCN significantly improves the robustness of GCNs against various types of attacks, including node injection, edge rewiring, and feature perturbation. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets show that AdvGCN achieves improved classification accuracy and robustness compared to standard GCN training.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Scalable Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between entities. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the inherent complexity of graph data structures. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'GraFOpt', which leverages a combination of graph summarization, index-based query rewriting, and adaptive caching to improve query performance. We evaluate GraFOpt on several real-world graph datasets and demonstrate significant speedups compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques, making graph databases more scalable and efficient for large-scale applications.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Scalable Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between entities. However, as the scale of these databases grows, query optimization becomes a significant bottleneck. This paper presents 'GraphOpt', a novel distributed query optimization framework for scalable graph databases. GraphOpt leverages a combination of graph partitioning, parallel query execution, and dynamic query rewriting to achieve up to 5x performance improvement over state-of-the-art query optimizers. We evaluate GraphOpt on a large-scale social network dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing query latency and improving system throughput.

title: Hierarchical Time-Series Forecasting with Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, energy, and healthcare. However, existing methods often struggle to capture complex hierarchical structures and long-range dependencies in multivariate time-series data. This paper proposes a novel Graph Attention Network (GAT) architecture, dubbed HierGAT, which leverages both temporal and spatial dependencies to improve forecasting accuracy. We evaluate HierGAT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art methods, particularly in handling missing values and non-stationary data.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Effective Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has emerged as a prominent paradigm for open-domain question answering. However, DPR models often struggle to generalize to unseen queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a neural query expansion (NQE) framework that leverages a transformer-based encoder to generate semantically enriched query representations. We introduce a novel training objective that encourages the NQE model to generate queries that are both diverse and relevant to the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NQE significantly improves the retrieval effectiveness of DPR models, especially for rare or out-of-vocabulary queries.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Multi-Dimensional Data in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and social media platforms has led to an exponential growth in multi-dimensional data. Traditional indexing techniques are often inefficient in distributed database systems, resulting in poor query performance. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'DIMEX', which leverages a combination of dimensionality reduction and clustering techniques to accelerate query processing. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DIMEX through extensive experiments on real-world datasets, achieving significant improvements in query response times and reduced storage overhead.

title: Emotional State Recognition from Multimodal Wearable Sensor Data using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Wearable sensors have shown significant potential in recognizing emotional states from physiological signals. However, existing approaches often rely on hand-crafted features and shallow learning models, limiting their accuracy and generalizability. This paper proposes a multimodal deep learning framework, 'EmoSense', which integrates data from electrodermal activity, heart rate, and acceleration sensors to recognize emotional states. Our approach leverages a novel attention-based fusion mechanism to selectively weight sensor modalities and capture complex patterns. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate EmoSense outperforms state-of-the-art methods by 12.5% in F1-score, achieving an accuracy of 92.1% in recognizing four emotional states (happiness, sadness, fear, and anger).

title: Evaluating the Effect of Embodiment on Trust in Virtual Agents
paper_abstract: Virtual agents are increasingly used in various applications, including customer service, education, and healthcare. While trust is a crucial aspect of human-agent interaction, the role of embodiment in trust formation remains understudied. This paper investigates the impact of different levels of embodiment on trust in virtual agents. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, exposing them to three conditions: text-based, 2D avatar, and 3D humanoid avatar. Our results show that participants who interacted with the 3D humanoid avatar reported higher levels of trust and perceived the agent as more trustworthy and competent. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of trustworthy virtual agents.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Attention-based Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval methods rely on hand-crafted features and ranking models, which often fail to capture the semantic nuances of natural language queries. This paper proposes a novel attention-based neural ranking model, 'AttRank', which leverages deep learning to learn query-document relevance patterns. AttRank utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant query terms and document passages, enabling more accurate retrieval results. Experimental evaluations on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of AttRank over state-of-the-art ranking models, particularly in handling complex, multi-entity queries.

title: Scalable Object Detection using Hierarchical Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Object detection in images remains a challenging task, particularly when dealing with large, complex scenes. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'HierDet', which leverages hierarchical knowledge graph embeddings to improve detection accuracy and scalability. By representing objects as nodes in a graph, we can capture semantic relationships between entities and contexts, enabling more informed feature extraction and bounding box prediction. Our experiments on the COCO dataset demonstrate significant improvements in AP and AR scores, especially for rare and occluded objects, while achieving real-time performance on modern GPU architectures.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems via Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient exploration is crucial for tasks like surveillance and search-and-rescue. However, as the number of agents increases, the exploration problem becomes increasingly complex. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical graph attention mechanism that enables coordinated exploration among agents. Our approach represents the environment as a graph, where agents learn to focus on the most informative regions and adapt their exploration strategies accordingly. Experimental results in simulated environments demonstrate that our method outperforms existing decentralized exploration approaches, achieving faster coverage and improved knowledge gathering.

title: Adversarial Training with Uncertainty-Aware Regularization for Robust Image Classification
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be mitigated by adversarial training. However, existing methods often overlook the uncertainty associated with the learned models. This paper proposes a novel uncertainty-aware regularization technique, 'UncerReg', which incorporates Bayesian neural networks into the adversarial training framework. UncerReg encourages the model to learn more robust features by penalizing the uncertainty of the predictions on adversarial examples. Experimental results on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that UncerReg significantly improves the robustness of image classification models against various types of attacks while maintaining competitive clean accuracy.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Scalable RDF Graph Processing
paper_abstract: RDF graph processing has become increasingly important for large-scale data integration and analysis. However, query optimization remains a significant bottleneck, particularly in distributed settings. This paper presents a novel distributed query optimization framework, 'RDF-DistOpt', which leverages graph partitioning and parallel processing to accelerate SPARQL query execution. We introduce a cost-based optimization strategy that takes into account data locality, network communication, and processing capacity of individual nodes. Experimental results on a real-world RDF dataset demonstrate that RDF-DistOpt achieves up to 5x speedup compared to state-of-the-art centralized optimization techniques.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Query Representations for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query representation plays a crucial role in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it directly impacts the retrieval efficiency and effectiveness. This paper presents a novel hierarchical query representation framework, HQRF, which captures both local and global semantic patterns in queries. HQRF employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to learn query representations at multiple granularities, enabling more accurate document ranking. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HQRF significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query representation methods, achieving up to 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Real-Time IoT Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has created a pressing need for efficient resource allocation strategies to ensure real-time processing and data transmission. This paper presents a novel autonomous agent-based framework, 'AURA', which leverages decentralized decision-making to optimize resource allocation in IoT systems. AURA agents employ a hybrid approach, combining reinforcement learning with constraint programming to adapt to dynamic system conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that AURA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of resource utilization, latency, and system resilience, while maintaining scalability and fault tolerance.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Multimodal Interaction for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their adoption is hindered by the lack of accessibility features for people with disabilities. This paper presents an investigation into the design of inclusive voice assistants, focusing on multimodal interaction mechanisms. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with individuals with visual, hearing, motor, and cognitive disabilities to identify key accessibility barriers. Our findings inform the development of a novel interaction framework that integrates speech, gesture, and tactile modalities. We evaluate the framework through a usability study, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction for participants with disabilities.

title: Hierarchical Attention Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention neural network (HANN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features at multiple levels of abstraction. Our approach leverages a novel hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights modalities and features based on their importance for emotion recognition. Experimental results on the CMU-Multimodal SDK dataset demonstrate that HANN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, achieving an accuracy of 85.2%.

title: Efficient Document Re-ranking using Neural Query Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models often rely on complex and computationally expensive architectures to capture nuanced query-document relationships. This paper proposes a novel query graph embedding approach, 'QGE', which leverages graph neural networks to efficiently model query semantics and re-rank documents. QGE learns a compact, dense representation of the query graph, enabling fast and accurate similarity computations with candidate documents. Our experiments on the TREC DL 2019 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ranking performance, with a 15% increase in NDCG@10 compared to strong baseline models, while reducing computational costs by up to 40%.

title: Designing Adaptive Transparency for Conversational AI Systems
paper_abstract: As conversational AI systems become increasingly prevalent, it is essential to design interfaces that foster trust and understanding. This paper presents a novel approach to adaptive transparency, where the system dynamically adjusts the level of explanation and justification to the user's needs and preferences. We developed a probabilistic model that infers user uncertainty and tailored our transparency mechanisms to provide contextual insights. A user study with 120 participants demonstrated that our approach improves user trust and satisfaction, while reducing feelings of frustration and confusion.

title: Conflict Resolution Strategies for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems often rely on negotiation and coordination to achieve shared goals. However, conflicts may arise when agents have differing preferences or goals. This paper introduces a novel conflict resolution framework, 'CoRe', which leverages graph-based reasoning to identify and resolve conflicts in real-time. CoRe incorporates a hybrid approach combining argumentation-based negotiation and machine learning-based prediction to improve conflict resolution efficiency and effectiveness. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the efficacy of CoRe in reducing conflict rates and improving overall system performance.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Evolutionary Game Theory
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving system-wide objectives. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework based on evolutionary game theory, which enables agents to adaptively learn and adjust their strategies in response to changing environmental conditions. Our approach leverages the concept of evolutionary stable strategies to ensure that agents converge to a stable and efficient allocation of tasks. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving system performance and robustness compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Session-based Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Session-based recommendation systems (SRS) aim to predict the next item a user will interact with based on their current session. Graph-based methods have shown promise in SRS, but struggle to capture complex item relationships and user behavior. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that models user sessions as hierarchical graphs, incorporating both item and session-level attention mechanisms. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art SRS methods, achieving significant improvements in precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Databases using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of large-scale RDF datasets has created a need for efficient query optimization techniques in distributed database systems. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to optimize query plans for distributed RDF databases. We design a GNN architecture that learns to predict optimal query plans based on graph structural features and query patterns. Our experimental results on the WatDiv benchmark demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time, while also achieving better scalability and robustness.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to cooperative task allocation for multi-agent systems using graph neural networks (GNNs). We model the agent-task interaction as a graph, where agents and tasks are represented as nodes, and edges denote the feasibility of task assignment. Our GNN-based algorithm learns to predict the optimal task allocation by leveraging the structural properties of the graph. We evaluate our approach on a set of benchmark scenarios and demonstrate significant improvements in terms of task completion time and agent utilization compared to traditional methods. Our results have implications for the coordination of autonomous robots, drones, and other multi-agent systems.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Graph Neural Networks via Hierarchical Graph Refinement
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based tasks. However, their vulnerability to adversarial attacks has raised concerns about their reliability. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Graph Refinement (HGR), to enhance the robustness of GNNs against adversarial attacks. HGR iteratively refines the graph structure by identifying and pruning suspicious nodes and edges, leading to improved robustness against various types of attacks. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGR in improving the robustness of GNNs, outperforming existing defense methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational agents is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates multimodal features from speech, text, and facial expressions to recognize emotions in real-time conversations. Our HAN model consists of three levels of attention: modality-level, utterance-level, and conversation-level, which enables the model to capture complex contextual relationships between modalities. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions, especially in cases of ambiguity or context-dependent emotions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Robust Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-based machine learning, but existing methods often struggle with noisy or incomplete graph structures. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages multi-scale graph representations to improve robustness. HGAN recursively applies graph attention mechanisms at different scales, allowing it to capture both local and global structural patterns. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in node classification accuracy, especially in the presence of noisy or missing edges.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is crucial in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and climate science. While AI-driven models have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often lack interpretability, hindering trust and adoption. This paper introduces HATSF, a novel hierarchical attention network that provides explainable time series forecasting. HATSF incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant features and time steps, generating interpretable attention weights. We evaluate HATSF on multiple real-world datasets, demonstrating improved forecasting accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art models. Furthermore, our model provides transparent insights into the forecasting process, enabling users to understand and trust the predictions.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Task Networks for Robust Disaster Response
paper_abstract: Effective disaster response requires coordinating multiple agents with diverse capabilities.
