We propose a hierarchical task network (HTN) framework for multi-agent systems, enabling robust and adaptive response to complex disasters. Our framework integrates planning, scheduling, and execution to allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, resource availability, and environmental constraints. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach through simulations of wildfire response and flood rescue scenarios, showcasing improved response times, reduced resource waste, and enhanced overall resilience.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-based Interaction Design
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but current VR systems often neglect the importance of embodied cognition in user experience. This paper presents a study on gesture-based interaction design, exploring how the incorporation of embodied cognition principles can enhance user engagement and performance in VR environments. We designed and evaluated a novel gesture-based interface for a VR puzzle game, leveraging cognitive architectures and machine learning algorithms to recognize and respond to users' gestures. Results show significant improvements in user satisfaction, task completion time, and cognitive load compared to traditional controller-based interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Task Learning for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is crucial in various domains, but existing methods often lack interpretability and scalability. We propose a hierarchical multi-task learning framework, 'HMTL-AD', which jointly learns anomaly detection and feature importance attribution. By stacking task-specific autoencoders, HMTL-AD captures complex temporal patterns and contextual relationships. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets and provides explicit feature importance scores, enabling explainable anomaly detection. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of HMTL-AD in real-world applications.

title: Context-Aware Negotiation Strategies for Autonomous Agents in Competitive Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for autonomous agents to negotiate in competitive environments. We introduce a context-aware negotiation strategy that incorporates opponent modeling, concession analysis, and adaptive decision-making. Our approach enables agents to dynamically adjust their negotiation tactics based on the opponent's behavior, leading to improved outcomes in terms of utility and efficiency. Experimental results using a real-world negotiation dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in outperforming traditional negotiation strategies.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in node classification tasks. However, existing methods often suffer from limited expressiveness and lack of interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN architecture, 'HAGNN', which leverages multi-scale graph representations and adaptive attention mechanisms to capture complex node relationships. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, including Cora, Citeseer, and Pubmed. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the learned attention patterns, revealing insights into the underlying graph structure and node importance.

title: Guided Document Expansion for Efficient Query-Based Summarization
paper_abstract: Query-based summarization has become a crucial task in Information Retrieval (IR) due to the exponential growth of digital content. This paper proposes a novel approach, GuidedDoc, which leverages query-dependent document expansion to improve the quality and efficiency of summarization. By incorporating keyphrase extraction and semantic role labeling, GuidedDoc selectively expands relevant documents to better capture the context and intent behind the query. Experimental results on the TREC news dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ROUGE scores and query relevance, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Evaluating the Efficacy of Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This study investigates the usability and accessibility of gestural interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments. We designed and implemented a gestural interface using a 3D depth sensor and evaluated its performance with 30 participants aged 65-85 with mild cognitive impairments. Our results show that the interface significantly improved task completion time and accuracy compared to traditional mouse-based input. Furthermore, we identified key design guidelines for gestural interfaces tailored to this population, including the importance of intuitive gesture mapping and feedback mechanisms. Our findings have implications for the development of inclusive and supportive technologies for older adults with cognitive impairments.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness against Backdoor Attacks in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have been shown to be vulnerable to backdoor attacks, where an attacker injects malicious data to manipulate the model's behavior. We propose a novel adversarial training framework, 'BackdoorGuard', to improve the robustness of DNNs against backdoor attacks. Our approach leverages a two-player game formulation, where a generator network crafts backdoor patterns, and a discriminator network detects and rejects them. We demonstrate the effectiveness of BackdoorGuard on various benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in model robustness compared to existing defense methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Deep Neural Language Models for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on simplistic assumptions about language and user intent. This paper explores the application of deep neural language models to query expansion, demonstrating improved retrieval performance on challenging datasets. Our approach leverages the contextualized embeddings and language understanding capabilities of transformer-based models to generate more effective expansion terms. We evaluate our method on several standard IR benchmarks, showing significant gains in precision and recall over state-of-the-art techniques.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Robot Navigation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Robot navigation in dynamic environments is a challenging problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that integrates a high-level task planner with a low-level motion controller. The proposed approach leverages a graph-based representation of the environment to learn a hierarchical policy that balances exploration and exploitation. Experimental results on a simulated robot navigation task demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of navigation efficiency and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Adaptive Contextualized Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in modern information retrieval systems, as it helps to alleviate the vocabulary mismatch problem between the user's query and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using adaptive contextualized embeddings, which dynamically captures the semantic relationships between query terms and their surrounding context. Our method, dubbed ACE-QE, leverages pre-trained language models to generate contextualized embeddings for query terms and then adaptively selects the most informative expansion terms based on their relevance to the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ACE-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Towards Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for managing large-scale data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of distributed query plans. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'DistOpt', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective query plans for DDS. DistOpt models the query optimization problem as a graph-based optimization problem and uses GNNs to learn the relationships between queries, data distributions, and system resources. Experimental results on the TPC-H benchmark show that DistOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Conventional neural ranking models for document retrieval suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HierRank', which leverages a dual-encoder architecture to efficiently process large document collections. HierRank first employs a coarse-grained relevance scorer to filter out irrelevant documents, and then applies a fine-grained ranking model to the remaining candidates. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierRank achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency while maintaining competitive ranking performance compared to state-of-the-art neural models.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph Convolutional Networks for Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: The increasing reliance on time series data in various applications has raised concerns about the vulnerability of these systems to adversarial attacks. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect such attacks using Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) on time series data. Our method, dubbed 'TS-Guard', models the temporal dependencies and relationships between time series variables as a graph, enabling the detection of subtle anomalies indicative of adversarial attacks. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of TS-Guard in detecting attacks, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 15% in terms of F1-score.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Deep Neural Latent Topic Modeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on simplistic term weighting schemes or shallow learning models. This paper proposes a novel deep neural latent topic modeling approach, 'NeuroTE', which jointly learns topic representations and query-document relevance. We leverage a hierarchical variational autoencoder to capture complex topic relationships and a neural ranking model to optimize retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroTE consistently outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly for queries with ambiguous or nuanced semantics.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization in DDS remains a challenging problem due to the complexities of distributed query planning and execution. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the DDS environment and receiving rewards based on query execution performance. Our experiments on a real-world DDS dataset demonstrate that the RL-based query optimizer outperforms traditional rule-based and cost-based optimizers in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) approaches often rely on hand-crafted features and linear models, which may not capture the complexities of natural language. We propose a deep neural network-based ranking model, 'DeepRank', that learns to represent documents and queries as dense vectors. Our architecture integrates a novel attention mechanism to weigh the importance of query terms and a hierarchical document encoder to capture multi-scale contextual information. Experiments on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate that DeepRank outperforms state-of-the-art IR models, achieving a 12% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization in such systems remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of query execution plans and the dynamic nature of data distributions. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to predict optimal query execution plans by interacting with the database environment. Our experiments on a real-world dataset show that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Enabling Accessible Gestural Interactions for Users with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor disabilities face significant barriers when interacting with gestural interfaces. This paper presents 'AccessibleGest', a novel framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision to enable accessible gestural interactions. We propose a real-time gesture recognition system that adapts to the unique abilities of individuals with motor disabilities, allowing for accurate and efficient gesture detection. Our user study involving 20 participants with motor disabilities demonstrates that AccessibleGest outperforms state-of-the-art gesture recognition systems, achieving an average recognition accuracy of 92.5%. We also present a set of design guidelines for developing accessible gestural interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Knowledge Graph Embedding for Commonsense Reasoning
paper_abstract: Commonsense reasoning is a crucial aspect of human-like intelligence, but existing knowledge graph embedding methods struggle to capture nuanced relationships between entities. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention-based Knowledge Graph Embedding (HATKE), a novel framework that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant subgraphs and contextualize entity representations. We evaluate HATKE on several benchmarks, demonstrating significant improvements in link prediction, entity disambiguation, and question answering tasks. Our approach paves the way for more accurate and interpretable commonsense reasoning in AI systems.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Embeddings and Ontology Alignment
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, but it remains a challenging task, especially when dealing with large datasets. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'OntoGraph', which leverages graph-based embeddings and ontology alignment to disambiguate entities at scale. Our method first learns entity representations using a graph convolutional neural network, and then aligns these representations with a knowledge graph ontology to resolve ambiguities. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that OntoGraph outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency, making it a promising solution for large-scale knowledge graph construction.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Modern information retrieval systems rely on neural ranking models to improve document retrieval efficiency. However, these models often struggle with large document collections and limited computational resources. We propose a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HierRank', which leverages a multi-level document representation to reduce computational complexity. Our approach first employs a lightweight ranking model to filter out irrelevant documents, and then applies a more accurate but computationally expensive model to the remaining candidates. Experimental results on the TREC-500 dataset demonstrate that HierRank achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational cost by up to 50% compared to existing neural ranking models.

title: Eliciting User Preferences for Smart Home Automation using Multimodal Interaction
paper_abstract: Smart home automation systems require users to explicitly configure and customize settings, which can be time-consuming and error-prone. This paper presents a novel multimodal interaction framework that elicits user preferences through a combination of speech, gesture, and gaze inputs. We design and evaluate a prototype system that integrates a conversational agent, computer vision, and machine learning to infer user intentions and adapt the smart home environment accordingly. Our user study demonstrates significant improvements in user satisfaction, efficiency, and accuracy compared to traditional interfaces.

title: Scalable Anomaly Detection in Univariate Time Series using Hierarchical Temporal Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task with numerous applications. However, existing approaches struggle to handle large-scale datasets and complex patterns. This paper presents Hierarchical Temporal Convolutional Networks (HTCN), a novel deep learning framework for anomaly detection in univariate time series. HTCN leverages a hierarchical architecture to learn multi-scale temporal representations, enabling the detection of anomalies at varying frequencies. We conduct extensive experiments on three real-world datasets, demonstrating that HTCN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Hierarchical Graph Decomposition
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of efficient pathfinding in large, complex environments by proposing a novel, hierarchical approach to graph decomposition for multi-agent systems. Our method, called Hierarchical Graph Partitioning (HGP), recursively divides the graph into smaller subgraphs, allowing agents to plan paths independently while minimizing conflicts. We demonstrate the scalability of HGP in simulations involving thousands of agents and show significant reductions in computation time and path length compared to existing methods. The proposed approach has applications in areas such as autonomous vehicles, disaster response, and smart cities.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of information retrieval systems, as it helps to improve the retrieval accuracy by incorporating additional relevant terms. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'SemEx', which leverages semantic embeddings to learn the contextual relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. Our method uses a combination of word2vec and graph convolutional networks to capture the semantic nuances of the query and documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SemEx outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision and recall.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization with Learned Index Structures for Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Modern database systems rely heavily on query optimization to achieve high performance. While traditional optimization techniques rely on manual indexing and query rewriting, recent advances in machine learning have introduced learned index structures as a promising alternative. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'LION', which integrates learned index structures with traditional optimization techniques. LION uses a neural network to predict the optimal query plan based on the database schema, query workload, and learned index statistics. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that LION outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Real-Time Traffic Prediction for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: As autonomous vehicles (AVs) increasingly share roads with human-driven vehicles, efficient pathfinding with real-time traffic prediction becomes crucial. This paper presents a novel multi-agent pathfinding framework, 'TrafficAware', which leverages real-time traffic data and predicts traffic patterns to optimize AV routes. We propose a decentralized approach where AVs, modeled as agents, communicate with each other and the infrastructure to dynamically adjust their paths. Our experiments demonstrate that TrafficAware reduces travel time by up to 25% and decreases the number of conflicts at intersections by 30% compared to traditional graph-based pathfinding methods.

title: Multi-Modal Relevance Feedback for Efficient Image Retrieval
paper_abstract: Relevance feedback is a crucial component in content-based image retrieval (CBIR) systems, as it enables users to refine their queries based on visual similarity. This paper presents a novel multi-modal relevance feedback approach that leverages both visual and textual features to improve the retrieval efficiency of CBIR systems. Our proposed framework, 'MMRF', incorporates a deep neural network to learn a unified representation of images and text, allowing for more effective user feedback. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that MMRF outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and query latency.

title: Designing Emotion-Aware Conversational Interfaces for Mental Health Support
paper_abstract: This paper presents an exploratory study on designing conversational interfaces that can recognize and respond to users' emotional states, with a focus on mental health support. We developed a novel affective computing framework that integrates natural language processing, sentiment analysis, and emotional intelligence. Our user-centered design approach involved co-creating the interface with mental health professionals and individuals with lived experience. Results from a pilot study indicate that our emotion-aware interface can lead to increased self-disclosure, empathy, and trust in online mental health support systems.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Task Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: Distributed task allocation in smart grids poses significant challenges due to the dynamic and uncertain nature of energy demand and supply. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARL-Grid', which enables autonomous agents to learn cooperative task allocation strategies in real-time. We introduce a decentralized Q-network architecture that leverages graph neural networks to model complex dependencies between agents and tasks. Experiments on a simulated smart grid environment demonstrate that MARL-Grid achieves improved task completion rates and reduced energy waste compared to traditional optimization methods.

title: Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Efficient Query Expansion in Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it can significantly improve the retrieval performance. However, traditional QE methods often rely on term co-occurrence statistics, which may not capture the semantic relationships between terms. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document embedding (HDE) framework for QE, which leverages both local and global contextual information. Our approach represents documents as hierarchical graphs, where nodes correspond to terms, and edges denote their co-occurrence relationships. We then learn dense embeddings for these graphs using a graph neural network. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HDE-based QE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion using Neural Entity Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture the semantic intent behind user queries, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework that leverages neural entity embeddings to improve the retrieval performance. Our approach first identifies key entities in the query and then expands them using a hierarchical graph-based model, incorporating semantic relationships between entities. Experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Coordinating Task-Oriented Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating task-oriented multi-agent systems is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep graph reinforcement learning to learn effective coordination policies. We represent the multi-agent system as a graph, where agents are nodes and edges capture their interactions. By learning a policy that optimizes a global reward function, our approach can coordinate agents to achieve complex tasks in a decentralized manner. Experimental results on a variety of task-oriented domains demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving coordination efficiency and task performance.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of optimizing resource allocation to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (DHRL) framework that learns to allocate resources efficiently by modeling the complex interactions between virtual machines, containers, and physical hosts. Our approach integrates a high-level resource manager with a low-level scheduling agent, enabling the system to adapt to changing workloads and minimize costs. Experimental results demonstrate that DHRL achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and response times compared to existing heuristic-based approaches.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) are increasingly being deployed in complex urban environments, necessitating effective coordination mechanisms to ensure safe and efficient traffic flow. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for coordinating AVs at intersections. Our approach, 'CoMA', leverages graph neural networks to model the dynamic interactions among AVs and the environment, enabling scalable and adaptive decision-making. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that CoMA reduces congestion and collision rates compared to traditional rule-based approaches, while requiring minimal communication overhead.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years, as they provide insights into the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention graph convolutional network (HAGCN) architecture that leverages both user-item interactions and side information to generate personalized explanations. Our approach learns to attend to relevant nodes in the graph, capturing complex relationships between users and items. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate that HAGCN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Investigation of Cognitive Biases in Spoken Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their interactions are often influenced by cognitive biases that can perpetuate social inequalities. This study examines the impact of confirmation bias, anchoring bias, and availability heuristic on user interactions with voice assistants. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants and found that these biases can lead to biased responses, reinforce stereotypes, and affect user trust. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants, emphasizing the need for explicit bias mitigation strategies and more transparent AI decision-making processes.

title: Latent Semantic Analysis for Efficient Query Expansion in Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it helps to disambiguate user queries and improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion based on latent semantic analysis (LSA), which models the semantic relationships between terms in a high-dimensional vector space. We introduce a probabilistic framework that integrates LSA with a relevance feedback mechanism, allowing the system to adapt to user preferences and iteratively refine the query representation. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search using Variational Autoencoders
paper_abstract: Neural search has emerged as a powerful paradigm for information retrieval, but its effectiveness is often hindered by the limitations of query representation. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method that leverages variational autoencoders (VAEs) to capture the underlying semantic structure of queries. Our approach, termed 'NeuroExpand', uses a VAE-based query encoder to generate a dense, disentangled representation of the query, which is then used to retrieve relevant documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroExpand outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness while reducing computational overhead.

title: Designing Inclusive Accessibility Features for Voice-Based Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Voice-based virtual assistants (VAs) have become ubiquitous, but their accessibility features often fail to account for diverse user needs. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to developing inclusive accessibility features for VAs. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants with disabilities to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our results inform the design of 'VAce', a VA platform that incorporates personalized accommodations, such as real-time transcription, speech rate adjustment, and multimodal feedback. A usability evaluation with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, designing accessible and usable conversational interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments has become increasingly important. This paper presents a Human-Centered Design approach to create an inclusive conversational system, 'ElderChat', tailored to the needs of this demographic. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers to identify key design requirements. ElderChat incorporates cognitive support features, such as simplified language processing, visual cues, and error forgiveness. A usability study with 20 older adults demonstrated significant improvements in conversational task completion rates and overall user satisfaction.

title: Towards Inclusive Design: A Multimodal Fusion Approach for Emotion Recognition in HCI
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition systems have significant implications for human-computer interaction, but often rely on a single modality, leading to biased or inaccurate results. This paper presents a novel multimodal fusion approach that integrates facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions in real-time. Our framework leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to weight and combine modalities, achieving improved recognition rates and robustness to individual differences. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a user study with 50 participants, highlighting its potential for enhancing emotional intelligence in HCI applications.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Robot Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for autonomous task allocation in multi-robot systems. The proposed approach, called Hierarchical Task Allocation (HTA), decomposes complex tasks into smaller sub-tasks and allocates them to individual robots based on their capabilities and environmental constraints. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HTA in a simulated warehouse scenario, where multiple robots collaborate to fulfill customer orders. Experimental results show that HTA achieves significant improvements in task completion efficiency and adaptability to changing environmental conditions compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Indexing for Time-Series Data in Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Main-memory database systems have become increasingly popular for real-time analytics, but indexing time-series data remains a significant challenge. Existing indexing techniques are often memory-inefficient or sacrifice query performance. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'TSMatrix', which exploits the inherent patterns in time-series data to achieve a better trade-off between memory usage and query performance. We introduce a matrix-based indexing structure that adaptively adjusts to the data distribution and query patterns, resulting in improved query throughput and reduced memory footprint. Experimental evaluation on real-world time-series datasets demonstrates the effectiveness of TSMatrix in supporting high-performance analytics workloads.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Interface Accessibility
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by inaccessible speech interfaces. This paper presents a user-centered design study focused on improving the accessibility of voice assistants for older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops and usability evaluations to identify critical design factors, including speech recognition accuracy, feedback mechanisms, and error recovery strategies. Our results highlight the importance of personalized speech profiles, multimodal feedback, and forgiving error handling in enabling older adults to effectively interact with voice assistants. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants and discuss implications for future research in this area.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly in scenarios where agents have diverse capabilities and tasks require complex coordination. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn coordinated task allocation policies. We represent the agent-task assignments as a graph and leverage GNNs to capture the structural dependencies between agents and tasks. Our approach, called Coordinated Task Allocation Network (CTAN), outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and adaptability to changing task requirements. We evaluate CTAN on several synthetic and real-world multi-agent domains, demonstrating its effectiveness in complex coordination scenarios.

title: Eye-Gaze based Adaptive UI for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has seen significant advancements in recent years, but user experience remains a major bottleneck. This paper presents an innovative approach to adaptive UI design, leveraging eye-gaze tracking to dynamically adjust interface elements in real-time. Our system, 'GazeUX', utilizes machine learning algorithms to identify user intent and optimize UI layout, reducing cognitive load and improving task completion time. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates that GazeUX outperforms traditional UI designs in VR, resulting in higher user satisfaction and reduced eye fatigue.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinated task allocation using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their capabilities, resource constraints, and communication with neighboring agents. Experimental results on a real-world logistics scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion rate, resource utilization, and adaptability to dynamic changes.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatar Representation on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have become increasingly popular, but the impact of personalized avatar representation on user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study that investigates how customized avatar features influence user presence, engagement, and emotional responses in VR environments. Our results show that users who created personalized avatars reported higher levels of presence and enjoyment compared to those with default avatars. Furthermore, we identify specific design factors, such as facial similarity and body type, that significantly affect user experience. Our findings have implications for the design of VR systems and avatar representation in various domains, including gaming, education, and therapy.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Semantic Embeddings and Hierarchical Clustering
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to document retrieval, which leverages semantic embeddings and hierarchical clustering to improve search efficiency and relevance. We introduce a neural network-based model that learns to represent documents as dense vectors, capturing their semantic relationships and facilitating fast similarity searches. Our method is further enhanced by a hierarchical clustering algorithm, which organizes the document collection into a navigation-friendly structure. Experimental results on a large-scale text dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and query response time compared to traditional keyword-based search methods.

title: Efficient Human-AI Collaboration for Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems that collaborate with humans can significantly improve task efficiency. However, current systems often rely on manual turn-taking, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel human-AI collaboration framework, 'TaskAlign', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize dialogue flow and task allocation. TaskAlign incorporates a neural network-based dialogue manager that adaptively adjusts its strategy based on user feedback and task progress. Experimental results on a task-oriented dialogue dataset demonstrate that TaskAlign achieves a 25% reduction in task completion time and a 15% increase in user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art systems.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Healthcare Interactions
paper_abstract: This paper presents an empirical study on the design of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) for healthcare interactions, focusing on inclusivity for users with disabilities. We conducted participatory design workshops with healthcare providers, patients, and accessibility experts to co-create ECA prototypes that address the needs of diverse user groups. Our findings highlight the importance of personalized avatars, multimodal input/output, and culturally sensitive dialogue management. We propose a set of design guidelines for ECAs that promote equal access to healthcare information and services, and evaluate their effectiveness in a quantitative user study.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HierMA', which learns to coordinate agents at both local and global levels. The framework consists of a high-level coordinator that sets goals for individual agents, which then learn to achieve these goals using deep reinforcement learning. We evaluate HierMA in a simulated robotic soccer domain and demonstrate improved coordination and task accomplishment compared to decentralized and centralized approaches. Our results have implications for real-world applications such as search and rescue, and autonomous vehicles.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have become a crucial component in various AI applications. However, existing methods often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand the learned representations. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that learns explainable knowledge graph embeddings. HGAT incorporates multi-hop attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between entities and their attributes. We introduce a sparsity-inducing regularization term to promote interpretable attention weights, enabling the identification of influential entities and relationships. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in link prediction and entity classification tasks, while providing insights into the learned representations.

title: Incremental View Maintenance for Dynamic Graph Databases
paper_abstract: View maintenance is a crucial task in graph databases, as it enables efficient query answering over dynamic graph data. Existing solutions often suffer from high computational overhead and data staleness. In this paper, we introduce 'GraphView', an incremental view maintenance approach that leverages graph structural properties to minimize recomputation. GraphView employs a novel delta-based maintenance strategy, which adaptively updates views based on the frequency and locality of graph updates. Our experiments on various graph datasets demonstrate that GraphView outperforms state-of-the-art solutions by up to 3x in terms of maintenance time and reduces data staleness by 50%.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents. Existing methods employ dense passage embeddings, which can be computationally expensive and require large-scale indexing. This paper proposes Hierarchical Document Representation (HDR), a novel approach that represents documents as a hierarchy of coarse-to-fine embeddings. Our method leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant sections and sentences, reducing the computational cost of passage retrieval. Experimental results on the Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets demonstrate that HDR achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing the indexing time by 3.5x and the retrieval time by 2x.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but personalized experiences can have unintended consequences on user engagement. This paper presents a mixed-methods study examining the effects of personalization on user engagement in VR interfaces. We developed a VR platform that adapts to individual user preferences and conducted a user study with 30 participants. Our results show that while personalization generally increases user engagement, it can also lead to a sense of discomfort and unease, particularly among users with high levels of anxiety. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of VR interfaces and propose guidelines for creating personalized VR experiences that balance user engagement with user comfort.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complexity and nuance of patent documents. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks, which learns to identify relevant expansion terms from a large corpus of patent texts. Our model, called PatentNet, incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture both local and global context in patent documents. Experimental results on a standard patent retrieval dataset show that PatentNet outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Designing Visually Impaired-Friendly Touchscreen Interactions using Tactile Feedback and Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Touchscreen devices often pose significant accessibility challenges for visually impaired individuals. This paper presents a novel approach to enhancing touchscreen interaction accessibility through the integration of tactile feedback and machine learning-based gesture recognition. We designed and evaluated a wearable tactile feedback system that provides haptic cues to guide users' fingers during gesture-based interactions. Our machine learning model, trained on a dataset of gesture samples from visually impaired users, achieves an accuracy of 92.5% in recognizing gestures. User studies demonstrate significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional touchscreen interfaces.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Neural-based Term Dependency Modeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, yet its effectiveness is often hindered by the lack of nuanced term dependencies. This paper presents a novel neural-based approach, TermDep, which captures contextual relationships between terms using graph convolutional networks. By integrating TermDep into a state-of-the-art query expansion framework, we demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets. Our analysis reveals that TermDep better captures latent term associations, leading to more informative and diverse expanded queries.

title: Hierarchical Attentional Neural Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. While deep learning models have shown promising results, they often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand the reasoning behind their predictions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attentional neural network (HATN) architecture that detects anomalies in time-series data while providing explainable results. HATN combines local and global attention mechanisms to highlight relevant features and time-steps contributing to anomaly detection. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that HATN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and interpretability.

title: Designing Adaptive Gestural Interfaces for Assistive Technology using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often struggle to interact with technology due to limited dexterity or mobility. This paper presents an adaptive gestural interface framework, 'GestARL', that utilizes reinforcement learning to personalize user interfaces for assistive technology. GestARL learns to recognize and adapt to unique gestural patterns, enabling more accurate and efficient interaction. We evaluate GestARL on a dataset of users with cerebral palsy, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction time and accuracy compared to traditional interface designs.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, autonomous agents face the challenge of efficiently allocating tasks while adapting to changing conditions. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework, 'DynaTA', which leverages multi-agent learning and graph theory to optimize task assignments. DynaTA enables agents to learn from experience and communicate with each other to resolve conflicts, resulting in improved task completion rates and reduced latency. We evaluate DynaTA in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating its effectiveness in coping with uncertain and dynamic environments.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems have made significant progress with the advent of deep learning, but their opaqueness hinders trust and understanding. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages multi-modal inputs (text, speech, and vision) to generate interpretable responses. HAN uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to focus on relevant input modalities, contextualize user queries, and provide explicit explanations for its responses. Our experiments on a large-scale multi-modal dialogue dataset demonstrate improved response accuracy, fluency, and human-evaluated explainability compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. We propose an autonomous framework, 'AgentTA', which enables agents to learn optimal task assignments in dynamic environments. AgentTA leverages a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a deep Q-network to learn task allocation policies. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that AgentTA outperforms traditional auction-based methods in terms of task completion rate and resource utilization. Our approach has potential applications in real-world domains such as search and rescue, smart manufacturing, and autonomous vehicles.

title: Enhancing Gesture Recognition with Personalized Haptic Feedback in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often struggle to accurately recognize user gestures, leading to frustrating interactions. This paper presents a novel approach that incorporates personalized haptic feedback to improve gesture recognition in VR. Our system, 'HapGR', uses a machine learning model to learn users' individual gesture patterns and adapt haptic cues to provide real-time feedback. We conducted a user study with 30 participants and demonstrated a significant reduction in gesture recognition errors (25.1%) compared to a baseline VR system. Our results show that HapGR enhances the overall VR experience, enabling more intuitive and effective user interactions.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Path Finding with Hierarchical Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex, dynamic environments, multi-agent systems often struggle to efficiently allocate tasks and navigate through crowded spaces. This paper introduces a decentralized, hierarchical framework for task allocation and path finding, applicable to various domains such as robotics, traffic management, and smart cities. Our approach leverages a novel, two-layered architecture that combines a top-down task allocator with a bottom-up path planner, enabling agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and optimize their routes in real-time. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced navigation times compared to existing, centralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-time Data Warehousing with Skew Handling
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing (RTDW) has become a crucial component of modern business intelligence, as it enables organizations to make timely decisions based on fresh data. However, skewed datasets can severely degrade query performance, leading to unacceptable latency. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'SkewOpt', which leverages advanced statistical methods to detect and mitigate skew in RTDW. SkewOpt incorporates a cost-based optimization algorithm that iteratively refines query plans to minimize latency and maximize throughput. Experimental results on a large-scale RTDW system demonstrate that SkewOpt achieves significant performance improvements compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Dialogue Management for Task-Oriented Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Task-oriented conversational agents have become ubiquitous in various applications, including customer service and virtual assistants. However, their dialogue management systems often struggle to effectively incorporate contextual information and adapt to evolving user goals. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based dialogue management framework that leverages both utterance-level and conversation-level representations to generate more coherent and goal-oriented responses. Our experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in dialogue success rate and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art approaches, particularly in complex, multi-turn conversations.

title: Designing Gesture-Based Authentication for Older Adults: A Study on Usability and Security
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for authentication methods that are accessible and secure for older adults. This paper presents a gesture-based authentication system designed specifically for older adults, leveraging HCI principles to minimize cognitive load and error rates. We conducted a usability study with 30 participants aged 65+, evaluating the system's performance and comparing it to traditional password-based authentication. Our results show that the gesture-based system significantly outperforms traditional methods in terms of login success rates and user satisfaction, while maintaining robust security against shoulder-surfing attacks.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Social Media
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in social media has become increasingly important for sentiment analysis and mental health monitoring. However, existing approaches struggle to effectively fuse and weigh multi-modal inputs (e.g., text, images, audio) from diverse platforms. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that adaptively learns to focus on relevant modalities and features for efficient emotion detection. Experimental results on a large-scale, multi-modal social media dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving improved accuracy and robustness in the presence of noisy or missing data.

title: Designing Adaptive Visual Feedback for Gesture-based Interfaces in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces in virtual reality (VR) often suffer from low accuracy and user frustration due to inadequate visual feedback. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive visual feedback for gesture recognition in VR. We propose a machine learning-based framework that dynamically adjusts the visual feedback based on the user's performance, gesture complexity, and cognitive load. Our user study with 30 participants shows that the adaptive feedback significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy and reduces user frustration, enabling more intuitive and immersive VR experiences.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization in DDS remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of data distribution and communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, called GraphIX, which models the data distribution and query patterns in a DDS as a graph. GraphIX leverages graph algorithms to identify optimal query execution plans, reducing the communication overhead and improving query response times. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GraphIX outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques in DDS by up to 3x.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommendation systems have become increasingly important in modern e-commerce and social media platforms. However, existing collaborative filtering methods suffer from scalability issues and limited model capacity. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively aggregate user and item features from multiple graphs. Experimental results on large-scale benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN achieves significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods, while maintaining interpretable and explainable results.

title: Designing Proxemic-Aware Interfaces for Enhanced Collaborative Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Collaborative virtual reality (VR) experiences often lack effective communication and spatial awareness among users. This paper presents a proxemic-aware interface design framework that incorporates subtle, non-verbal cues to enhance collaboration and social presence in VR. Our approach leverages machine learning-based gesture recognition, gaze tracking, and spatial audio cues to create an immersive and engaging experience. We evaluate our design through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in user satisfaction, communication efficiency, and overall collaboration quality.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Neural Search Engines using Implicit Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have revolutionized information retrieval by incorporating neural networks into the ranking process. However, their performance is heavily reliant on explicit user feedback, which is often scarce. This paper proposes an adaptive re-ranking framework that leverages implicit feedback, such as dwell time and scrolling behavior, to improve search result ranking. We introduce a novel neural architecture that combines explicit and implicit signals, and demonstrate its effectiveness on a large-scale search engine dataset. Experimental results show significant improvements in ranking quality and user engagement metrics.

title: Investigating the Effects of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology advances, human-robot collaboration (HRC) in VR environments is becoming increasingly important. This paper explores the impact of embodiment on HRC in VR, where humans and robots work together to accomplish tasks. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, using a custom-built VR platform that enables real-time communication and collaboration between humans and robots. Our results show that embodied robots, which have a physical presence in the VR environment, lead to higher user satisfaction, trust, and task performance compared to non-embodied robots. We also identify key design factors that influence embodiment effects, including robot appearance, movement, and interaction cues.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Cultural and Linguistic Biases in Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their language understanding capabilities often reflect the cultural and linguistic biases of their designers. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the effects of cultural and linguistic biases in dialogue systems, focusing on the nuances of language usage across different demographics. We propose a novel framework for culturally sensitive dialogue design, incorporating participatory design methods and machine learning-based bias detection. Our evaluation on a diverse set of users shows that our approach significantly improves the conversational experience, reducing errors and increasing user satisfaction.

title: Scalable Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries on Modern Storage Systems
paper_abstract: As data sizes continue to grow, efficient indexing techniques are crucial for supporting fast query performance. This paper presents 'RiFT', a novel indexing method optimized for multi-dimensional range queries on modern storage systems. RiFT leverages the parallelization capabilities of modern SSDs and HDDs to accelerate query processing. We propose a hierarchical indexing structure that adaptively partitions the data space, reducing the number of disk accesses and improving query latency. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that RiFT outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving up to 3x speedup for complex range queries.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts system performance and scalability. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We model the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and employ a deep Q-network (DQN) to learn an optimal query execution plan. Our approach, called 'RL-Opt', adapts to changing workload patterns and database statistics, outperforming traditional optimization techniques in terms of query latency and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate the effectiveness of RL-Opt in improving system performance and scalability.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Resource Optimization in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing resources are often underutilized, leading to significant energy waste and operational costs. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach to optimize resource allocation in cloud data centers. We design a hierarchical DRL framework that integrates a high-level resource manager with low-level controller agents, enabling adaptive resource provisioning and workload scheduling. Experimental results on a real-world cloud infrastructure show that our approach achieves up to 30% energy savings and 25% reduction in response times compared to state-of-the-art heuristics.

title: Enhancing Query Reformulation using Reinforcement Learning for Improving Search Engine Efficiency
paper_abstract: Query reformulation is a crucial task in search engines to improve the retrieval of relevant documents. Traditional methods rely on manual rules or supervised learning, which may not generalize well to diverse query patterns. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning approach, 'RL-Reform', that learns to reformulate queries by interacting with a simulated search engine environment. We design a novel reward function that balances the trade-off between query similarity and relevance improvement. Experimental results on a large-scale query log dataset demonstrate that RL-Reform outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of search engine efficiency and user satisfaction.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Embeddings and Incremental Clustering
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a fundamental task in knowledge graph construction, where the goal is to resolve ambiguities in entity references. Existing approaches often struggle with scalability and incremental updates, leading to poor performance on large, dynamic knowledge graphs. This paper proposes a novel graph-based embedding method, 'GraphED', which leverages incremental clustering to efficiently disambiguate entities. By representing entities as graph embeddings and clustering them based on similarity, GraphED achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets while supporting incremental updates and handling large-scale knowledge graphs. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of GraphED in resolving entity ambiguities.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for cooperative resource allocation in smart grids. We model the grid as a decentralized system consisting of autonomous agents, each responsible for managing a subset of resources. The agents learn to cooperate through a novel, graph-based communication mechanism that enables the exchange of local information. Our approach is evaluated on a realistic simulation platform, demonstrating improved efficiency and resilience in the face of uncertain demand and supply patterns. We show that the proposed method outperforms traditional, centralized optimization techniques in terms of both resource utilization and response time.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to improve the lives of people with disabilities, but existing systems often fail to account for individual differences in motor abilities. This paper presents a novel approach to adaptive gesture recognition, which leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to learn personalized gesture models for users with disabilities. Our system, ' GestureAdapt', incorporates a user-centered design approach, involving participatory design and co-creation with users to ensure that the system is accessible, usable, and meets their needs. We evaluate GestureAdapt with a user study involving 20 participants with mobility and dexterity impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Event Detection
paper_abstract: Event detection from multi-modal data (e.g., text, images, videos) is a crucial task in various applications. However, existing methods often rely on complex neural architectures, making it challenging to interpret the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of both self-attention and graph attention mechanisms. Our HAN model detects events by learning to focus on relevant modalities, entities, and relationships, providing explainable insights into the detection process. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving event detection accuracy while enhancing model interpretability.
